original: appaṭisamaṭṭhena seṭṭho”ti niṭṭhaṃ gantvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – jeṭṭho bhavaṃ gotamo
analyzed: a paṭisamaṭṭhena seṭṭhaḥ iti niṭṭham gantvā bhagavantam etat avoca jeṭṭhaḥ bhavam gotamaḥ
translated: “The Lord is the best, the Lord is supreme, the Lord is incomparable.”🔽And after saying this, he expressed his appreciation of the Lord’s teaching with the words:🔽“Excellent, Lord! Excellent, Lord! It is as if someone were to set up what had been knocked down, or to point out the way to one who had got lost, or to bring an oil-lamp into a dark place, so that those with eyes could see what was there.🔽And so it is that the Lord has expounded the Dhamma in various ways.

original: seṭṭho bhavaṃ gotamoti. Evañca pana vatvā puna taṃ bhagavato dhammadesanaṃ abbhanumodamāno🔽abhikkantaṃ bho gotamātiādimāha. Taṃ vuttatthamevāti.🔽2. Sīhasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: seṭṭhaḥ bhavam gotamaḥ iti evam ca pana vatvā puna tam bhagavataḥ dhamma desanam abbhanumodamāno  abhikkantam bho gotama ati ādim āha tam vutta ttham eva iti  sīha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: And the Lord consented to stay for the Rains Retreat in Vesall.🔽In the second discourse, “well-known” means well-known, renowned, famous.

original: 12. Dutiye abhiññātāti ñātā paññātā pākaṭā. Santhāgāreti mahājanassa vissamanatthāya
analyzed: dutiye abhiññātā ati ñātā paññātā pākaṭā santhāgārā iti mahājanassa vissamana tthāya
translated: “Assembly hall” is a hall built for the purpose of giving rest to the people.

original: kate agāre. Sā kira santhāgārasālā nagaramajjhe ahosi, catūsu ṭhānesu ṭhitānaṃ paññāyati,
analyzed: kate agāre sā kira santhā āgāra sālā nagara majjhe ahosi catūsu ṭhānesu ṭhitānam paññāyati
translated: It was a hall for public meetings in the middle of the city, visible from the four directions,

original: catūhi disāhi āgatamanussā paṭhamaṃ tattha vissamitvā pacchā attano attano phāsukaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: catūhi disāhi āgata manussā paṭhamam tattha vissamitvā pacchā attano attano phāsuka ṭṭhānam
translated: where people coming from the four directions first rested and then went to their own comfortable places.

original: gacchanti. Rājakulānaṃ rajjakiccasantharaṇatthāya kataṃ agārantipi vadantiyeva. Tattha
analyzed: gacchanti rāja kulānam rajja kicca santharaṇa tthāya katam
translated: They say it was built for the purpose of carrying on the business of the royal family.

original: hi nisīditvā licchavirājāno rajjakiccaṃ santharanti karonti vicārenti. Sannisinnāti
analyzed: hi nisīditvā licchavi rājānaḥ rajja kiccam santharanti karonti vicārenti sannisinnā ati
translated: For there the Licchavi kings sat down and carried on the business of the royal family, transacted it, and deliberated on it.🔽“Seated” means

original: tesaṃ nisīdanatthaññeva paññattesu mahārahavarapaccattharaṇesu samussitasetacchattesu🔽āsanesu sannisinnā. Anekapariyāyena buddhassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsantīti rājakule kiccañceva
analyzed: tesam paññattesu mahā raha vara paccattharaṇesu samussita seta chattesu  āsanesu sannisinnāḥ aneka pariyāyena buddhassa vaṇṇam bhāsanti iti rāja kule kiccam ca iva
translated: and on costly couches spread with choice rugs.🔽They were speaking praise of the Buddha in many a figure.

original: lokatthacariyañca vicāretvā anekehi kāraṇehi buddhassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsanti kathenti dīpenti.
analyzed: lokattha cariyam ca vicāretvā anekehi kāraṇehi buddhassa vaṇṇam bhāsanti kathenti dīpenti
translated: In the royal palace they were discussing the duties of kings and the welfare of the world, and in many a way they were speaking praise of the Buddha, telling forth his glory.

original: Paṇḍitā hi te rājāno saddhā pasannā sotāpannāpi sakadāgāminopi anāgāminopi ariyasāvakā,
analyzed: paṇḍitāḥ hi te rājānaḥ saddhā pasannā sotāpannā api sakadāgāminaḥ api anāgāminaḥ api ariya sāvakā
translated: For these kings were wise, and they had faith and confidence, and some of them were Stream-Winners, some Once-Returners, and some Never-Returners.

original: te sabbepi lokiyajaṭaṃ chinditvā buddhādīnaṃ tiṇṇaṃ ratanānaṃ vaṇṇaṃ bhāsanti. Tattha
analyzed: te sabbe api lokiya jaṭam chinditvā buddha ādīnam tiṇṇam ratanānam vaṇṇam bhāsanti tattha
translated: All of them had cut off the tangle of worldly thoughts, and they were speaking praise of the Buddha and the other two Jewels.

original: tividho buddhavaṇṇo nāma cariyavaṇṇo, sarīravaṇṇo, guṇavaṇṇoti. Tatrime rājāno cariyāya
analyzed: tividhaḥ buddha vaṇṇaḥ nāma cariya vaṇṇaḥ sarīra vaṇṇaḥ guṇa vaṇṇaḥ iti tatra ime rājānaḥ cariyāya
translated: Now there are three kinds of praise of the Buddha: praise of his career, praise of his body, and praise of his special qualities.

original: vaṇṇaṃ ārabhiṃsu – “dukkaraṃ vata kataṃ sammāsambuddhena kappasatasahassādhikāni
analyzed: vaṇṇam ārabhiṃsu dukkaram vata katam sammāsambuddhena kappa sata sahassa adhikāni
translated: Here these kings began with praise of his career: “How hard he worked! For a hundred thousand aeons and more

original: cattāri asaṅkheyyāni dasa pāramiyo, dasa upapāramiyo, dasa paramatthapāramiyoti samattiṃsa
analyzed: cattāri asaṅkheyyāni dasa pāramiyaḥ dasa upapāramiyaḥ dasa paramattha pāramiyaḥ ti samattiṃsa
translated: he fulfilled the ten Perfections, the ten Higher Perfections, and the ten Ultimate Perfections, making thirty in all.

original: pāramiyo pūrentena, ñātatthacariyaṃ, lokatthacariyaṃ, buddhacariyaṃ matthakaṃ pāpetvā
analyzed: pāramiyaḥ pūrentena ñāta ttha cariyam loka ttha cariyam buddha cariyam matthakam pāpetvā
translated: while fulfilling the Perfections, while practising for the sake of knowledge, while practising for the sake of the world, while practising the Buddha-practice,🔽while making the five great sacrifices.”

original: pañca mahāpariccāge pariccajantenā”ti aḍḍhacchakkehi jātakasatehi buddhavaṇṇaṃ kathentā
analyzed: pañca mahāpariccāge pariccajantena ati aḍḍhacchakkehi jātaka satehi buddha vaṇṇam kathentā
translated: and so on, with the five hundred and fifty Jātakas, they praised the Buddha,

original: tusitabhavanaṃ pāpetvā ṭhapayiṃsu.
analyzed: tusitabhavanam ṭhapayiṃsu
translated: and then they took him to the Tusita heaven and left him there.

original: Dhammassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsantā pana “tena bhagavatā dhammo desito, nikāyato pañca nikāyā,
analyzed: dhammassa vaṇṇam bhāsantā pana tena bhagavatā dhammo desito nikāyataḥ pañca nikāyā
translated: But when they came to praise the Dhamma, they said: “The Dhamma was taught by the Blessed One. As to the collections, there are the five collections.

original: piṭakato tīṇi piṭakāni, aṅgato nava aṅgāni, khandhato caturāsītidhammakkhandhasahassānī”ti
analyzed: piṭakataḥ tīṇi piṭakāni aṅgataḥ nava aṅgāni khandhataḥ caturāsīti dhammakkhandha sahassāni iti
translated: As to the baskets, there are the three baskets. As to the limbs, there are the nine limbs. As to the aggregates, there are eighty-four thousand aggregates of the True Idea.”

original: koṭṭhāsavasena dhammaguṇaṃ kathayiṃsu.
analyzed: koṭṭhāsa vasena dhamma guṇam kathayiṃsu
translated: and so on, they praised the Dhamma by way of the aggregates.

original: Saṅghassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsantā satthu dhammadesanaṃ sutvā “paṭiladdhasaddhā kulaputtā
analyzed: saṅghassa vaṇṇam bhāsantā satthu dhamma desanam sutvā paṭiladdha saddhā kula puttā
translated: But when they came to praise the Community, they said: “The clansmen who had faith when the Master taught the Dhamma

original: bhogakkhandhañceva ñātiparivaṭṭañca pahāya setacchattaṃ oparajjaṃ senāpatiseṭṭhibhaṇḍāgārikaṭṭhānantarādīni
analyzed: bhoga kkhandham ca iva ñāti parivaṭṭam ca pahāya seta chattam oparajjam senāpati seṭṭhi bhaṇḍāgārika ṭṭhānantara ādīni
translated: and who abandoned the mass of their possessions and their circle of relatives, and the white parasol and the deputy kingship and the office of general and the office of treasurer and the office of minister and so on,

original: agaṇetvā nikkhamma satthu varasāsane pabbajanti. Setacchattaṃ pahāya pabbajitānaṃ
analyzed: a gaṇetvā nikkhamma satthu vara sāsane pabbajanti seta chattam pahāya pabbajitānam
translated: and went forth into the Master’s supreme Dispensation, and who, having gone forth, abandoned the white parasol,

original: bhaddiyarājamahākappinapukkusātiādīnaṃ rājapabbajitānaṃyeva buddhakāle asītisahassāni🔽ahesuṃ. Anekakoṭisataṃ dhanaṃ pahāya pabbajitānaṃ pana yasakulaputtasoṇaseṭṭhiputtaraṭṭhapālakulaputtādīnaṃ
analyzed: bhaddiya rāja mahākappina pukkusa ati ādīnam rāja pabbajitānam yeva buddha kāle asīti sahassāni  ahesum aneka koṭi satam dhanam pahāya pabbajitānam pana yasa kula putta soṇa seṭṭhi putta raṭṭhapāla kula putta ādīnam
translated: There were eighty thousand who went forth in the dispensation of the Buddha, such as the kings Bhaddiya, Mahā Kappa, Pukkusāti, and so forth.🔽But there is no limit to the number of those who went forth in the dispensation of the Buddha, such as the young men of good families Yasaka, Soṇa, Setthiputta, Rāṭṭhapāla, and so forth, who renounced many hundreds of thousands of gold coins.

original: paricchedo natthi. Evarūpā ca evarūpā ca kulaputtā satthu sāsane pabbajantī”ti pabbajjāsaṅkhepavasena
analyzed: paricchedaḥ natthi evarūpā ca evarūpā ca kula puttā satthu sāsane pabbajanti iti pabbajjā saṅkhepa vasena
translated: Such and such young men of good families went forth in the dispensation of the Buddha.”

original: saṅghaguṇe kathayiṃsu.
analyzed: saṅgha guṇe kathayiṃsu
translated: Thus they spoke in praise of the virtues of the Sangha in brief, by way of the going forth.🔽Sīha the general

original: Sīho senāpatīti evaṃnāmako senāya adhipati. Vesāliyañhi satta sahassāni satta satāni
analyzed: sīhaḥ senāpati iti evaṃnāmakaḥ senāya adhipati vesāliyam hi satta sahassāni satta satāni
translated: Sīha the general was the commander of the army. In Vesālī there were seven thousand, seven hundred,

original: satta ca rājāno. Te sabbepi sannipatitvā sabbesaṃ manaṃ gahetvā “raṭṭhaṃ vicāretuṃ
analyzed: satta ca rājāno te sabbe api sannipatitvā sabbesam manam gahetvā raṭṭham vicāretuṃ
translated: and seven kings. All of them assembled together and, after winning over the minds of all, they searched for a man who was able to investigate the kingdom.

original: samatthaṃ ekaṃ vicinathā”ti vicinantā sīhaṃ rājakumāraṃ disvā “ayaṃ sakkhissatī”ti
analyzed: samattham ekam vicinatha ati vicinantā sīham rāja kumāram disvā ayam sakkhissati iti
translated: While searching, they saw Prince Sīha and thought, “He will be able to do it.”

original: sanniṭṭhānaṃ katvā tassa rattamaṇivaṇṇaṃ kambalapariyonaddhaṃ senāpaticchattaṃ adaṃsu.
analyzed: sanniṭṭhānam katvā tassa ratta maṇi vaṇṇam kambala pariyonaddham senāpati chattam adaṃsu
translated: They made their decision and gave him the general’s parasol, which was covered with a woolen cloth of the color of a precious gem.

A counter-argument in conformity with the Dhamma by others is a counter-argument in conformity with the Dhamma by others after that. A counter-argument in conformity with the Dhamma by you or by others is a counter-argument in conformity with the Dhamma by you or by others after that.🔽A counter-argument in conformity with the Dhamma by you or by others does not come to a reason that is a place for censure by the wise in the least degree.🔽This is what is said: “Is there not a reason for censure in your argument in any way at all?”

original: vāde gārayhaṃ kāraṇaṃ natthīti. Anabbhakkhātukāmāti na abhūtena vattukāmā. Atthi
analyzed: vāde gārayham kāraṇam natthi iti an abbhakkhātu kāmā ati na abhūtena vattu kāmā atthi
translated: Not wishing to misrepresent: not wishing to speak falsely.

original: sīhapariyāyotiādīnaṃ attho verañjakaṇḍe āgatanayeneva veditabbo. Paramena assāsenāti
analyzed: sīha pariyāyaḥ ti ādīnam atthaḥ verañja kaṇḍe āgata nayena iva veditabbo paramena assāsena ati
translated: The meaning of the words “lion’s roar” and so on should be understood in the way given in the Verañjā Khandhaka. With the supreme comfort:

original: catumaggacatuphalasaṅkhātena uttamena. Assāsāya dhammaṃ desemīti assāsanatthāya santhambhanatthāya
analyzed: catu magga catu phala saṅkhātena uttamena assāsāya dhammam desemi iti assāsana tthāya santhambhana tthāya
translated: with the supreme comfort called the four paths and the four fruits. I teach the Dhamma for the sake of comfort: I teach the Dhamma for the sake of consolation, for the sake of support,

original: dhammaṃ desemi. Iti bhagavā aṭṭhahaṅgehi sīhassa senāpatissa dhammaṃ desesi.🔽Anuviccakāranti anuviditvā cintetvā tulayitvā kattabbaṃ karohīti vuttaṃ hoti. Sādhu🔽hotīti sundaro hoti. Tumhādisasmiñhi maṃ disvā maṃ saraṇaṃ gacchante nigaṇṭhaṃ disvā
analyzed: dhammam desemi iti bhagavā aṭṭhahaṅgehi sīhassa senāpatissa dhammam desesi  anuviccakāran ti anuviditvā cintetvā tulayitvā kattabbam karohi iti vuttam hoti sādhu  hoti iti sundaraḥ tumhādisasmin hi mam disvā mam saraṇam gacchante nigaṇṭham disvā
translated: for the sake of comfort. Thus the Blessed One taught the Dhamma to the general Siha by means of the eight qualities of the lion.

original: nigaṇṭhaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchante “kiṃ ayaṃ sīho diṭṭhadiṭṭhameva saraṇaṃ gacchatī”ti garahā
analyzed: nigaṇṭham saraṇam gacchante kim ayam sīhaḥ diṭṭha diṭṭham eva saraṇam gacchati iti garahā
translated: After consideration: after having considered, after having reflected, after having deliberated, do what should be done, is what is said. It is good: it is beautiful. For when they see someone like you going for refuge to me, and when they see someone like you going for refuge to the Niganthas, the reproach arises: “Why does he go for refuge to whatever he sees?”

original: uppajjati, tasmā anuviccakāro tumhādisānaṃ sādhūti dasseti. Paṭākaṃ parihareyyunti
analyzed: uppajjati tasmai anuviccakāraḥ tumha ādisānam sādhu iti dasseti paṭākam parihareyyunti
translated: Therefore he shows that the practice of consideration is good for people like you. He should remove the banner:

original: te kira evarūpaṃ sāvakaṃ labhitvā “asuko nāma rājā vā rājamahāmatto vā seṭṭhi vā
analyzed: te kira evarūpam sāvakam labhitvā asukaḥ nāma rājā vā rāja mahāmattaḥ vā seṭṭhi vā
translated: it seems that when they get such a disciple, they say: “So-and-so, a king or a royal minister or a money-lender or a merchant,

original: amhākaṃ saraṇaṃ gato sāvako jāto”ti paṭākaṃ ukkhipitvā nagare ghosentā āhiṇḍanti.🔽Kasmā? Evaṃ no mahantabhāvo āvibhavissatīti ca. Sace panassa “kimahaṃ etesaṃ saraṇaṃ
analyzed: amhākam saraṇam gataḥ sāvakaḥ jātaḥ iti paṭākam ukkhipitvā nagare ghosentāḥ āhiṇḍanti  kasmai evam naḥ mahanta bhāvaḥ āvibhavissati iti ca sace panassa kim aham etesam saraṇam
translated: and he has gone for refuge to us and become our disciple.” And they went about the town proclaiming it with flags flying.

original: gato”ti vippaṭisāro uppajjeyya, tampi so “etesaṃ me saraṇagatabhāvaṃ bahū jānanti,
analyzed: gataḥ ti vippaṭisāraḥ uppajjeyya tam pi saḥ etesam me saraṇa gata bhāvam bahū jānanti
translated: Why? Thinking: “In this way our greatness will be made known.” But if he should get remorse, thinking: “What have I done by going for refuge to them?” he would dispel it, thinking: “Many people know that I have gone for refuge to them.

original: dukkhaṃ idāni paṭinivattitu”nti vinodetvā na paṭikkamissatīti ca. Tenāha – “paṭākaṃ
analyzed: dukkham idāni paṭinivattitun ti vinodetvā na paṭikkamissati iti ca tena āha paṭākam
translated: It is hard to turn back now.” Therefore it is said: “They would take down the flag.”🔽A place of rest: standing ready like a well-prepared drinking place.

original: parihareyyu”nti. Opānabhūtanti paṭiyattaudapāno viya ṭhitaṃ. Kulanti tava nivesanaṃ.
analyzed: parihareyyunti ṭhitam tava nivesanam
translated: Your family: your house.

original: Dātabbaṃ maññeyyāsīti pubbe dasapi vīsatipi saṭṭhipi jane āgate disvā natthīti avatvā🔽desi, idāni maṃ saraṇaṃ gatakāraṇamatteneva mā imesaṃ deyyadhammaṃ upacchindi. Sampattānañhi
analyzed: dātabbam maññeyyāsi iti pubbe dasapi vīsatipi saṭṭhipi jane āgate disvā natthi iti avatvā  desi idāni mam saraṇam gata kāraṇa mattena iva mā imesam deyya dhammam upacchindi sampattānam hi
translated: You should think it should be given: formerly, when ten, twenty, or thirty people came, you did not say “There is none,”🔽but you gave. Now, do not stop giving them what should be given just because they have gone for refuge to us. For what should be given🔽must be given to those who have arrived.

original: dātabbamevāti ovadi. Sutaṃ metaṃ, bhanteti kuto sutanti? Nigaṇṭhānaṃ santikā. Te
analyzed: dātabbam eva ati ovadi sutam mā etam bhante iti kutas sutam ti nigaṇṭhānam santikā te
translated: I have heard this, venerable sir: from the Niganthas.

original: kira kulagharesu evaṃ pakāsenti “mayaṃ yassa kassaci sampattassa dātabbanti vadāma,
analyzed: kira kula gharesu evam pakāsenti mayam yassa kassaci sampattassa dātabbanti vadāma
translated: and they proclaim it among the wealthy householders thus: ‘We say that what is given should be given to anyone at all.

original: samaṇo pana gotamo ‘mayhameva dānaṃ dātabbaṃ nāññesaṃ, mayhameva sāvakānaṃ dānaṃ🔽dātabbaṃ, nāññesaṃ sāvakānaṃ, mayhameva dinnaṃ dānaṃ mahapphalaṃ, nāññesaṃ, mayhameva
analyzed: samaṇaḥ pana gotamaḥ mayham eva dānam dātabbam na aññesam mayham eva sāvakānam dānam  dātabbam na aññesam sāvakānam mayham eva dinnam dānam mahapphalam na aññesam mayham eva
translated: But the recluse Gotama says: “Give only to me, not to others; give only to my disciples, not to others’ disciples; what is given to me is more fruitful than what is given to others, what is given to my disciples is more fruitful than what is given to others’ disciples.”’

original: sāvakānaṃ dinnaṃ mahapphalaṃ, nāññesa’nti evaṃ vadatī”ti. Taṃ sandhāya ayaṃ “sutaṃ meta”nti āha.
analyzed: sāvakānam dinnam mahapphalam evam vadati iti tam sandhāya ayam sutam mā itanti āha
translated: This is what I heard, and in this way I heard it.”

original: Anupubbiṃ kathanti dānānantaraṃ sīlaṃ, sīlānantaraṃ saggaṃ, saggānantaraṃ magganti🔽evaṃ anupaṭipāṭikathaṃ. Tattha dānakathanti idaṃ dānaṃ nāma sukhānaṃ nidānaṃ, sampattīnaṃ🔽mūlaṃ, bhogānaṃ patiṭṭhā, visamagatassa tāṇaṃ leṇaṃ gati parāyaṇaṃ, idhalokaparalokesu
analyzed: anupubbim kathanti dāna anantaram sīlam sīla anantaram saggam sagga anantaram magganti  evam anupaṭipāṭi katham tattha dāna kathanti idam dānam nāma sukhānam nidānam sampattīnam  mūlam bhogānam patiṭṭhā visama gatassa tāṇam leṇam gati parāyaṇam idha loka para lokesu
translated: “A talk in due course”: a talk on generosity followed by a talk on virtue, a talk on virtue followed by a talk on heaven, a talk on heaven followed by a talk on the noble path.

original: dānasadiso avassayo patiṭṭhā ārammaṇaṃ tāṇaṃ leṇaṃ gati parāyaṇaṃ natthi. Idañhi
analyzed: dāna sadisaḥ avassayaḥ patiṭṭhā ārammaṇam tāṇam leṇam gati parāyaṇam natthi idam hi
translated: Herein, a talk on generosity is this: “This generosity is the source of happiness, the root of prosperity, the foundation of sovereignty, the means of livelihood for dependents, the means of support for oneself, the bestower of glory, the bestower of fame, the bestower of heaven, the means of attaining sovereignty for a warrior, the means of attaining the throne for a king’s son, the means of attaining the position of a guildmaster for a merchant’s son, the means of attaining the position of a town chief for a farmer’s son, the means of attaining the position of a brahmin for a brahmin’s son, the means of attaining the position of a chief for a hunter, the means of attaining the position of a chief for a chief’s son, the means of attaining the position of a chief for a chief’s daughter, the means of attaining the position of a chief for a chief’s wife, the means of attaining the position of a chief for a chief’s slave, the means of attaining the position of a chief for a chief’s man, the means of attaining the position of a chief for a chief’s woman, the means of attaining the position of a chief for a chief’s eunuch, the means of attaining the position of a chief for a chief’s boy, the means of attaining the position of a chief for a chief’s girl, the means of attaining the position of a chief for a chief’s slave girl, the means of attaining the position of a chief for a chief’s slave boy, the means of attaining the position of a chief for a chief’s slave woman, the means of attaining the position of a chief for a chief’s slave eunuch,

original: avassayaṭṭhena ratanamayasīhāsanasadisaṃ, patiṭṭhānaṭṭhena mahāpathavīsadisaṃ, ārammaṇaṭṭhena
analyzed: avassaya ṭṭhena ratana maya sīhāsana sadisam patiṭṭhāna ṭṭhena mahā pathavī sadisam ārammaṇa ṭṭhena
translated: It is like a jewel-studded lion-throne in the sense of being the support for the noble qualities of the noble disciples; it is like the great earth in the sense of being the foundation for the world; it is like a rope for tethering the mind in the sense of being the object of the jhānas.

original: ālambanarajjusadisaṃ. Idañhi dukkhanittharaṇaṭṭhena nāvā, samassāsanaṭṭhena saṅgāmasūro,
analyzed: ālambana rajju sadisam idam hi dukkha nittharaṇa ṭhena nāvā samassāsana ṭhena
translated: For the Dhamma is like a ship for crossing the ocean of suffering, like a hero in battle for the destruction of the defilements,

original: bhayaparittāṇaṭṭhena susaṅkhatanagaraṃ, maccheramalādīhi anupalittaṭṭhena padumaṃ,
analyzed: bhaya parittāṇa ṭṭhena susaṅkhata nagaram macchera mala ādīhi an upalitta ṭṭhena padumam
translated: like a well-fortified city for protection from the dangers of the world, like a lotus for remaining unstained by the mud of avarice and so on,

original: tesaṃ nidahanaṭṭhena aggi, durāsadaṭṭhena āsiviso, asantāsanaṭṭhena sīho, balavantaṭṭhena
analyzed: tesam nidahana ṭṭhena aggi durāsada ṭṭhena āsi visaḥ asanta asana ṭṭhena sīhaḥ balavanta ṭṭhena
translated: like a fire for burning the fuel of defilements, like a poisonous snake for striking down the proud, like a lion for terrifying the deer, like an elephant for crushing the enemies,

original: hatthī, abhimaṅgalasammataṭṭhena setavasabho, khemantabhūmisampāpanaṭṭhena valāhako
analyzed: hatthī abhimaṅgala sammata ṭṭhena setavasabhaḥ khemanta bhūmi sampāpana ṭṭhena valāhako
translated: like a white bull for being the most excellent of all, like a rain cloud for bringing down the rain of the noble path,🔽like a king for bestowing the sovereignty of Nibbāna.

original: assarājā. Dānaṃ nāmetaṃ mayā gatamaggo, mayheso vaṃso, mayā dasa pāramiyo pūrentena
analyzed: assa rājā dānam nāma etam mayā gata maggaḥ mayha isaḥ vaṃsaḥ mayā dasa pāramiyaḥ pūrentena
translated: “This gift is the path I have gone,” “This is my lineage,” “I, fulfilling the ten perfections,”

original: velāmamahāyañño, mahāgovindamahāyañño, mahāsudassanamahāyañño, vessantaramahāyaññoti,
analyzed: velāma mahāyaññaḥ mahāgovinda mahāyaññaḥ mahāsudassana mahāyaññaḥ vessantara mahāyaññaḥ iti
translated: “The sacrifice of Vessāmitta, the sacrifice of Mahāgovinda, the sacrifice of Mahāsudassana, the sacrifice of Vessantara,”

original: anekamahāyaññā pavattitā, sasabhūtena jalitaaggikkhandhe attānaṃ niyyādentena sampattayācakānaṃ
analyzed: aneka mahā yaññā pavatti tā sasa bhūtena jalita aggi kkhandhe attānam niyyādentena sampatta yācakānam
translated: He gave away his own body to beggars who came to him, by throwing himself into a great fire that was burning with many sacrificial offerings.

original: cittaṃ gahitaṃ. Dānañhi loke sakkasampattiṃ deti mārasampattiṃ brahmasampattiṃ, cakkavattisampattiṃ,
analyzed: cittam gahitam dānam hi loke sakka sampattim deti māra sampattim brahma sampattim cakkavatti sampattim
translated: For generosity gives the world the success of Sakka, the success of Mara, the success of Brahma, the success of a Wheel-turning Monarch,

original: sāvakapāramīñāṇaṃ, paccekabodhiñāṇaṃ, abhisambodhiñāṇaṃ detīti evamādidānaguṇappaṭisaṃyuttaṃ kathaṃ.
analyzed: sāvaka pāramī ñāṇam paccekabodhi ñāṇam abhisambodhi ñāṇam deti iti evamādi dāna guṇa paṭisaṃyuttam katham
translated: the knowledge of the perfection of discipleship, the knowledge of the enlightenment of a Paccekabuddha, and the knowledge of the supreme enlightenment.

original: Yasmā pana dānaṃ dento sīlaṃ samādātuṃ sakkoti, tasmā tadanantaraṃ sīlakathaṃ kathesi.🔽Sīlakathanti sīlaṃ nāmetaṃ avassayo patiṭṭhā ārammaṇaṃ tāṇaṃ leṇaṃ gati parāyaṇaṃ.
analyzed: yasmai pana dānam dento sīlam samādātum sakkoti tasmai tad anantaram sīla katham kathesi  sīlakathanti sīlam nāma etam avassayaḥ patiṭṭhā ārammaṇam tāṇam leṇam gati parāyaṇam
translated: But because one who gives generosity is able to undertake virtue, therefore next to generosity he expounded virtue.🔽“Virtue is a support, a foundation, a resting-place, a refuge, a haven, a destination, a final support.

original: Sīlaṃ nāmetaṃ mama vaṃso, ahaṃ saṅkhapālanāgarājakāle bhūridattanāgarājakāle campeyyanāgarājakāle🔽sīlavarājakāle mātuposakahatthirājakāle chaddantahatthirājakāleti anantesu attabhāvesu
analyzed: sīlam nāma itam mama aham saṅkhapāla nāga rāja kāle bhūridatta nāga rāja kāle campeyya nāga rāja kāle 🔽sīlava rāja kāle mātu posaka hatthi rāja kāle chaddanta hatthi rāja kāla iti anantesu atta bhāvesu
translated: This virtue is my family. In the course of my endless births in the past I was the nāga king Saṅkhapāla, the nāga king Bhūridatta, the nāga king Campeyya,🔽the king of horses named Somanassa, the king of horses named Valāhaka, the king of horses named Sūriya, the king of horses named Cūḷa-Sūriya, the king of horses named Mahati, the king of horses named Mahā-Sūriya, the king of horses named Kanthaka, the king of horses named Kanthaka-jāta, the king of horses named Kanthaka-paṇḍita, the king of horses named Kanthaka-paṇḍita-jāta, the king of horses named Kanthaka-paṇḍita-paṇḍita, the king of horses named Kanthaka-paṇḍita-paṇḍita-jāta, the king of horses named Kanthaka-paṇḍita-paṇḍita-paṇḍita, the king of horses named Kanthaka-paṇḍita-paṇḍita-paṇḍita-jāta, the king of horses named Kanthaka-paṇḍita-paṇḍita-paṇḍita-paṇḍita, the king of horses named Kanthaka-paṇḍita-paṇḍita-paṇḍita-paṇḍita-jāta, the king of horses named Kanthaka-paṇḍita-paṇḍita-paṇḍita-paṇḍita-paṇḍita, the king of horses named Kanthaka-paṇḍita-paṇḍita-paṇḍita-pa

original: sīlaṃ paripūresiṃ. Idhalokaparalokasampattīnañhi sīlasadiso avassayo patiṭṭhā ārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: sīlam idhaloka paraloka sampattīnam hi sīla sadisaḥ avassayaḥ patiṭṭhā ārammaṇam
translated: I fulfilled virtue. For there is no refuge, no support, no basis, no protection, no shelter, no final resort equal to virtue for the attainments in this world and the next.

original: tāṇaṃ leṇaṃ gati parāyaṇaṃ natthi, sīlālaṅkārasadiso alaṅkāro natthi, sīlapupphasadisaṃ🔽pupphaṃ natthi, sīlagandhasadiso gandho natthi. Sīlālaṅkārena hi alaṅkataṃ sīlagandhānulittaṃ
analyzed: tāṇam leṇam gati parāyaṇam natthi sīla alaṅkāra sadisaḥ alaṅkāraḥ natthi sīla puppha sadisam  puppham natthi sīla gandha sadisaḥ gandhaḥ natthi sīla alaṅkārena hi alaṅkatam sīla gandha anulittam
translated: There is no ornament equal to virtue. There is no flower equal to virtue.🔽There is no fragrance equal to virtue. For the world with its gods, though looking, does not weary of one adorned with the ornament of virtue, perfumed with the fragrance of virtue.

original: sadevakopi loko olokento tittiṃ na gacchatīti evamādisīlaguṇappaṭisaṃyuttaṃ kathaṃ.
analyzed: sa devakaḥ api lokaḥ olokento tittim na gacchati iti evamādi sīla guṇa paṭisaṃyuttam katham
translated: Thus he spoke talk connected with virtue.

original: “Idaṃ pana sīlaṃ nissāya ayaṃ saggo labbhatī”ti dassetuṃ sīlānantaraṃ saggakathaṃ
analyzed: idam pana sīlam nissāya ayam saggo labbhati iti dassetum sīla anantaram sagga kathaṃ
translated: In order to show that this heaven is obtained by depending on this virtue, he spoke talk on heaven next to the talk on virtue.

original: kathesi. Saggakathanti “ayaṃ saggo nāma iṭṭho kanto manāpo, niccamettha kīḷā, niccaṃ
analyzed: kathesi sagga kathanti ayam saggaḥ nāma iṭṭhaḥ kantaḥ manāpaḥ niccam ettha kīḷā niccam
translated: Talk on heaven is talk such as this: “This heaven is desirable, lovely, agreeable. One can play there for ever.

original: sampattiyo labbhanti, cātumahārājikā devā navutivassasatasahassāni dibbasukhaṃ dibbasampattiṃ
analyzed: sampattiyaḥ labbhanti cātumahārājikāḥ devāḥ navuti vassa sata sahassāni dibba sukham dibba sampattim
translated: There one gets perpetual happiness and perpetual success. The gods of the Four Great Kings enjoy divine happiness and divine success for nine hundred thousand years,

original: anubhavanti, tāvatiṃsā tisso ca vassakoṭiyo saṭṭhi ca vassasatasahassānī”ti evamādisaggaguṇappaṭisaṃyuttaṃ
analyzed: anubhavanti tāvatiṃsā tisso ca vassa koṭiyo saṭṭhi ca vassa sata sahassāni iti evamādi sagga guṇa paṭisaṃyuttam
translated: and they enjoy themselves for so many hundreds of thousands of years, for a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand years, for a million times a hundred thousand years.”

original: kathaṃ. Saggasampattiṃ kathayantānañhi buddhānaṃ mukhaṃ nappahoti. Vuttampi cetaṃ
analyzed: katham sagga sampattim kathayantānam hi buddhānam mukham na ppahoti vuttam pi ca itam
translated: When they tell of the excellences of the heavenly world, the Buddhas’ faces do not become distorted. And this is said:

original: – “anekapariyāyena khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, saggakathaṃ katheyya”ntiādi.
analyzed: aneka pariyāyena khvā aham bhikkhave sagga katham katheyya tiādi
translated: “Bhikkhus, I could tell you in many ways about heaven in order to make heaven known” .

original: Evaṃ saggakathāya palobhetvā pana hatthiṃ alaṅkaritvā tassa soṇḍaṃ chindanto viya🔽“ayampi saggo anicco addhuvo, na ettha chandarāgo kattabbo”ti dassanatthaṃ “appassādā🔽kāmā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo”tiādinā nayena kāmānaṃ ādīnavaṃ🔽okāraṃ saṃkilesaṃ kathesi. Tattha ādīnavoti doso. Okāroti avakāro lāmakabhāvo. Saṃkilesoti
analyzed: evam sagga kathāya palobhetvā pana hatthim alaṅkaritvā tassa soṇḍam chindantaḥ viya  ayam pi saggaḥ aniccaḥ addhuvaḥ na ettha chanda rāgo kattabbaḥ iti dassana ttham appassādā  kāmāḥ bahu dukkhāḥ bahu pāyāsāḥ ādīnavaḥ ettha bhiyyo ti ādinā nayena kāmānam ādīnavam  okāram saṃkilesam kathesi tattha ādīnavaḥ ati doso okāro ati avakāro lāmaka bhāvo saṃkileso ti
translated: But after tempting him with talk of heaven in this way, he then cut the tusk off the elephant by way of ornamenting it,🔽saying, “This heaven is impermanent, unstable, and a ground for terror. Delight and lust should not be aroused here,” and he showed the danger in sensual desires by the method beginning with “Sensual pleasures give little enjoyment” ,

original: tehi sattānaṃ saṃsāre saṃkilissanaṃ. Yathāha – “saṃkilissanti vata, bho, sattā”ti.
analyzed: tehi sattānam saṃsāre saṃkilissanam yathā āha saṃkilissanti vata bho sattā ati
translated: and he told of the disadvantage, the corruption, and the defilement in sensual desires. Herein, danger is blame. Corruption is an opportunity, a state of being raw. He should know what is in conformity with the Dhamma and what is not: he should be skilled in what is in conformity with the Dhamma and what is not. He should not be suspicious: he should be free from doubt, free from uncertainty. When asked: when asked for the purpose of questioning.

original: 19. Navame pahārādoti evaṃnāmako. Asurindoti asurajeṭṭhako. Asuresu hi vepacitti
analyzed: navame evaṃnāmakaḥ asurindoti asura jeṭṭhakaḥ asuresu hi
translated: 19. The asura king named Navel-Piercer: the chief of the asuras. For among the asuras there are three chiefs: Vepacitti,

original: rāhu pahārādoti ime tayo jeṭṭhakā. Yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamīti dasabalassa abhisambuddhadivasato
analyzed: ime tayaḥ jeṭṭhakāḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami iti dasabalassa abhisambuddha divasataḥ
translated: Rahu, and Navel-Piercer. He approached the Blessed One: for eleven years after the Blessed One’s enlightenment,

original: paṭṭhāya “ajja gamissāmi sve gamissāmī”ti ekādasa vassāni atikkamitvā dvādasame vasse
analyzed: paṭṭhāya ajja gamissāmi sve gamissāmi iti ekādasa vassāni atikkamitvā dvādasame vasse
translated: beginning with the day of his enlightenment, he had thought, “I will go today, I will go tomorrow,” and then, in his twelfth year,

original: satthu verañjāyaṃ vasanakāle “sammāsambuddhassa santikaṃ gamissāmī”ti cittaṃ uppādetvā
analyzed: satthu verañjāyam vasana kāle sammāsambuddhassa santikam gamissāmi iti cittam uppādetvā
translated: at the time when the Master was living at Verañjā, he had formed the thought, “I will go to the Fully Enlightened One.”

original: “mama ‘ajja sve’ti dvādasa vassāni jātāni, handāhaṃ idāneva gacchāmī”ti taṅkhaṇaṃyeva
analyzed: mama ajja sva iti dvādasa vassāni jātāni handa aham idānā iva gacchāmi iti
translated: Then he thought, “I have been thinking, ‘Today, tomorrow,’ for twelve years. Now I will go this very day.”

original: asuragaṇaparivuto asurabhavanā nikkhamitvā divā divassa yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami,
analyzed: asura gaṇa parivutaḥ asura bhavanā nikkhamitvā divā divassa yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami
translated: So immediately he left the asura world surrounded by a company of asuras, and he approached the Blessed One by day.

original: ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsīti so kira “tathāgataṃ pañhaṃ pucchitvā eva dhammaṃ suṇissāmī”ti
analyzed: eka mantam aṭṭhāsi iti saḥ kira tathāgatam pañham pucchitvā eva dhammam suṇissāmi iti
translated: He stood at one side: it seems he had come thinking, “I will question the Tathāgata and listen to the Dhamma.”

original: āgato, tathāgatassa pana diṭṭhakālato paṭṭhāya buddhagāravena pucchituṃ asakkonto
analyzed: āgataḥ tathāgatassa pana diṭṭha kālataḥ paṭṭhāya buddha gāravena pucchitum a sakkontaḥ
translated: But when he saw the Tathāgata, he was unable to question him because of his respect for the Buddha.

original: api satthāraṃ vanditvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Tato satthā cintesi – “ayaṃ pahārādo mayi🔽akathente paṭhamataraṃ kathetuṃ na sakkhissati, ciṇṇavasiṭṭhāneyeva naṃ kathāsamuṭṭhāpanatthaṃ
analyzed: api satthāram vanditvā ekamantam aṭṭhāsi tato satthā cintesi ayam pahāra ādaḥ mayi  a kathente paṭhamataram kathetum na sakkhissati nam kathā samuṭṭhāpana tham
translated: and stood at one side. Then the Teacher thought, “This Pahārāda will not be able to speak before me unless I speak first. I will ask him a question in order to set the conversation going.”

original: ekaṃ pañhaṃ pucchissāmī”ti.
analyzed: ekam pañham pucchissāmi iti
translated: So he asked him, “Pahārāda, do the Yāma gods delight in the pleasures of the five senses?”

original: Atha naṃ pucchanto api pana pahārādātiādimāha. Tattha abhiramantīti ratiṃ vindanti,
analyzed: atha nam pucchantaḥ api pana pahārāt āti ādim āha tattha abhiramanti iti ratim vindanti
translated: Herein, delighting means finding delight.

original: anukkaṇṭhamānā vasantīti attho. So “pariciṇṇaṭṭhāneyeva maṃ bhagavā pucchatī”ti attamano
analyzed: an ukkaṇṭhamānāḥ vasanti iti so mama bhagavā pucchati iti atta mano
translated: The meaning is, they live without discontent. He thought, “The Blessed One asks me a question in a place where I am familiar with the matter,” and being pleased,🔽he said, “They delight, venerable sir.”

original: hutvā abhiramanti, bhanteti āha. Anupubbaninnotiādīni sabbāni anupaṭipāṭiyā ninnabhāvassa
analyzed: hutvā abhiramanti bhante ti āha anupubba ninnaḥ ti ādīni sabbāni anupaṭipāṭiyā ninna bhāvassa
translated: The words “in due course” , etc., are all synonyms for “in a downward course.”

original: vevacanāni. Na āyatakeneva papātoti na chinnataṭamahāsobbho viya āditova papāto.
analyzed: vevacanāni na āyatakena iva papāta iti na chinna taṭa mahā sobbhaḥ viyaḥ āditas uva papātaḥ
translated: Not a precipice from the very beginning means not a great abyss with a sheer drop.

original: So hi tīrato paṭṭhāya ekaṅguladvaṅgulavidatthiratanayaṭṭhiusabhaaḍḍhagāvutagāvutaaḍḍhayojanādivasena
analyzed: saḥ hi tīrataḥ paṭṭhāya ekaṅgula dvaṅgula vidatthiratanayaṭṭhi usabha aḍḍha gāvuta gāvuta aḍḍha yojana ādi vasena
translated: For that is a precipice from the other side, in the sense of one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred cubits, etc.,

original: gambhīro hutvā gacchanto sinerupādamūle caturāsītiyojanasahassagambhīro hutvā ṭhitoti dasseti.
analyzed: gambhīraḥ hutvā gacchantaḥ sineru pāda mūle caturāsīti yojana sahassa gambhīraḥ hutvā ṭhitaḥ iti dasseti
translated: and as it goes on, it shows that it becomes deeper and deeper, and that it is 84,000 leagues deep at the foot of Sineru.

original: Ṭhitadhammoti ṭhitasabhāvo. Kuṇapenāti yena kenaci hatthiassādīnaṃ kaḷevarena. Thalaṃ ussāretīti hatthena gahetvā viya vīcipahāreneva thalaṃ khipati.
analyzed: ṭhita dhammaḥ ti ṭhita sabhāvaḥ kuṇapena ati yena kenacid hatthi assa ādīnam kaḷevarena thalam ussāreti iti hatthena gahetvā viya vīci pahārena iva thalam khipati
translated: ‘Standing firm’: of standing nature. ‘With a corpse’: with any corpse, such as an elephant’s, a horse’s, etc. ‘It throws up on to the bank’: it throws it up on to the bank with the force of the waves as though it were holding it with its hands.

original: Gaṅgāyamunāti idha ṭhatvā imāsaṃ nadīnaṃ uppattikathaṃ kathetuṃ vaṭṭati. Ayaṃ tāva🔽jambudīpo dasasahassayojanaparimāṇo, tattha catusahassayojanaparimāṇo padeso udakena
analyzed: gaṅgā yamunā ti idha imāsam nadīnam uppatti katham kathetum vaṭṭati ayam tāva  jambudīpaḥ dasa sahassa yojana parimāṇaḥ tattha catu sahassa yojana parimāṇaḥ padesaḥ udakena
translated: ‘The Ganges and the Yamunā’: it is proper to tell the story of the origin of these rivers here. This is the story.

original: ajjhotthaṭo mahāsamuddoti saṅkhaṃ gato, tisahassayojanappamāṇe manussā vasanti, tisahassayojanappamāṇe
analyzed: ajjhotthaṭaḥ mahā samuddaḥ ti saṅkham gataḥ ti sahassa yojana ppamāṇe manussāḥ vasanti ti sahassa yojana ppamāṇe
translated: This Jambudīpa is ten thousand leagues in extent. Of that, the region four thousand leagues in extent is submerged by the water and is known as the ‘great ocean.’ People live in the region three thousand leagues in extent.

original: himavā patiṭṭhito ubbedhena pañcayojanasatiko caturāsītikūṭasahassapaṭimaṇḍito samantato🔽sandamānapañcasatanadīvicitto, yattha āyāmavitthārena ca gambhīrato ca paṇṇāsapaṇṇāsayojanā
analyzed: himavā patiṭṭhitaḥ ubbedhena pañca yojana satiko catur āsīti kūṭa sahassa paṭimaṇḍito samantataḥ 🔽sandamāna pañca sata nadī vicittaḥ yattha āyāma vitthārena ca gambhīrato ca paṇṇāsa paṇṇāsa yojanā
translated: The Himalayas are situated in the region three thousand leagues in extent. They are five hundred leagues high and are adorned with eighty-four thousand peaks.🔽They extend all around for five hundred leagues. There are five hundred rivers that flow from there. The breadth and length of the lake are fifty leagues each.

original: diyaḍḍhayojanasataparimaṇḍalā anotattadaho kaṇṇamuṇḍadaho rathakāradaho chaddantadaho
analyzed: diyaḍḍha yojana sata parimaṇḍalāḥ anotatta daho kaṇṇamuṇḍa daho rathakāra daho chaddanta daho
translated: The lake Anotatta, which is two and a half yojanas in breadth, the lake Kaṇṇamuṇḍa, the lake Rathakāra, the lake Chaddanta,

original: kuṇāladaho mandākinidaho sīhappapātadahoti satta mahāsarā patiṭṭhahanti.🔽Tesu anotatto sudassanakūṭaṃ cittakūṭaṃ kāḷakūṭaṃ gandhamādanakūṭaṃ kelāsakūṭanti
analyzed: kuṇāla dahaḥ mandākini dahaḥ sīhappapāta dahaḥ ti satta mahā sarā patiṭṭhahanti  tesu sudassana kūṭam cittakūṭam kāḷa kūṭam gandhamādana kūṭam kelāsa kūṭanti
translated: the lake Kuṇāla, the lake Mandākinī, and the lake Sīhappapāta, these seven great lakes are situated.🔽Of these, the Anotatta is surrounded by the five mountains called Sudassana, Citta, Kāḷaka, Gandhamādana, and Kelāsa.

original: imehi pañcahi pabbatehi parikkhitto. Tattha sudassanakūṭaṃ sovaṇṇamayaṃ dviyojanasatubbedhaṃ
analyzed: imehi pañcahi pabbatehi parikkhittaḥ tattha sudassanakūṭam sovaṇṇa mayam dvi yojana satu bedham
translated: The Sudassana mountain is golden, two hundred yojanas in height,

original: antovaṅkaṃ kākamukhasaṇṭhānaṃ tameva saraṃ paṭicchādetvā tiṭṭhati, cittakūṭaṃ sabbaratanamayaṃ,
analyzed: antovaṅkam kākamukha saṇṭhānam tam eva saram paṭicchādetvā tiṭṭhati cittakūṭam sabba ratana mayam
translated: and it stands covering the lake itself, like the mouth of a crow. The Citta mountain is made of all the gems,

original: kāḷakūṭaṃ añjanamayaṃ, gandhamādanakūṭaṃ sānumayaṃ abbhantare muggavaṇṇaṃ, mūlagandho
analyzed: kāḷakūṭam añjana mayam gandhamādanakūṭam sānu mayam abbhantare mugga vaṇṇam mūla gandhaḥ
translated: the Kāḷaka mountain is made of collyrium, the Gandhamādana mountain is made of sandal-wood, and inside it is the colour of a kidney-bean,

original: sāragandho pheggugandho tacagandho papaṭikāgandho rasagandho pattagandho pupphagandho
analyzed: sāra gandho pheggu gandho taca gandho papaṭikā gandhaḥ rasa gandho patta gandho puppha gandho
translated: the root-fragrance, the heart-fragrance, the pith-fragrance, the bark-fragrance, the leaf-fragrance, the flower-fragrance,

original: phalagandho gandhagandhoti imehi dasahi gandhehi ussannaṃ, nānappakāraosadhasañchannaṃ
analyzed: phala gandhaḥ gandha gandhaḥ ti imehi dasahi gandhehi ussannam nānappakāra osadha sañchannam
translated: the fruit-fragrance, and the fragrance of fragrance, these ten fragrances are abundant, and it is covered with various kinds of medicinal herbs,

original: kāḷapakkhauposathadivase ādittamiva aṅgāraṃ jalantaṃ tiṭṭhati, kelāsakūṭaṃ rajatamayaṃ.
analyzed: kāḷa pakkha auposatha divase ādittam iva aṅgāram jalantam tiṭṭhati kelāsa kūṭam rajata mayam
translated: On the Uposatha day of the dark fortnight it is like a burning charcoal pit. The peak of Kelasa is made of silver.

original: Sabbāni sudassanena samānubbedhasaṇṭhānāni tameva saraṃ paṭicchādetvā ṭhitāni. Tāni
analyzed: sabbāni sudassanena samāna ubbedha saṇṭhānāni tam eva saram paṭicchādetvā ṭhitāni tāni
translated: All these are of the same height and shape as Sumanakūṭa. They stand covering that lake.

original: sabbāni devānubhāvena nāgānubhāvena ca vassanti, nadiyo cetesu sandanti. Taṃ sabbampi
analyzed: sabbāni deva anubhāvena nāga anubhāvena ca vassanti nadiyaḥ cetesu sandanti tam sabbam pi
translated: All these rain by the power of the gods and the power of the nāgas. Rivers flow in them. All that

original: udakaṃ anotattameva pavisati. Candimasūriyā dakkhiṇena vā uttarena vā gacchantā pabbatantarena
analyzed: udakam anotattam eva pavisati candima sūriyā dakkhiṇena vā uttarena vā gacchantā pabbata antarena
translated: water enters only the Anotatta. The moon and sun, going south or north,

original: tattha obhāsaṃ karonti, ujuṃ gacchantā na karonti. Tenevassa anotatto tisaṅkhā udapādi.
analyzed: tattha obhāsam karonti ujum gacchantā na karonti tena iva assa anotattaḥ ti saṅkhā udapādi
translated: shine there in the mountain gap, but not when going straight. Thus the name Anotatta arose.

original: Tattha manoharasilātalāni nimmacchakacchapāni phalikasadisanimmalodakāni nhānatitthāni
analyzed: tattha manohara silā talāni nimmaccha kacchapāni phalika sadisa nimmala udakāni nhāna titthāni
translated: There are bathing places with delightful rock terraces, free of mud and moss, with water like crystal,

original: supaṭiyattāni honti, yesu buddhā khīṇāsavā ca paccekabuddhā ca iddhimantā ca isayo
analyzed: su paṭiyattāni honti yesu buddhā khīṇāsavā ca paccekabuddhā ca iddhimantā ca isayo
translated: well prepared, where Buddhas, those with cankers destroyed, and paccekabuddhas, and seers with supernormal powers,

original: nhāyanti, devayakkhādayo udakakīḷaṃ kīḷanti.
analyzed: nhāyanti deva yakkha ādayaḥ udaka kīḷam kīḷanti
translated: bathe, and gods, yakkhas, and so on, play water sports.

original: Tassa catūsu passesu sīhamukhaṃ, hatthimukhaṃ, assamukhaṃ, usabhamukhanti cattāri🔽mukhāni honti, yehi catasso nadiyo sandanti. Sīhamukhena nikkhantanadītīre sīhā bahutarā
analyzed: tassa catūsu passesu sīha mukham hatthi mukham assa mukham usabha mukhanti cattāri  mukhāni honti yehi catasso nadiyaḥ sandanti sīha mukhena nikkhanta nadī tīre sīhāḥ bahutarā
translated: At its four corners it has lion-mouthed, elephant-mouthed, horse-mouthed, and bull-mouthed openings,🔽from which the four rivers flow out. On the bank of the river flowing out from the lion-mouthed opening there are many lions,

original: honti, hatthimukhādīhi hatthiassausabhā. Puratthimadisato nikkhantanadī anotattaṃ
analyzed: honti hatthi mukha ādīhi hatthi assa usabhā puratthima disataḥ nikkhanta nadī anotattam
translated: and on the banks of the other three rivers there are many elephants, horses, and bulls respectively. The river flowing out from the eastern direction, the Anotatta,

original: tikkhattuṃ padakkhiṇaṃ katvā itarā tisso nadiyo anupagamma pācīnahimavanteneva amanussapathaṃ
analyzed: tikkhattum padakkhiṇam katvā itarāḥ tissaḥ nadiyaḥ an upagamma pācīna himavantena iva amanussa patham
translated: goes round the city three times clockwise and then, without entering the other three rivers, goes by the northern side of the Himalayas to the human world

original: gantvā mahāsamuddaṃ pavisati. Pacchimadisato ca uttaradisato ca nikkhantanadiyopi
analyzed: gantvā mahā samuddam pavisati pacchima disatas ca uttara disatas ca nikkhanta nadiyo pi
translated: and enters the ocean. The rivers flowing out from the western and northern directions

original: tatheva padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pacchimahimavanteneva uttarahimavanteneva ca amanussapathaṃ🔽gantvā mahāsamuddaṃ pavisanti. Dakkhiṇamukhato nikkhantanadī pana taṃ tikkhattuṃ
analyzed: tathā iva padakkhiṇam katvā pacchima himavantena iva uttara himavantena iva ca amanussa patham  gantvā mahā samuddam pavisanti dakkhiṇa mukhataḥ nikkhanta nadī pana tam tikkhattum
translated: also go round the city three times clockwise and then, by the western and northern sides of the Himalayas respectively, go to the human world🔽and enter the ocean. But the river flowing out from the southern direction, after going round the city three times,

original: padakkhiṇaṃ katvā uttarena ujukaṃ pāsāṇapiṭṭheneva saṭṭhi yojanāni gantvā pabbataṃ
analyzed: padakkhiṇam katvā uttarena ujukam pāsāṇa piṭṭhena iva saṭṭhi yojanāni gantvā pabbatam
translated: goes straight north for sixty leagues by a rocky surface and then enters the ocean by the southern side of Laṅkā.

original: paharitvā uṭṭhāya parikkhepena tigāvutappamāṇā udakadhārā hutvā ākāsena saṭṭhi yojanāni🔽gantvā tiyaggaḷe nāma pāsāṇe patitā, pāsāṇo udakadhārāvegena bhinno. Tattha paññāsayojanappamāṇā
analyzed: paharitvā uṭṭhāya parikkhepena udaka dhārāḥ hutvā ākāsena saṭṭhi yojanāni  gantvā tiyaggaḷe nāma pāsāṇe patitā pāsāṇaḥ udaka dhārā vegena bhinnaḥ tattha paññāsa yojana ppamāṇā
translated: and having struck it, it rose up and went through the sky for sixty leagues as a water-fall a league wide,🔽and fell on a rock called Tiyaggala, and the rock was split by the force of the water-fall. There a great lotus-pond called Tiyaggala was formed, fifty leagues wide,

original: tiyaggaḷā nāma mahāpokkharaṇī jātā, pokkharaṇiyā kūlaṃ bhinditvā pāsāṇaṃ pavisitvā
analyzed: tiyaggaḷā nāma mahā pokkharaṇī jātā pokkharaṇiyā kūlam bhinditvā pāsāṇam pavisitvā
translated: and having split the bank of the lotus-pond and entered the rock,

original: saṭṭhi yojanāni gatā. Tato ghanapathaviṃ bhinditvā ummaṅgena saṭṭhi yojanāni gantvā
analyzed: saṭṭhi yojanāni gatā tatas ghana pathavim bhinditvā ummaṅgena saṭṭhi yojanāni gantvā
translated: it went sixty leagues and having split the solid earth, it went sixty leagues by the Ummaṅga channel,

original: giñjhaṃ nāma tiracchānapabbataṃ paharitvā hatthatale pañcaṅgulisadisā pañca dhārā🔽hutvā pavattati. Sā tikkhattuṃ anotattaṃ padakkhiṇaṃ katvā gataṭṭhāne āvattagaṅgāti🔽vuccati. Ujukaṃ pāsāṇapiṭṭhena saṭṭhi yojanāni gataṭṭhāne kaṇhagaṅgā, ākāsena saṭṭhi
analyzed: giñjham nāma tiracchāna pabbatam paharitvā hattha tale pañca aṅguli sadisā pañca dhārā  hutvā pavattati sā tikkhattum anotattam padakkhiṇam katvā gata ṭṭhāne āvattagaṅgā ati  vuccati ujukam pāsāṇa piṭṭhena saṭṭhi yojanāni gata ṭṭhāne kaṇhagaṅgā ākāsena saṭṭhi
translated: and having struck a mountain called Giñjā, it flowed out in five streams like the five fingers of a hand.

original: yojanāni gataṭṭhāne ākāsagaṅgā, tiyaggaḷapāsāṇe paññāsayojanokāse ṭhitā tiyaggaḷapokkharaṇī,
analyzed: yojanāni gata ṭṭhāne ākāsagaṅgā tiyaggaḷa pāsāṇe paññāsa yojana ukāse ṭhitā tiyaggaḷa pokkharaṇī
translated: It is said that after going round the Anotatta (Lake) three times, it returns to the place from which it came, and is called the Āvatagaṅgā (Returning Ganges). In the place where it goes straight on the back of the rock for sixty leagues it is called the Kaṇhagaṅgā (Thin Ganges), in the place where it goes through the sky for sixty leagues it is called the ākāsagaṅgā (Sky Ganges), in the place where it stands on the rock of Tiyaggala for fifty leagues it is called the Tiyaggalapokkharaṇī (Tiyaggala Lotus-pond),🔽and in the place where it flows out in five streams it is called the Giñjāpokkharaṇī (Giñjā Lotus-pond).

original: kūlaṃ bhinditvā pāsāṇaṃ pavisitvā saṭṭhi yojanāni gataṭṭhāne bahalagaṅgāti, umaṅgena
analyzed: kūlam bhinditvā pāsāṇam pavisitvā saṭṭhi yojanāni gata ṭṭhāne bahalagaṅgā ati umaṅgena
translated: The river that goes sixty leagues after breaking through the mountain spur is called the “Deep Ganges.”🔽The river that goes sixty leagues after being checked by Umin is called the “Umin Ganges.”

original: saṭṭhi yojanāni gataṭṭhāne umaṅgagaṅgāti vuccati. Viñjhaṃ nāma tiracchānapabbataṃ
analyzed: saṭṭhi yojanāni gata ṭṭhāne umaṅgagaṅgā ti vuccati viñjham nāma tiracchāna pabbatam
translated: The mountain spur called Viñjhā is a mountain range running across the island.

original: paharitvā pañca dhārā hutvā pavattanaṭṭhāne pana gaṅgā, yamunā, aciravatī, sarabhū,
analyzed: paharitvā pañca dhārāḥ hutvā pavattana ṭṭhāne pana gaṅgā yamunā aciravatī sarabhū
translated: The river that flows out in five streams after breaking through it is called the “Ganges.” The river that flows out in five streams after being checked by the mountain spur is called the “Yamunā.” The river that flows out in five streams after being checked by the mountain spur is called the “Aciravatī.” The river that flows out in five streams after being checked by the mountain spur is called the “Sarabhū.”

original: mahīti pañca saṅkhaṃ gatā. Evametā pañca mahānadiyo himavantato pavattantīti veditabbā.🔽Savantiyoti yā kāci savamānā gacchantī mahānadiyo vā kunnadiyo vā. Appentīti allīyanti
analyzed: mahī iti pañca saṅkham gatāḥ evam etā pañca mahā nadiyaḥ himavantataḥ pavattanti iti veditabbā  yā kāci savamānā gacchantī mahā nadiyaḥ vā kunnadiyaḥ vā appenti iti allīyanti
translated: The river that flows out in five streams after being checked by the mountain spur is called the “Mahī.” Thus these five great rivers should be understood to flow from the Himalayas.

original: osaranti. Dhārāti vuṭṭhidhārā. Pūrattanti puṇṇabhāvo. Mahāsamuddassa hi ayaṃ dhammatā🔽– “imasmiṃ kāle devo mando jāto, jālakkhipādīni ādāya macchakacchape gaṇhissāmā”ti
analyzed: osaranti dhārā ati vuṭṭhi dhārā pūrattanti puṇṇa bhāvaḥ mahā samuddassa hi ayam dhamma tā  imasmin kāle devaḥ mandaḥ jātaḥ jālakkhipa ādīni ādāya maccha kacchape gaṇhissāma ati
translated: “Flow in” : whatever rivers flow and go, whether great rivers or small streams. “Fill up” : they stick, they descend. “Stream” : a flowing stream. “Fullness” : a state of being full. For this is the nature of the great ocean🔽that at a certain time the rain-god rains down little, and then one can go out to catch fish and turtles with a net or basket, or one can make a causeway and go out.

original: vā “imasmiṃ kāle mahantā vuṭṭhi, labhissāma nu kho piṭṭhipasāraṇaṭṭhāna”nti vā vattuṃ
analyzed: vā imasmin kāle mahantāḥ vuṭṭhi labhissāma nu kho piṭṭhi pasāraṇa ṭhānanti vā vattum
translated: Or at a certain time the rain-god rains down much, and then one cannot go out to catch fish and turtles with a net or basket, or make a causeway and go out.

original: na sakkā. Paṭhamakappikakālato paṭṭhāya hi yaṃ sinerumekhalaṃ āhacca udakaṃ ṭhitaṃ,
analyzed: na sakkā paṭhama kappika kālataḥ paṭṭhāya hi yam sinerumekhalam āhatca udakam ṭhitam
translated: It cannot. For from the time of the first aeon onwards the water that stands held in by the Sineru range of mountains🔽does not subside even as much as an inch either below or above, though it is stirred up by the winds of the aeon.

original: tato ekaṅgulamattampi udakaṃ neva heṭṭhā osīdati, na uddhaṃ uttarati. Ekarasoti asambhinnaraso.🔽Muttāti khuddakamahantavaṭṭadīghādibhedā anekavidhā. Maṇīti rattanīlādibhedo anekavidho.
analyzed: tatas eka aṅgula mattam pi udakam na iva heṭṭhā osīdati na uddham uttarati ekarasaḥ iti asambhinna rasaḥ  muttā ati khuddaka mahanta vaṭṭa dīgha ādi bhedāḥ anekavidhāḥ maṇiḥ iti ratta nīla ādi bhedaḥ anekavidhaḥ
translated: Of one taste: of undiversified taste.🔽Of many colours: of many kinds, such as small, large, round, long, etc.🔽Of many forms: of many kinds, such as sapphire, etc.🔽Of many shapes: of many kinds, such as the colour of bamboo shoots, the colour of jasmine flowers, etc.

original: Veḷuriyoti vaṃsavaṇṇasirīsapupphavaṇṇādibhedo anekavidho. Saṅkhoti dakkhiṇāvaṭṭatambakucchikadhamanasaṅkhādibhedo
analyzed: veḷuriyaḥ ti vaṃsa vaṇṇa sirīsa puppha vaṇṇa ādi bhedaḥ anekavidhaḥ saṅkhaḥ ti dakkhiṇā vaṭṭa tamba kucchika dhamana saṅkha ādi bhedaḥ
translated: Of many kinds: of many kinds, such as right-handed, left-handed, with a navel to the right, with a navel to the left, with lines, without lines, etc.🔽Of many hues: of many kinds, such as white, black, spotted, etc.

original: anekavidho. Silāti setakāḷamuggavaṇṇādibhedo anekavidhā. Pavāḷanti khuddakamahantarattaghanarattādibhedaṃ
analyzed: anekavidhaḥ silāti seta kāḷa mugga vaṇṇa ādi bhedaḥ anekavidhā khuddaka mahanta ratta ghana ratta ādi bhedam
translated: Of many kinds: of many kinds, such as small, large, dark red, bright red, etc.🔽Of many kinds: of many kinds, such as the gem called “the king’s treasure,” the gem called “the minister’s treasure,” the gem called “the general’s treasure,” etc.

original: anekavidhaṃ. Masāragallanti kabaramaṇi. Nāgāti ūmipiṭṭhavāsinopi vimānaṭṭhakā nāgāpi.
analyzed: anekavidham masāragallanti kabaramaṇi ūmipiṭṭhavāsinaḥ api vimānaṭṭhakāḥ nāgā api
translated: Of many kinds: of many kinds, such as the nāgas that live in the ocean, the nāgas that live on the continent, and the nāgas that live in palaces.

original: Aṭṭha pahārādāti satthā aṭṭhapi dhamme vattuṃ sakkoti, soḷasapi bāttiṃsapi catusaṭṭhipi
analyzed: aṭṭha satthā aṭṭha api dhamme vattum sakkoti soḷasa pi catusaṭṭhi pi
translated: Eight times: the Teacher can speak of eight things, sixteen things, thirty-two things, sixty-four things,

original: sahassampi, pahārādena pana aṭṭha kathitā, ahampi teheva sarikkhake katvā kathessāmīti
analyzed: sahassam pi pahārādena pana aṭṭha kathitāḥ aham pi tehi iva sa rikkhake katvā kathessāmi iti
translated: But the thousand are included in the eight, and I shall explain them by including them in the eight.

original: cintetvā evamāha. Anupubbasikkhātiādīsu anupubbasikkhāya tisso sikkhā gahitā, anupubbakiriyāya🔽terasa dhutaṅgāni, anupubbapaṭipadāya satta anupassanā aṭṭhārasa mahāvipassanā aṭṭhatiṃsa
analyzed: cintetvā evam āha anupubba sikkhā ti ādīsu anupubba sikkhāya tisso sikkhāḥ gahitāḥ anupubba kiriyāya  terasa dhutaṅgāni anupubba paṭipadāya satta anupassanāḥ aṭṭhārasa mahāvipassanāḥ aṭṭhatiṃsa
translated: Thinking thus, he said as follows. In the three kinds of training are included the three kinds of training beginning with that in the higher virtue.🔽In the thirteen forms of austerity are included the thirteen forms of austerity beginning with the triple-robes austerity.🔽In the seven contemplations and the eighteen principal kinds of insight and the thirty-eight kinds of object-classification are included the thirty-seven aids to enlightenment.

original: ārammaṇavibhattiyo sattatiṃsa bodhapakkhiyadhammā. Na āyatakeneva aññāpaṭivedhoti🔽maṇḍūkassa uppatitvā gamanaṃ viya āditova sīlapūraṇādiṃ akatvā arahattappaṭivedho
analyzed: ārammaṇa vibhattiyaḥ sattatiṃsa bodha pakkhiya dhammā na āyatakena iva aññā paṭivedho ti  maṇḍūkassa uppatitvā gamanam viya āditas va sīla pūraṇa ādim a katvā arahatta paṭivedhaḥ
translated: Not by the far-extending is there penetration of the state of further-men.🔽There is no penetration of the state of arahatship by the far-extending, as there is by the leaping, which is like a frog’s leaping.

original: nāma natthi, paṭipāṭiyā pana sīlasamādhipaññāyo pūretvāva sakkā arahattaṃ pattunti attho.
analyzed: nāma natthi paṭipāṭiyā pana sīla samādhi paññāyo pūretvā ava sakkā arahattam pattunti attho
translated: But the meaning is that it is possible to reach arahatship by fulfilling virtue, concentration, and understanding in due succession.

original: Ārakāvāti dūreyeva. Na tena nibbānadhātuyā ūnattaṃ vā pūrattaṃ vāti asaṅkhyeyyepi
analyzed: ārakā avāti dūreya iva na tena nibbāna dhātuyā ūnattam vā pūrattam vā ati asaṅkhyeyye pi
translated: Far away: far off. By that there is no deficiency or excess in the element of extinction.

original: kappe buddhesu anuppannesu ekasattopi parinibbātuṃ na sakkoti, tadāpi “tucchā nibbānadhātū”ti🔽na sakkā vattuṃ. Buddhakāle ca pana ekekasmiṃ samāgame asaṅkhyeyyāpi sattā amataṃ
analyzed: kappe buddhesu anuppannesu eka sattaḥ api parinibbātum na sakkoti tadā api tucchā nibbāna dhātu uti  na sakkā vattum buddha kāle ca pana eka ekasmin samāgame asaṅkhyeyyā api sattāḥ amatam
translated: When there are no Buddhas in the world, not a single being can attain Nibbāna. But even then it is not right to say that the Nibbāna element is empty.🔽And in the Buddhas’ time, in each of the assemblies countless beings have attained immortality,

original: ārādhenti, tadāpi na sakkā vattuṃ – “pūrā nibbānadhātū”ti.🔽10. Uposathasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ārādhenti tadā api na sakkā vattum pūrā nibbāna dhātū ti  uposatha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: When there are no Buddhas in the world, not even one being can attain Nibbāna. Then it cannot be said that the Nibbāna element is void. And when there are Buddhas in the world, countless beings attain the deathless Nibbāna in each of the assemblies. Then it cannot be said that the Nibbāna element is full.

original: 20. Dasame nisinno hotīti uposathakaraṇatthāya upāsikāya ratanapāsāde nisinno. Nisajja🔽pana bhikkhūnaṃ cittāni olokento ekaṃ dussīlapuggalaṃ disvā “sacāhaṃ imasmiṃ puggale🔽nisinneyeva pātimokkhaṃ uddisissāmi, sattadhā tassa muddhā phalissatī”ti tassa anukampāya🔽tuṇhīyeva ahosi. Abhikkantāti atikkantā parikkhīṇā. Uddhaste aruṇeti uggate aruṇasīse.🔽Nandimukhiyāti tuṭṭhamukhiyā. Aparisuddhā, ānanda, parisāti “asukapuggalo aparisuddho”ti
analyzed: dasame nisinno hoti iti uposatha karaṇa atthāya upāsikāya ratana pāsāde nisinnaḥ nisajja 🔽pana bhikkhūnam cittāni olokento ekam dussīla puggalam disvā sacā aham imasmin puggale 🔽nisinneya iva pātimokkham uddisissāmi sattadhā tassa muddhā phalissati iti tassa anukampāya 🔽tuṇhīyā iva ahosi abhikkantā ati atikkantā parikkhīṇā uddhaste aruṇā iti uggate aruṇa sīse 🔽nandi mukhiyā ti tuṭṭha mukhiyā aparisuddhā ānanda parisā ati asuka puggalo aparisuddho ti
translated: The explanation of the tenth chapter, on the Uposatha observance, is concluded.

original: avatvā “aparisuddhā, ānanda, parisā”ti āha. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: avatvā aparisuddhā ānanda parisā ti āha sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: and without sitting down he said, “The assembly is not pure, Ānanda.” The rest is clear in all sections.

original: Mahāvaggo dutiyo.🔽3. Gahapativaggo
analyzed: mahā vaggo dutiyaḥ  gahapati vaggo
translated: The Second Great Chapter is finished.🔽The Householder Chapter

original: 1. Paṭhamauggasuttavaṇṇanā🔽21. Tatiyassa paṭhame paññatte āsane nisīdīti tassa kira ghare pañcannaṃ bhikkhusatānaṃ
analyzed: paṭhama ogga sutta vaṇṇanā  tatiyassa paṭhame paññatte āsane nisīdi iti tassa kira ghare pañcannam bhikkhu satānam
translated: 1. The First Discussion🔽In the first of the third section, “in the prepared seat” means that in his house there were always prepared five hundred seats for five hundred bhikkhus,

original: pañca āsanasatāni niccaṃ paññattāneva honti, tesu aññatarasmiṃ āsane nisīdi. Taṃ🔽suṇāhīti te suṇāhi, taṃ vā aṭṭhavidhaṃ acchariyadhammaṃ suṇāhi. Cittaṃ pasīdīti “buddho
analyzed: pañca āsana satāni niccam paññattāni eva honti tesu aññatarasmin āsane  suṇāhi iti te suṇāhi tam vā aṭṭhavidham acchariya dhammam suṇāhi cittam pasīdi iti buddhaḥ
translated: and he sat down on one of them.🔽“Listen to it” means listen to that eightfold wonderful Dhamma. “The mind became clear” means that not even a thought arose as to whether the Buddha was or was not the Buddha,

original: nu kho na buddho nu kho”ti vitakkamattampi na uppajji, ayameva buddhoti cittuppādo
analyzed: nu kho na buddhaḥ nu kho ti vitakka mattam pi na uppajji ayam eva buddhaḥ iti cittuppādaḥ
translated: and the arising of the thought “He is the Buddha” became clear and unclouded.

original: pasanno anāvilo ahosi. Sakāni vā ñātikulānīti attano yāpanamattaṃ dhanaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: pasannaḥ anāvilaḥ ahosi sakāni vā ñāti kulāni iti attanaḥ yāpana mattam dhanam gahetvā
translated: “Go to your own relatives’ houses” means “Take as much wealth as is needed for your own livelihood and go to your relatives’ houses.”

original: ñātigharāni gacchatu. Kassa vo dammīti katarapurisassa tumhe dadāmi, ārocetha me
analyzed: ñāti gharāni gacchatu kassa vaḥ dammi iti katara purisassa tumhe dadāmi ārocetha me
translated: “To whom shall I give you?” means “To which man shall I give you? Tell me.”

original: attano adhippāyaṃ. Appaṭivibhattāti “ettakaṃ dassāmi ettakaṃ na dassāmi, idaṃ dassāmi
analyzed: attanaḥ adhippāyam appaṭivibhattā ati ettakam dassāmi ettakam na dassāmi idam dassāmi
translated: his own intention. Not shared: “I will give this much, not that much; I will give this, not that;

original: idaṃ na dassāmī”ti cittaṃ uppādentena hi paṭivibhattā nāma hoti, mayhaṃ pana na evaṃ.
analyzed: idam na dassāmi iti cittam uppādentena hi paṭivibhattā nāma hoti mayham pana na evam
translated: His own intention. Not shared: for when one arouses the thought, “I will give this much, not that much; I will give this, not that,” then it is called shared. But not so in my case.

original: Atha kho saṅghikā viya gaṇasantakā viya ca sīlavantehi saddhiṃ sādhāraṇāyeva. Sakkaccaṃyeva
analyzed: atha kho saṅghikāḥ viya gaṇa santakāḥ viya ca sīlavantehi saddhim sādhāraṇāya iva sakkaccaṃyā iva
translated: Rather, it is as if it were shared with the Community or with a group, in common with those who are virtuous.

original: payirupāsāmīti sahatthā upaṭṭhahāmi, cittīkārena upasaṅkamāmi.
analyzed: payirupāsāmi iti sahatthā upaṭṭhahāmi cittīkārena upasaṅkamāmi
translated: I serve with my own hands: I attend to it with my own hands. I approach with a mind of confidence.

original: Anacchariyaṃ kho pana maṃ, bhanteti, bhante, yaṃ maṃ devatā upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ ārocenti,
analyzed: kho pana mam bhantā iti bhante yam mam devatāḥ upasaṅkamitvā evam ārocenti
translated: It is not at all strange, venerable sir, that deities should approach me and make such a statement,

original: idaṃ na acchariyaṃ. Yaṃ panāhaṃ tatonidānaṃ cittassa uṇṇatiṃ nābhijānāmi, taṃ eva🔽acchariyanti vadati. Sādhu sādhu, bhikkhūti ettha kiñcāpi bhikkhuṃ āmanteti, upāsakasseva
analyzed: idam na acchariyam yam pana aham tatonidānam cittassa uṇṇatim na abhijānāmi tam eva  acchariyanti vadati sādhu sādhu bhikkhu iti ettha kiñcā api bhikkhum āmanteti upāsakassa iva
translated: but it is strange that I do not recall any mental excitement on that account.🔽Good, good, bhikkhu! Here, although he addresses the bhikkhu, the good, good should be understood as praise of the lay follower’s

original: pana veyyākaraṇasampahaṃsane esa sādhukāroti veditabbo.
analyzed: pana veyyākaraṇa sampahaṃsane esa sādhukāro ti veditabbo
translated: answer.

original: 2. Dutiyauggasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya ogga sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Second Discourse on the Noble Ones

original: 22. Dutiye nāgavaneti tassa kira seṭṭhino nāgavanaṃ nāma uyyānaṃ, so tattha purebhattaṃ
analyzed: dutiye nāgavana iti tassa kira seṭṭhinaḥ nāgavanam nāma uyyānam saḥ tattha purebhattam
translated: In the second, in the nāga grove: there was a park belonging to that merchant called the nāga grove. He went there, taking perfumes, garlands, etc.,

original: gandhamālādīni gāhāpetvā uyyānakīḷikaṃ kīḷitukāmo gantvā paricāriyamāno bhagavantaṃ🔽addasa. Saha dassanenevassa purimanayeneva cittaṃ pasīdi, surāpānena ca uppannamando
analyzed: gandha mālā ādīni gāhāpetvā uyyāna kīḷikam kīḍitu kāmaḥ gantvā paricāriyamānaḥ bhagavantam  addasa saha dassanena iva assa purima nayena iva cittam pasīdi surā pānena ca uppanna mandaḥ
translated: and while being entertained there, he saw the Exalted One,

original: taṅkhaṇaṃyeva pahīyi. Taṃ sandhāyevamāha. Oṇojesinti udakaṃ hatthe pātetvā adāsiṃ.🔽Asukoti amuko. Samacittova demīti “imassa thokaṃ, imassa bahuka”nti evaṃ cittanānattaṃ
analyzed: tam sandhāya ivam āha udakam hatthe pātetvā adāsim  asukaḥ iti amukaḥ sama cittaḥ uva demi iti imassa thokam imassa bahukam ti evam citta nānattam
translated: and his mind became clear, and the intoxication that had arisen through drinking liquor disappeared at that moment. With reference to that, he said, “I sprinkled water on my hands and gave it to him.”

original: na karomi, deyyadhammaṃ pana ekasadisaṃ karomīti dasseti. Ārocentīti ākāse ṭhatvā
analyzed: na karomi deyya dhammam pana eka sadisam karomi iti dasseti ārocenti iti ākāse ṭhatvā
translated: “To such and such a person”: to so and so. “I gave with an even mind”: I did not make distinctions in my mind, thinking, “I will give a little to this one, and a lot to that one.” I made the gift equal.

original: ārocenti. Natthi taṃ saṃyojananti iminā upāsako attano anāgāmiphalaṃ byākaroti.
analyzed: ārocenti natthi tam saṃyojanan ti iminā upāsakaḥ attanaḥ anāgāmi phalam byākaroti
translated: “They announced”: they stood in the air and announced. “There is no fetter”: by this the lay follower declares his attainment of the non-returner fruit.

original: 3. Paṭhamahatthakasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The first discourse on the hand

original: 23. Tatiye hatthako āḷavakoti bhagavatā āḷavakayakkhassa hatthato hatthehi sampaṭicchitattā
analyzed: tatiye hatthako āḷavakaḥ iti bhagavatā āḷavaka yakkhassa hatthataḥ hatthehi sampaṭicchita ttā
translated: 23. In the third, the prince called Hatthaka, who was given the name Hatthaka because he was accepted by the ogre of Āḷavaka with his hands,

original: hatthakoti laddhanāmo rājakumāro. Sīlavāti pañcasīladasasīlena sīlavā. Cāgavāti cāgasampanno.
analyzed: hatthako ti laddha nāmaḥ rāja kumāro sīlavāti pañca sīla dasa sīlena sīlavā cāgavāti cāga sampanno
translated: was virtuous, endowed with the five precepts and the ten precepts, and bountiful, endowed with generosity.

original: Kaccittha, bhanteti, bhante, kacci ettha bhagavato byākaraṇaṭṭhāne. Appicchoti adhigamappicchatāya appiccho.
analyzed: kacci ittha bhante iti bhante kacci ettha bhagavataḥ byākaraṇa ṭṭhāne appiccho ti adhigama ppicchatāya appiccho
translated: “Is it true, venerable sir?” means “Venerable sir, is it true that there is a place for the Blessed One’s reply here?” He was modest, modest in his acquisition.

original: 4. Dutiyahatthakasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya hatthaka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the second sutta of the Hatthaka group.

original: 24. Catutthe pañcamattehi upāsakasatehīti sotāpannasakadāgāmīnaṃyeva ariyasāvakaupāsakānaṃ
analyzed: catutthe upāsaka satehi iti ariyasāvaka upāsakānam
translated: In the fourth, with five hundred lay followers: surrounded by five hundred lay followers who were noble disciples, stream-enterers and once-returners,

original: pañcahi satehi parivuto bhuttapātarāso gandhamālavilepenacuṇṇāni gahetvā yena bhagavā🔽tenupasaṅkami. Saṅgahavatthūnīti saṅgaṇhanakāraṇāni. Tehāhanti tehi ahaṃ. Taṃ dānena
analyzed: pañcahi satehi parivutaḥ bhutta pāta rāsaḥ gandha māla vilepena cuṇṇāni gahetvā yena bhagavā  tena upasaṅkami saṅgaha vatthūni iti saṅgaṇhana kāraṇāni tehi ahanti tehi aham tam dānena
translated: after the meal, he took perfumes, garlands, ointments, and cosmetics and approached the Blessed One.

original: saṅgaṇhāmīti naṅgalabalibaddabhattabījādīni ceva gandhamālamūlādīni ca datvā saṅgaṇhāmi.
analyzed: saṅgaṇhāmi iti naṅgala balibadda bhatta bīja ādīni ca iva gandha māla mūla ādīni ca da tvā saṅgaṇhāmi
translated: The bases of sympathy: the reasons for sympathy. “By them”: by those. “I gather him in with gifts”: I gather him in by giving him ploughs, oxen, rice, seed, etc., and perfumes, garlands, etc.

original: Peyyavajjenāti amma, tāta, bhātara, bhaginītiādikena kaṇṇasukhena mudukena piyavacanena🔽saṅgaṇhāmi. Atthacariyāyāti “imassa dānena vā piyavacanena vā kiccaṃ natthi, atthacariyāya🔽saṅgaṇhitabbayuttako aya”nti ñatvā uppannakiccanittharaṇasaṅkhātāya atthacariyāya
analyzed: peyyavajjena ati amma tāta bhātara bhagini iti ādikena kaṇṇa sukhena mudukena piya vacanena  saṅgaṇhāmi attha cariyāya ati imassa dānena vā piya vacanena vā kiccam natthi attha cariyāya  saṅgaṇhitabba yuttakaḥ ayanti ñatvā uppanna kicca nittharaṇa saṅkhātāya attha cariyāya
translated: I win them over with pleasing speech, with such words of endearment as ‘dear sir,’ ‘dear friend,’ ‘dear brother,’ ‘dear sister,’ and so on.🔽I win them over with service, thinking, ‘There is no need for this person to give me anything or to speak an endearing word to me. translated: “As impermanent”: in the aspect of “having been, they are not.” “As they really are”: according to their true nature. “With right understanding”: with the understanding of the path together with insight. “Like a charcoal pit”: these sensual pleasures are compared to a charcoal pit in the sense of burning. “Intent on seclusion”: intent on Nibbāna by way of fruition attainment. “Standing on seclusion”: secluded from defilements, or far removed from them. “Delighting in renunciation”: delighting in going forth. “Having attained the peaceful state”: having attained the state of being free from the cankers.

original: anallīnaṃ visaṃyuttaṃ visaṃsaṭṭhaṃ. Āsavaṭṭhāniyehīti sampayogavasena āsavānaṃ kāraṇabhūtehi,🔽kilesadhammehīti attho. Atha vā byantibhūtanti vigatavāyanti attho. Kuto? Sabbaso🔽āsavaṭṭhāniyehi dhammehi, sabbehi tebhūmakadhammehīti attho. Imasmiṃ sutte ariyamaggo

translated: As impermanent: in the aspect of non-existence after having been. As it really is: according to its true nature. With right understanding: with path understanding accompanied by insight. As a pit of glowing embers: these sensual desires are compared to a pit of glowing embers in the sense of burning. Bent on seclusion: bent on extinction by way of fruition attainment. Abiding in seclusion: secluded from defilements, or far removed. Delighting in renunciation: delighting in the going forth. Tranquil: free from the element of agitation, not stuck anywhere, unassociated, disjoined. From things that cause the influxes to occur: from things that are a cause for the influxes to occur by way of association; the meaning is, from defilement things. Or else, “tranquil” means “free from agitation.” From where? From all things that cause the influxes to occur, from all things of the three planes. The noble path is taught here in this sutta as both mundane and supramundane.🔽. The exposition of the “Untimely” sutta

analyzed: na deti dvebhātika theresu jeṭṭha theraḥ viya vatthu visuddhi magge kathitam ayam  dhammaḥ ti evam santa guṇa niguhanena ca paṭiggahaṇe mattaññu tāya ca appicchassa puggalassa
translated: Herein, one who is content with requisites takes little when much is offered, and he takes even little as less; he does not take without discerning. One who is content with spiritual attainments does not give his own spiritual attainments to others to know, like the Elder Majjhantika. One who is content with learning does not want others to know that he has learned much, like the Elder Tissa of Sāketa. One who is content with ascetic practices does not give others to know that he practices ascetic practices, like the elder of the two brothers. The story is told in the Visuddhimagga.🔽This Dhamma,

original: ayaṃ navalokuttaradhammo sampajjati, no mahicchassa. Evaṃ sabbattha yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: ayam nava lokuttara dhammo sampajjati no mahicchassa evam sabbattha yojetabbam
translated: this supramundane Dhamma consisting of the nine supramundane states, is produced in a person who is content, who conceals his good qualities in this way and who knows the right amount to take in receiving, not in one who is discontented. This should be applied in all cases.

original: Santuṭṭhassāti catūsu paccayesu tīhi santosehi santuṭṭhassa. Pavivittassāti kāyacittaupadhivivekehi
analyzed: santuṭṭhassa ati catūsu paccayesu tīhi santosehi santuṭṭhassa pavivittassa ati kāya citta upadhi vivekehi
translated: “Content” : content with the four requisites by means of the three kinds of contentment. “Secluded” : secluded by means of bodily seclusion, mental seclusion, and seclusion from acquisitions.🔽Herein, bodily seclusion is the state of being alone after sending away a companion, by giving up the intimacy of a companion.🔽Mental seclusion is the state of being alone after giving up the intimacy of companions, by giving up the intimacy of bodily activities.🔽Seclusion from acquisitions is the state of being alone after giving up the intimacy of mental activities, by giving up the intimacy of the five constituents of sensual pleasure.

original: vivittassa. Tattha kāyaviveko nāma gaṇasaṅgaṇikaṃ vinodetvā ārambhavatthuvasena ekībhāvo.🔽Ekībhāvamatteneva kammaṃ na nipphajjatīti kasiṇaparikammaṃ katvā aṭṭha samāpattiyo
analyzed: vivittassa tattha kāya vivekaḥ nāma gaṇa saṅgaṇikam vinodetvā ārambha vatthu vasena ekībhāvaḥ  ekībhāva mattena iva kammam na nipphajjati iti kasiṇa parikammam katvā aṭṭha samāpattiyaḥ
translated: Translation: Santuṭṭhassa cattāri paccayā tīhi tuṭṭhīhi santuṭṭhassa | Pavivittassāti kāyacittaupadhivivekehi vivittassa | Tattha kāyaviveko nāma gaṇasaṅgaṇikaṃ vinodetvā ārambhavatthuvasena ekībhāvo |

Tenāha bhagavā – “kāyaviveko ca vivekaṭṭhakāyānaṃ nekkhammābhiratānaṃ,🔽cittaviveko ca parisuddhacittānaṃ paramavodānappattānaṃ, upadhiviveko ca nirupadhīnaṃ
analyzed: nibbattā iti ayam citta vivekaḥ nāma samāpattimattena iva kammam na nipphajjati iti jhānam  pādakam katvā saṅkhāre sammasitvā saha paṭisambhidāhi arahattam pāpuṇāti ayam sabba ākārataḥ  upadhi vivekaḥ nāma tena āha bhagavā ca viveka ṭṭha kāyānam nekkhamma abhiratānam  citta viveko ca parisuddha cittānam parama vodāna pattānam upadhi viveko ca nirupadhīnam
translated: Ekībhāvamatteneva kammaṃ na nipphajjatīti kasiṇaparikammaṃ katvā aṭṭha samāpattiyo nibbatteti, ayaṃ cittaviveko nāma | Samāpattimatteneva kammaṃ na nipphajjatīti jhānaṃ pādakaṃ katvā saṅkhāre sammasitvā saha paṭisambhidāhi arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti, ayaṃ sabbākārato upadhiviveko nāma | Tena vuccati bhagavatā – “kāyaviveko ca vivekaṭṭhakāyānaṃ nekkhammābhiratānaṃ,

translated: cittaviveko ca parisuddhacittānaṃ paramavodānappattānaṃ, upadhiviveko ca nirupadhīnaṃ puggalānaṃ visaṅkhāragatān”nti |

original: Saṅgaṇikārāmassāti gaṇasaṅgaṇikāya ceva kilesasaṅgaṇikāya ca ratassa. Āraddhavīriyassāti🔽kāyikacetasikavīriyavasena āraddhavīriyassa. Upaṭṭhitassatissāti catusatipaṭṭhānavasena
analyzed: saṅgaṇika ārāmassa ati gaṇa saṅgaṇikāya ca iva kilesa saṅgaṇikāya ca ratassa āraddha vīriyassa ati  kāyika cetasika vīriya vasena āraddha vīriyassa upaṭṭhita ssatissa ati catusati paṭṭhāna vasena
translated: “Who delights in solitude” : who delights in the solitude of the group and in the solitude of the defilements. “Who is strenuous” :🔽who is strenuous in bodily and mental energy. “Who is mindful” :

original: upaṭṭhitassatissa. Samāhitassāti ekaggacittassa. Paññavatoti kammassakatapaññāya paññavato.
analyzed: upaṭṭhita ssatissa samāhitassa ati ekagga cittassa paññavataḥ ti kammassakata paññāya paññavataḥ

analyzed: sādhu sādhu iti therassa vitakkam sampahaṃsentaḥ evam āha imam aṭṭhamanti satta nidhī  laddha purisassa aṭṭhamam dentaḥ viya satta maṇi ratanāni satta hatthi ratanāni satta  assa ratanāni laddha purisassa aṭṭhamam dentaḥ viya satta mahāpurisa vitakke vitakketvā
translated: as if giving the eighth of the seven treasures

original: ṭhitassa aṭṭhamaṃ ācikkhanto evamāha. Nippapañcārāmassāti taṇhāmānadiṭṭhipapañcarahitattā
analyzed: ṭhitassa aṭṭhamam ācikkhantaḥ evam āha nippapañca ārāmassa ati taṇhā māna diṭṭhi papañca rahita ttā
translated: to a man who has received the first seven, or as if giving the eighth of the seven great treasures, the seven great elephants, the seven great horses, the seven great jewels, the seven women, the seven men, and the seven chief counselors to a man who has received the first seven of each set, so too, he says this in order to point out the eighth of the seven great thoughts of a man who has stood firm after having thought the first seven great thoughts.

original: nippapañcasaṅkhāte nibbānapade abhiratassa. Itaraṃ tasseva vevacanaṃ. Papañcārāmassāti
analyzed: nippapañca saṅkhāte nibbāna pade abhiratassa itaram tassa iva vevacanam papañca ārāmassa ati

analyzed: yathā vuttesu papañcesu abhiratassa itaram tassa iva vevacanam

original: Yatoti yadā. Tatoti tadā. Nānārattānanti nilapītalohitodātavaṇṇehi nānārajanehi rattānaṃ.🔽Paṃsukūlanti tevīsatiyā khettesu ṭhitapaṃsukūlacīvaraṃ. Khāyissatīti yathā tassa
analyzed: yatas iti yadā tatas iti tadā nila pīta lohita udāta vaṇṇehi nānā rajanehi  paṃsukūlanti tevīsatiyā khettesu ṭhita paṃsukūla cīvaram khāyissati iti yathā tassa
translated: When: at the time when. Then: at the time when. With various colours: with various colours such as blue, yellow, red, and white.
