original: udakassa suvaṇṇabhiṅgāraṃ pūretvā “imasmiṃ loke sace imaṃ dānaṃ paṭiggahetuṃ yuttarūpā
analyzed: udakassa suvaṇṇa bhiṅgāram pūretvā imasmin loke sace imam dānam paṭiggahetum yutta rūpā
translated: and having arranged a garment worth five hundred pieces of money over one shoulder, he adorned himself with all the ornaments, and in order to test the gifts, he filled a golden pitcher with water of the color of crystal, saying, “If there be any in the world worthy to receive this gift,🔽let him come hither.”

original: dakkhiṇeyyapuggalā atthi, idaṃ udakaṃ nikkhamitvā pathaviṃ gaṇhātu. Sace natthi,🔽evameva tiṭṭhatū”ti saccakiriyaṃ katvā bhiṅgāraṃ adhomukhaṃ akāsi. Udakaṃ dhamakaraṇena🔽gahitaṃ viya ahosi. Bodhisatto “suñño vata, bho, jambudīpo, ekapuggalopi dakkhiṇaṃ🔽paṭiggahetuṃ yuttarūpo natthī”ti vippaṭisāraṃ akatvā “sace dāyakassa vasenāyaṃ dakkhiṇā🔽visujjhissati, udakaṃ nikkhamitvā pathaviṃ gaṇhātū”ti cintesi. Phalikavaṇṇasadisaṃ
analyzed: dakkhiṇeyya puggalāḥ atthi idam udakam nikkhamitvā pathavim gaṇhātu sace na atthi  evam eva tiṭṭhatu iti saccakiriyam katvā bhiṅgāram adhomukham akāsi udakam dhamakaraṇena  gahitam viya ahosi bodhisatto suññaḥ vata bho jambudīpo eka puggalaḥ api dakkhiṇam  paṭiggahetum yutta rūpaḥ na atthi iti vippaṭisāram a katvā sace dāyakassa vasena ayam dakkhiṇā  visujjhissati udakam nikkhamitvā pathavim gaṇhātu iti cintesi phalika vaṇṇa sadisam
translated: “If there be any worthy of offerings, let this water go forth and touch the earth. If there be none,

original: udakaṃ nikkhamitvā pathaviṃ gaṇhi. “Idāni dānaṃ dassāmī”ti dānaggaṃ patvā dānaṃ oloketvā🔽yāguvelāya yāguṃ, khajjakavelāya khajjakaṃ, bhojanavelāya bhojanaṃ dāpesi. Eteneva🔽nīhārena divase divase dānaṃ dīyati.
analyzed: udakam nikkhamitvā pathavim gaṇhi idāni dānam dassāmi iti dāna aggam patvā dānam oloketvā 🔽yāgu velāya yāgum khajjaka velāya khajjakam bhojana velāya bhojanam dāpesi etena iva 🔽nīhārena divase divase dānam dīyati
translated: let it remain as it is.” Having thus made his vow, he turned the water-pot upside down. The water remained as if it had been caught in a funnel. The Bodhisatta thought, “Empty indeed is the world! There is not a single person worthy to receive this offering.” But he did not repent. “If this offering is to be purified by the will of the giver, let the water go forth and touch the earth.” The water, like a streak of lightning, went forth and touched the earth. “Now I will give the offering,” he thought. He went to the place where the offering was prepared, and looking at the food, he had gruel given to those who wanted gruel, solid food to those who wanted solid food, and rice to those who wanted rice. In this way he gave the offering day after day.

original: Tasmiṃ kho pana dānagge “idaṃ nāma atthi, idaṃ nāma natthī”ti vattabbaṃ natthi. Idāni
analyzed: tasmin kho pana dāna agge idam nāma atthi idam nāma natthi iti vattabbam natthi idāni
translated: There was no need to say, “This is, this is not.”

original: taṃ dānaṃ ettakamatteneva na niṭṭhaṃ gamissatīti rattasuvaṇṇaṃ nīharāpetvā suvaṇṇapātiyo
analyzed: tam dānam ettaka mattena iva na niṭṭham gamissati iti ratta suvaṇṇam nīharāpetvā suvaṇṇa pātiyaḥ
translated: But the gift would not be completed with so little as that. So he had gold brought and had golden bowls made,

original: kāretvā caturāsītisuvaṇṇapātisahassādīnaṃ atthāya caturāsītirājasahassānaṃ sāsanaṃ
analyzed: kāretvā caturāsīti suvaṇṇa pāti sahassa ādīnam atthāya caturāsīti rāja sahassānam sāsanam
translated: and sent word to eighty-four thousand kings to provide eighty-four thousand golden bowls.

original: pahiṇi. Rājāno “cirassaṃ vata mayaṃ ācariyena anuggahitā”ti sabbaṃ sampādetvā pesesuṃ.
analyzed: rājāno cirassam vata mayam ācariyena anuggahitā ati sabbam sampādetvā pesesuṃ
translated: The kings said, “At last we have been remembered by our teacher,” and they provided everything and sent it.

original: Dāne diyyamāneyeva satta vassāni satta māsā atikkantā. Atha brāhmaṇo “hiraññaṃ bhājetvā
analyzed: dāne diyyamāneya iva satta vassāni satta māsāḥ atikkantāḥ atha brāhmaṇaḥ hiraññam bhājetvā
translated: When the gift was being given, seven years and seven months passed. Then the brahman thought, “I will divide the gold and give the gift.”

original: dānaṃ dassāmī”ti mahante okāse dānaṃ sajjāpesi. Sajjāpetvā caturāsīti suvaṇṇapātisahassāni
analyzed: dānam dassāmi iti mahante okāse dānam sajjāpesi sajjāpetvā catur asīti suvaṇṇa pāti sahassāni
translated: He had a large space prepared for the gift. When it was prepared, he gave eighty-four thousand golden bowls,

original: ādiṃ katvā koṭito paṭṭhāya adāsi.
analyzed: ādim katvā koṭito paṭṭhāya adāsi
translated: beginning with a hundred thousand for each bowl.

original: Tattha rūpiyapūrānīti rajatataṭṭirajataphālarajatamāsakehi pūrāni. Pātiyo pana khuddikāti
analyzed: tattha rūpiya pūrāni iti rajata taṭṭi rajata phāla rajata māsakehi pūrāni pātiyaḥ pana
translated: Herein, filled with silver means filled with silver plates, silver lids, and silver stands. But the bowls were small

original: na sallakkhetabbā, ekakarīsappamāṇe bhūmibhāge catassova pātiyo ṭhapayiṃsu. Pātimakuḷaṃ
analyzed: na sallakkhetabbāḥ eka karīsa ppamāṇe bhūmi bhāge catasso uva pātiyaḥ ṭhapayiṃsu pāti makuḷam
translated: and they did not have to be measured out. They placed four bowls on a space the size of a cow’s hide. The bowl was made of the nine precious substances.

original: navaratanaṃ hoti, mukhavaṭṭito paṭṭhāya aṭṭharatanaṃ, pātimukhavaṭṭiyā chayutto ājaññaratho🔽anupariyāyati, dadamāno pātiyā bāhirantena vaggavagge paṭiggāhake ṭhapetvā paṭhamaṃ
analyzed: nava ratanam hoti mukhavaṭṭitaḥ paṭṭhāya aṭṭha ratanam pātimukhavaṭṭiyā cha yuttaḥ ājañña ratho  anupariyāyati dadamānaḥ pātiyāḥ bāhirantena vagga vagge paṭiggāhake ṭhapetvā paṭhamam
translated: The rim was made of the eight precious substances. A chariot drawn by thoroughbred horses🔽followed behind, giving out bowls. After placing the recipients in a row outside the bowl,

original: pātiyā pakkhittaṃ datvā pacchā sandhisandhito viyojetvā pātinti evaṃ caturāsīti pātisahassāni
analyzed: pātiyā pakkhittam datvā pacchā sandhi sandhitaḥ viyojetvā pātim ti evam caturāsīti pāti sahassāni
translated: he first gave what was put into the bowl and then, after separating them from the rim, the rim. In this way he gave eighty-four thousand bowls.

original: adāsi. Rūpiyapātiādīsupi eseva nayo. Etthapi ca suvaṇṇapūrānīti suvaṇṇataṭṭisuvaṇṇaphālasuvaṇṇamāsakehi
analyzed: adāsi rūpiya pāti ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ ettha api ca suvaṇṇa pūrāni iti suvaṇṇa taṭṭi suvaṇṇa phāla suvaṇṇa māsakehi
translated: The same method applies to the silver bowls, etc. Here too, “filled with gold” means filled with gold dust, gold leaves, and gold coins.

original: pūrāni. Hiraññapūrānīti sattavidharatanapūrāni. Sovaṇṇālaṅkārānīti suvaṇṇālaṅkārāni.
analyzed: pūrāni hirañña pūrāni iti sattavidha ratana pūrāni sovaṇṇa alaṅkārāni iti suvaṇṇa alaṅkārāni
translated: “Filled with silver” means filled with the seven kinds of precious substances. “Adorned with gold” means adorned with gold.

original: Kaṃsūpadhāraṇānīti rajatamayakhīrapaṭicchakāni. Tāsaṃ pana dhenūnaṃ siṅgāni suvaṇṇakosakapariyonaddhāni
analyzed: kaṃsūpadhāraṇāni iti rajata maya khīra paṭicchakāni tāsam pana dhenūnam siṅgāni suvaṇṇa kosaka pariyonaddhāni
translated: “With silver handles” means with silver milk-rice covers. But the horns of the cows were covered with golden boxes.

original: ahesuṃ, gīvāya sumanadāmaṃ piḷandhiṃsu, catūsu pādesu nupūrāni, piṭṭhiyaṃ varadukūlaṃ🔽pārutaṃ, kaṇṭhe suvaṇṇaghaṇṭaṃ bandhiṃsu. Vatthakoṭisahassānīti lokavohārato vīsativatthayugāni
analyzed: ahesum gīvāya sumana dāmam catūsu pādesu nupūrāni vara dukūlam  pārutam kaṇṭhe suvaṇṇa ghaṇṭam bandhiṃsu vattha koṭi sahassāni iti lokavohārataḥ vīsati vattha yugāni
translated: They hung a garland of jasmine flowers round his neck, and anklets on his four feet, and a fine blanket on his back,🔽and a golden bell round his neck. “Ten thousand suits of garments” means twenty-five pairs of garments.

original: ekā koṭi, idha pana dasa sāṭakāti vuttaṃ. Khomasukhumānantiādimhi khomādīsu yaṃ yaṃ
analyzed: ekā koṭi idha pana dasa sāṭakā ti vuttam khoma sukhumāna nti ādimhi khoma ādīsu yam yam
translated: Here, however, “ten garments” is said. “Fine linen” and so on: in the case of linen and so on, whatever was fine,

original: sukhumaṃ, taṃ tadeva adāsi. Yāni panetāni itthidānaṃ usabhadānaṃ majjadānaṃ samajjādānanti
analyzed: su khumam tam tat eva adāsi yāni panetāni itthi dānam usabha dānam majja dānam sa majjā dānan ti
translated: he gave that. But these gifts of women, of bulls, of ointments, and of feasts,

original: adānasammatāni, tānipi esa “velāmassa dānamukhe idaṃ nāma natthī”ti vacanapathaṃ
analyzed: adāna sammatāni tāni pi dāna mukhe idam nāma natthi iti vacana patham
translated: though not really gifts, he gave them, thinking: “There is nothing that is not a gift at the time of giving.”

original: pacchindituṃ parivāratthāya adāsi. Najjo maññe vissandantīti nadiyo viya vissandanti.
analyzed: pacchinditum parivāra atthāya adāsi najjaḥ maññe vissandanti iti nadiyaḥ viya vissandanti
translated: “As if the rivers were flowing back” means as if the rivers were flowing back.

original: Iminā satthā velāmassa dānaṃ kathetvā, “gahapati, etaṃ mahādānaṃ nāñño adāsi, ahaṃ
analyzed: iminā satthā velāmassa dānam kathetvā gahapati etam mahā dānam na aññaḥ adāsi aham
translated: Having thus spoken of Velāma’s gift, the Teacher said: “Householder, no one else gave this great gift. I gave it.

original: adāsiṃ. Evarūpaṃ pana dānaṃ dadantopi ahaṃ paṭiggahetuṃ yuttarūpaṃ puggalaṃ nālatthaṃ,
analyzed: adāsim evarūpam pana dānam dadantaḥ api aham paṭiggahetum yutta rūpam puggalam na alattham
translated: But though I gave such a gift, I did not find a person worthy to receive it.

original: tvaṃ mādise buddhe lokasmiṃ diṭṭhamāne dānaṃ dadamāno kasmā cintesī”ti seṭṭhissa
analyzed: tvam mā ādise buddhe lokasmin diṭṭha māne dānam dadamāno kasmai cintesi iti seṭṭhissa
translated: “Why do you think thus, giving gifts when you have seen a Buddha like me in the world?”🔽and he said, “It may be, householder,” and so on, increasing the teaching.

original: desanaṃ vaḍḍhento siyā kho pana tetiādimāha. Nanu ca yāni tadā ahesuṃ rūpavedanāsaññāsaṅkhāraviññāṇāni,
analyzed: desanam vaḍḍhentaḥ siyā kho pana te ti ādim āha nanu ca yāni tadā ahesum rūpa vedanā saññā saṅkhāra viññāṇāni
translated: But were not the material form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness that existed then ceased?🔽Why did he say, “At that time I was the brahmin Velama”?

original: tāni niruddhāni? Kasmā “ahaṃ tena samayena velāmo brāhmaṇo”ti āhāti? Paveṇiyā avicchinnattā.
analyzed: tāni niruddhāni kasmai aham tena samayena brāhmaṇaḥ iti āha ati paveṇiyā
translated: Because the stream was unbroken.

original: Tāni hi rūpādīni nirujjhamānāni imesaṃ paccaye datvā niruddhāni aparāparaṃ avicchinnaṃ🔽paveṇiṃ gahetvā evamāha. Na taṃ koci dakkhiṇaṃ sodhetīti koci samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo
analyzed: tāni hi rūpa ādīni nirujjhamānāni imesam paccaye da tvā niruddhāni apara aparam avicchinnam  paveṇim gahetvā evam āha na tam koci dakkhiṇam sodheti iti koci samaṇaḥ vā brāhmaṇo
translated: For those material form, etc., having given their support to these things while they were ceasing, ceased themselves, and they took up the stream that was unbroken🔽and continued in succession. No one can purify that offering.

original: vā devo vā māro vā uṭṭhāya taṃ dakkhiṇaṃ sodhetīti vattabbo nāhosi. Tañhi dakkhiṇaṃ
analyzed: vā devaḥ vā māraḥ vā uṭṭhāya tam dakkhiṇam sodheti iti vattabbaḥ na ahosi tat hi dakkhiṇam
translated: No one, whether a recluse or brahmin, a god, Mara, or Brahma, can be said to purify that offering.

original: sodhento uttamakoṭiyā buddho, heṭṭhimakoṭiyā dhammasenāpatisāriputtattherasadiso sāvako sodheyya.
analyzed: sodhentaḥ uttama koṭiyā buddhaḥ heṭṭhima koṭiyā dhammasenāpati sāriputta tthera sadiso sāvako sodheyya
translated: For one who would purify that offering would have to be either a Buddha at the highest point or a disciple like the Elder Sariputta, the General of the Dhamma, at the lowest point.

original: Diṭṭhisampannanti dassanasampannaṃ sotāpannaṃ. Idaṃ tato mahapphalataranti idaṃ sotāpannassa🔽dinnadānaṃ lokiyamahājanassa sattamāsādhikāni satta saṃvaccharāni ettakaṃ hiraññasuvaṇṇaṃ
analyzed: diṭṭhi sampannanti dassana sampannam sotāpannam idam tatas mahapphalataram ti idam sotāpannassa  dinna dānam lokiya mahājanassa satta māsa adhikāni satta saṃvaccharāni ettakam hirañña suvaṇṇam
translated: “One perfect in view”: one perfect in seeing, a Stream-Enterer. “This is of far greater fruit”: this gift given to a Stream-Enterer

original: pariccajantena dinnadānato mahapphalaṃ.
analyzed: pariccajantena dinna dānataḥ mahat phalam
translated: is of greater fruit than that given by one who gives gold and silver to the extent of seven hundred thousand for seven years and seven months to the world of men.

original: Yo ca sataṃ diṭṭhisampannānanti ettha ekassa sakadāgāmissa vasena ekuttarasataṃ sotāpanne
analyzed: yaḥ ca satam diṭṭhi sampannānam ti ettha ekassa sakadāgāmissa vasena ekuttara satam sotāpanne
translated: “And if a hundred perfect in view”: here, taking one Non-Returner, a hundred and one Stream-Enterers

original: katvā sotāpannagaṇanā veditabbā. Iminā upāyena sabbavāresu heṭṭhā heṭṭhā āgate anantarena
analyzed: katvā sotāpanna gaṇanā veditabbā iminā upāyena sabba vāresu heṭṭhā heṭṭhā āgate anantarena
translated: should be understood as the number of Stream-Enterers. By this method, in all the cases below, the number of the next

original: sataguṇaṃ katvā puggalagaṇanā veditabbā.🔽Buddhappamukhanti ettha sammāsambuddhaṃ saṅghattheraṃ katvā nisinno saṅgho buddhappamukho
analyzed: sataguṇam katvā puggala gaṇanā veditabbā  buddha ppamukham ti ettha sammāsambuddham saṅgha theram katvā nisinnaḥ saṅghaḥ buddha ppamukhaḥ
translated: person should be understood as a hundred times the number of the previous person.

original: saṅghoti veditabbo. Cātuddisaṃ saṅghaṃ uddissāti ettha cātuddisaṃ saṅghaṃ uddissa
analyzed: saṅghaḥ iti veditabbaḥ cātuddisam saṅgham uddissa ati ettha cātuddisam saṅgham uddissa
translated: “The Community with the Buddha at its head”: here, the Community should be understood as the Community with the Buddha at its head, sitting down with the Fully Enlightened One as the senior elder.🔽“The Community on the four quarters”: here, a monastery where a shrine has been established, where the Dhamma is listened to,

original: katavihāro nāma yattha cetiyaṃ patiṭṭhitaṃ hoti, dhammassavanaṃ karīyati, catūhi
analyzed: katavihāraḥ nāma yattha cetiyam patiṭṭhitam hoti dhammassavanam karīyati catūhi
translated: and where the four requisites are provided

original: disāhi anudisāhi ca bhikkhū āgantvā appaṭipucchitvāyeva pāde dhovitvā kuñcikāya dvāraṃ
analyzed: disāhi anudisāhi ca bhikkhū āgantvā a paṭipucchitvāya iva pāde dhovitvā kuñcikāya dvāraṃ
translated: Monks come from all directions, wash their feet, and without asking permission open the door with their key,

original: vivaritvā senāsanaṃ paṭijaggitvā vasitvā yathāphāsukaṃ gacchanti. So antamaso caturataniyā
analyzed: vivaritvā senāsanam paṭijaggitvā vasitvā yathāphāsukam gacchanti catur ataniyā
translated: enter the dwelling, and go away again as they please after using it as they wish. Even if it is only a leaf hut,

original: paṇṇasālāpi hotu, cātuddisaṃ saṅghaṃ uddissa katavihārotveva vuccati.
analyzed: paṇṇasālā api hotu cātuddisam saṅgham uddissa kata vihārā tu eva vuccati
translated: it is called a monastery dedicated to the Community of the four quarters.

original: Saraṇaṃ gaccheyyāti ettha maggenāgataṃ anivattanasaraṇaṃ adhippetaṃ. Apare panāhu
analyzed: saraṇam gaccheyya ati ettha maggena āgatam a nivattana saraṇam adhippetam apare pana āhu
translated: ‘Goes for refuge’: the refuge that has gone by means of the path and does not return is intended here. But others say

original: – attānaṃ niyyādetvā dinnattā saraṇāgamanaṃ tato mahapphalataranti vuttaṃ. Sikkhāpadāni
analyzed: attānam niyyādetvā dinna ttā saraṇa āgamanam tatas mahapphalataranti vuttam sikkhāpadāni
translated: that the going for refuge is more fruitful than the giving because it is given by dedicating oneself.

original: samādiyeyyāti pañca sīlāni gaṇheyya. Sīlampi maggena āgataṃ anivattanasīlameva kathitaṃ.
analyzed: samādiyeyya ati pañca sīlāni gaṇheyya sīlam pi maggena āgatam a nivattana sīlam eva kathitam
translated: ‘Undertakes the training precepts’: takes up the five training precepts. The virtue that has gone by means of the path and does not return is called ‘training precepts.’

original: Apare panāhu – sabbasattānaṃ abhayadānassa dinnattā sīlaṃ tato mahapphalataranti
analyzed: apare pana āhu sabba sattānam abhaya dānassa dinna ttā sīlam tatas mahapphalataranti
translated: But others say that virtue is more fruitful than the giving because it is the giving of fearlessness to all beings.

original: vuttaṃ. Gandhohanamattanti gandhaūhanamattaṃ, dvīhaṅgulīhi gaṇḍapiṇḍaṃ gahetvā upasiṅghanamattaṃ.
analyzed: vuttam gandhohana mattam ti gandha ūhana mattam dvīhi aṅgulīhi gaṇḍa piṇḍam gahetvā upasiṅghana mattam
translated: ‘Just a sniff’: just a sniff, just a whiff, just a smell, as if taking a pinch of powder with two fingers and smelling it.

original: Apare pana “gaddohanamatta”nti pāḷiṃ vatvā gāviyā ekavāraṃ thanaañchanamattanti atthaṃ
analyzed: apare pana gaddohanam attanti pāḷim vatvā gāviyā eka vāram atthaṃ
translated: explain the meaning as “the mere bellowing of a cow once.”🔽“Mindful and clearly comprehending”: he is mindful by the mindfulness faculty and clearly comprehending by the understanding faculty.🔽“With a mind of loving-kindness”: with a mind of compassion for all beings. But this is taken

original: vadanti. Mettacittanti sabbasattānaṃ hitānupharaṇacittaṃ. Taṃ pana appanāvaseneva
analyzed: vadanti metta cittam ti sabba sattānam hita anupharaṇa cittam tam pana appanā vasena iva
translated: as referring to the absorption of loving-kindness.

original: gahitaṃ. Aniccasaññanti maggassa anantarapaccayabhāvena sikhāpattabalavavipassanaṃ.🔽Upamāto pana imāni dānādīni puññāni evaṃ veditabbāni – sacepi hi jambudīpaṃ bheritalasadisaṃ
analyzed: gahitam anicca saññanti maggassa anantara paccaya bhāvena sikhāpatta balava vipassanam  upamātaḥ pana imāni dāna ādīni puññāni evam veditabbāni sace pi hi jambudīpam bheri tala sadisam
translated: “Perception of impermanence”: insight that is strong enough to lead to the path, by being its proximate cause.🔽But these merits of giving, etc., should be understood as follows by way of simile: if the whole of Jambudīpa were made into a single great granary,🔽and if all the people in it were to make a single great heap of rice from the produce of that granary,

original: samatalaṃ katvā koṭito paṭṭhāya pallaṅke attharitvā ariyapuggale nisīdāpeyya, tattha🔽sotāpannānaṃ dasa pantiyo assu, sakadāgāmīnaṃ pañca, anāgāmīnaṃ aḍḍhateyyā, khiṇāsavānaṃ🔽diyaḍḍhā, paccekabuddhānaṃ ekā panti bhaveyya, sammāsambuddho ekakova. Ettakassa
analyzed: sama talam katvā koṭitaḥ paṭṭhāya pallaṅke attharitvā ariya puggale tattha  sotāpannānam dasa pantiyaḥ assu sakadāgāmīnam pañca anāgāmīnam aḍḍhateyyā khiṇāsavānam  paccekabuddhānam ekā bhaveyya sammāsambuddhaḥ ekakaḥ uva ettakassa

analyzed: na guṇa vaṇṇena sampanno sesam pāḷi nayena iva veditabbam yat ha ittha vattabbam siyā  tat tika nipāta vaṇṇanāyam vuttam eva  taṇhāmūlaka sutta vaṇṇanā  tatiye taṇham paṭicca ati dve taṇhāḥ esana taṇhā esita taṇhā ca yāya taṇhāya aja patha saṅku patha ādīni
translated: In the second sutta, “endowed with speed” means endowed with the speed of the feet. “Not endowed with beauty” means not endowed with the beauty of the body. “Among men endowed with speed” means endowed with the speed of knowledge. “Not endowed with beauty” means not endowed with the beauty of virtue. The rest can be understood from the text itself. What should be said here has already been said in the commentary on the Tikanipata.🔽. Taṇhāmūlakasutta

original: paṭipajjitvā bhoge esati gavesati, ayaṃ esanataṇhā nāma. Yā tesu esitesu gavesitesu
analyzed: paṭipajjitvā bhoge esati gavesati ayam esana taṇhā nāma yā tesu esitesu gavesitesu
translated: In the third sutta, “with craving as condition”: there are two kinds of craving, namely, the craving for search and the craving for what has been searched out. The craving by which one goes by wrong paths and crooked paths, etc., and searches for and seeks out wealth, is called the craving for search. The craving for what has been searched out and sought out is called the craving for what has been searched out.

original: paṭiladdhesu taṇhā, ayaṃ esitataṇhā nāma. Idha pana esanataṇhā daṭṭhabbā. Pariyesanāti
analyzed: paṭiladdhesu taṇhā ayam esitataṇhā nāma idha pana esana taṇhā daṭṭhabbā pariyesanā ti
translated: Craving for what is obtained is called craving for search. But here craving for search should be understood as craving for acquisition.

original: rūpādiārammaṇapariyesanā. Sā hi esanataṇhāya sati hoti. Lābhoti rūpādiārammaṇapaṭilābho.
analyzed: rūpa ādi ārammaṇa pariyesanā sā hi esana taṇhāya sati hoti rūpa ādi ārammaṇa paṭilābho
translated: Seeking is the seeking for the object of the kind of craving that is craving for search. For that is when there is craving for search. Gain is the obtaining of the object of the kind of craving that is craving for acquisition.

original: So hi pariyesanāya sati hoti.🔽Vinicchayo pana ñāṇataṇhādiṭṭhivitakkavasena catubbidho. Tattha “sukhavinicchayaṃ
analyzed: saḥ hi pariyesanāya sati  vinicchayaḥ pana ñāṇa taṇhā diṭṭhi vitakka vasena catubbidhaḥ tattha sukha vinicchayam
translated: For that is when there is seeking.🔽Decision is of four kinds as knowledge, craving, view, and thought. Herein, “One should know the decision regarding pleasure. Having known the decision regarding pleasure, one should practice for the attainment of pleasure internally” .

original: jaññā, sukhavinicchayaṃ ñatvā ajjhattaṃ sukhamanuyuñjeyyā”ti ayaṃ ñāṇavinicchayo.
analyzed: jaññā sukha vinicchayam ñatvā ajjhattam sukham anuyuñjeyya iti ayam ñāṇa vinicchayaḥ
translated: This is decision as knowledge.

original: “Vinicchayāti dve vinicchayā taṇhāvinicchayo ca diṭṭhivinicchayo cā”ti evaṃ āgatāni
analyzed: vinicchayā ati dve vinicchayā taṇhā vinicchayo ca diṭṭhi vinicchayo ca ati evam āgatāni
translated: “‘Decision’: there are two kinds of decision, decision through craving and decision through view” .

original: aṭṭhasatataṇhāvicaritāni taṇhāvinicchayo. Dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhiyo diṭṭhivinicchayo. “Chando
analyzed: aṭṭha sata taṇhā vicaritāni taṇhā vinicchayaḥ dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhiyaḥ diṭṭhi vinicchayo chando
translated: The eighty-four kinds of craving are decision through craving. The sixty-two views are decision through view. “Desire, Ruler of the Gods, has thinking as its source” .

original: kho, devānaminda, vitakkanidāno”ti imasmiṃ pana sutte idha vinicchayoti vutto vitakkoyeva
analyzed: kho devānaminda vitakka nidānaḥ ti imasmim pana sutte idha vinicchayaḥ ti vuttaḥ
translated: But in this sutta, “decision” is said to be thinking.

original: āgato. Lābhaṃ labhitvā hi iṭṭhāniṭṭhaṃ sundarāsundaraṃ vitakkeneva vinicchinanti🔽“ettakaṃ me rūpārammaṇatthāya bhavissati, ettakaṃ saddhārammaṇatthāya, ettakaṃ mayhaṃ
analyzed: āgataḥ lābham labhitvā hi iṭṭha aniṭṭham sundara asundaram vitakkena iva vinicchinanti  ettakam me rūpa ārammaṇa tthāya bhavissati ettakam saddhā ārammaṇa tthāya ettakam mayham
translated: Having obtained gain, they decide by mere thought what is desirable and undesirable, beautiful and ugly,

original: bhavissati, ettakaṃ parassa, ettakaṃ paribhuñjissāmi, ettakaṃ nidahissāmī”ti. Tena
analyzed: bhavissati ettakam parassa ettakam paribhuñjissāmi ettakam nidahissāmi iti tena
translated: thinking: “So much will be for the purpose of visible forms, so much for the purpose of sounds, so much will be for me, so much for others, so much I will use, so much I will store away.”

original: vuttaṃ – lābhaṃ paṭicca vinicchayoti.🔽Chandarāgoti evaṃ akusalavitakkena vitakkite vatthusmiṃ dubbalarāgo ca balavarāgo🔽ca uppajjati. Idañhi idha chandoti dubbalarāgassādhivacanaṃ. Ajjhosānanti ahaṃ mamanti🔽balavasanniṭṭhānaṃ. Pariggahoti taṇhādiṭṭhivasena pariggahakaraṇaṃ. Macchariyanti
analyzed: vuttam lābham paṭicca vinicchayo ti  chanda rāgaḥ ti evam akusala vitakkena vitakkite vatthusmim dubbala rāgo ca balava rāgo  ca uppajjati idam hi idha chando ti dubbala rāgassa adhivacanam aham mama nti  balava sanniṭṭhānam pariggaho ti taṇhā diṭṭhi vasena pariggaha karaṇam macchariyanti
translated: Hence it was said: “Depending on gain, there is decision-making.”

original: parehi sādhāraṇabhāvassa asahanatā. Tenevassa porāṇā evaṃ vacanatthaṃ vadanti – “idaṃ
analyzed: parehi sādhāraṇa bhāvassa a sahana tā porāṇāḥ evam vacana attham vadanti idam
translated: “Desire and lust”: in regard to the object thought about by unwholesome thought, weak lust and strong lust arise. For here “desire” is a term for weak lust, and “clinging” is the strong determination of “I” and “mine.” “Grasping” is the act of grasping by way of craving and views. “Avarice” is the inability to bear sharing with others. Therefore the ancients gave the following explanation of the meaning of the words: “This is mine, this I am, this is my self.”

original: acchariyaṃ mayhameva hotu, mā aññassa acchariyaṃ hotūti pavattattā macchariyanti🔽vuccatī”ti. Ārakkhoti dvārapidahanamañjūsāgopanādivasena suṭṭhu rakkhanaṃ. Adhikarotīti🔽adhikaraṇaṃ, kāraṇassetaṃ nāmaṃ. Ārakkhādhikaraṇanti bhāvanapuṃsakaṃ, ārakkhāhetūti🔽attho. Daṇḍādānādīsu paranisedhanatthaṃ daṇḍassa ādānaṃ daṇḍādānaṃ. Ekato dhārādino
analyzed: acchariyam mayham eva hotu mā aññassa acchariyam hotu uti pavatta ttā macchariyanti  vuccati iti ārakkho ti dvāra pidahana mañjūsā gopana ādi vasena suṭṭhu rakkhanam adhikaroti iti  adhikaraṇam kāraṇassa itam nāmam ārakkha adhikaraṇanti bhāva napuṃsakam ārakkhā hetu uti  atthaḥ daṇḍa ādāna ādīsu para nisedhana attham daṇḍassa ādānam daṇḍa ādānam ekatas dhārā ādino
translated: It is called “miserliness” because it occurs thus: “Let there be no wonder in me, let there be no wonder in anyone else.”🔽“Guarding” is guarding well by such means as locking the door and hiding the key. “Cause for a dispute” is a cause for a dispute. This is a name for a reason. “Cause for a dispute about guarding” is a neuter noun; the meaning is: a cause for guarding.

original: satthassa ādānaṃ satthādānaṃ. Kalahoti kāyakalahopi vācākalahopi. Purimo viggaho,
analyzed: satthassa ādānam sattha ādānam kalaho ti kāya kalahaḥ api vācā kalahaḥ api purimaḥ viggahaḥ
translated: “Taking up a stick” is the taking up of a stick for the purpose of restraining others in the case of beating, etc. “Taking up a knife” is the taking up of a knife for the purpose of killing, etc. “Quarrel” is a quarrel by body or by speech. The former is a “dispute,” the latter a “litigation.”

original: pacchimo vivādo. Tuvaṃtuvanti agāravavasena tuvaṃtuvaṃvacanaṃ.
analyzed: pacchimaḥ vivādaḥ agārava vasena tuvaṃtuvaṃvacanam
translated: “You and I” is the expression “you and I” used in a disrespectful way.

analyzed: sattāvāsa sutta vaṇṇanā  catutthe satta āvāsā ti sattānam āvāsāḥ vasana ṭṭhānāni iti tattha suddhāvāsā api
translated: . Commentary on the Sattavāsasutta

analyzed: sattāvāsā iva asabbakālika ttā pana na gahitā suddhāvāsāḥ hi buddhānam khandhāvāra ṭṭhāna sadisā
translated: . In the fourth sutta, “abodes of beings” are the abodes of beings, their places of dwelling. Here the pure abodes are also abodes of beings, but they are not included because they are not always so. For the pure abodes are like the headquarters of the Buddhas,

original: asaṅkheyyakappe buddhesu anibbattesu taṃ ṭhānaṃ suññaṃ hoti. Iti asabbakālikattā
analyzed: asaṅkheyya kappe buddhesu a nibbattesu tat ṭhānam suññam hoti iti asabbakālikattā
translated: When no Buddhas have been reborn for countless ages, that place is empty.

original: na gahitā. Sesamettha viññāṇaṭṭhitīsu vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: na gahitā sesam ettha viññāṇa ṭṭhitīsu vutta nayena iva veditabbam
translated: When incalculable aeons have passed without the arising of Buddhas, that place is empty. Thus it is not included because it does not exist at all times. The rest should be understood here in the way already stated under the stations for consciousness.

original: 5. Paññāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: paññā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The fifth sutta

original: 25. Pañcame yatoti yasmiṃ kāle. Suparicitaṃ hotīti suṭṭhu upacitaṃ suvaḍḍhitaṃ hoti.
analyzed: pañcame yatas iti yasmin kāle su paricitam hoti iti suṭṭhu upacitam su vaḍḍhitam hoti
translated: “When”: at the time when. “Is well known”: is well accumulated, well increased.

original: Kallaṃ vacanāyāti yuttaṃ vattuṃ. Vītarāganti vigatarāgaṃ. Asarāgadhammanti na sarajjanasabhāvaṃ.🔽Anāvattidhammanti anāvattanasabhāvaṃ anibbattārahaṃ, appaṭisandhikabhāveneva nirujjhanasabhāvanti
analyzed: kallam vacanāya ati yuttam vattum vīta rāganti vigata rāgam na sarat jana sabhāvam  anāvatti dhammanti anāvattana sabhāvam anibbatta araham appaṭisandhika bhāvena iva nirujjhana sabhāvanti
translated: “Is fit to be spoken”: is suitable to be spoken. “Free from passion”: free from lust. “Not subject to passion”: not of the nature to generate lust.

original: attho. Imasmiṃ sutte khīṇāsavova kathito.🔽6. Silāyūpasuttavaṇṇanā🔽26. Chaṭṭhe candikāputtoti mātu nāmavasena paññāto candikāputtatthero. Cetasā cittaṃ
analyzed: attho imasmin sutte khīṇāsavaḥ uva kathito  silāyūpa sutta vaṇṇanā  chaṭṭhe candikāputto ti mātu nāma vasena paññāto candikāputta thero cetasā cittam
translated: “Not subject to return”: not of the nature to return, not fit to be reborn, of the nature to cease through non-arising, is the meaning. In this sutta only one whose cankers are destroyed is spoken of.🔽The sixth sutta

original: hotīti cittavārapariyāyena cittavārapariyāyo cito vaḍḍhito hoti. Cetasā cittaṃ suparicitanti
analyzed: hoti iti citta vāra pariyāyena citta vāra pariyāyaḥ citaḥ vaḍḍhitaḥ hoti cetasā cittam su paricitanti
translated: “Caṇḍakāḷiputta”: the elder known as Caṇḍakāḷiputta after his mother’s name. “The mind is well known to him by means of the mind” : by the method of the mind-door process, the mind-door process is well known, well increased, to him. “The mind is well apprehended by him with the mind” :

original: cittavārapariyāyena cittavārapariyāyo uparūpari sucito suvaḍḍhito hoti. Nevassa cittaṃ🔽pariyādiyantīti tāni ārammaṇāni tassa khīṇāsavassa cittuppādaṃ gahetvā khepetvā ṭhātuṃ
analyzed: citta vāra pariyāyena citta vāra pariyāyo upari upari su citaḥ su vaḍḍhitaḥ hoti na iva assa cittam  pariyādiyanti iti tāni ārammaṇāni tassa khīṇāsavassa cittuppādam gahetvā khepetvā ṭhātum
translated: The successive steps of consciousness are well purified, well cleansed, in him.🔽His consciousness does not come under the sway of those objects: those objects cannot hold his consciousness captive by seizing it and making it stay with them.

original: na sakkonti. Amissīkatanti tāni ārammaṇāni anallīnattā tehi amissīkataṃ. Āneñjappattanti
analyzed: na sakkonti amissīkatanti tāni ārammaṇāni an allīna ttā tehi amissīkatam āneñja ppattanti
translated: Unmixed: because they are not absorbed in them, they are unmixed with them.

original: aniñjanabhāvaṃ nipphandanabhāvaṃ pattaṃ.
analyzed: an iñjana bhāvam nipphandana bhāvam pattam
translated: It has reached imperturbability: it has reached imperturbability, non-agitation.🔽A stone pillar: a stone pillar. Sixteen cubits long: sixteen cubits in length.

original: Silāyūpoti silāthambho. Soḷasakukkukoti dīghato soḷasahattho. Heṭṭhānemaṅgamāti āvāṭassa
analyzed: silā yūpo ti silā thambho soḷasa kukkuko ti dīghataḥ soḷasa hatthaḥ āvāṭassa
translated: Below the ground: below the pit.🔽Above the ground: above the pit.

original: heṭṭhāgatā. Upari nemassāti upari āvāṭassa. Sunikhātattāti ayamusalehi koṭṭetvā koṭṭetvā🔽suṭṭhu nikhātattā. Evameva khoti ettha silāyūpo viya khīṇāsavo daṭṭhabbo, mahāvātā
analyzed: heṭṭhā gatā upari nemassa ati upari āvāṭassa su nikhāta ttā ati aya musalehi koṭṭetvā koṭṭetvā  suṭṭhu nikhāta ttā evam eva kho ti ettha silā yūpaḥ viya khīṇa āsavaḥ daṭṭhabbo mahā vātā
translated: Well sunk: well sunk by striking with hammers.

original: viya chasu dvāresu uppajjanakā kilesā, catūhi disāhi āgantvā vātānaṃ silāyūpaṃ cāletuṃ
analyzed: chasu dvāresu uppajjanakā kilesā catūhi disāhi āgantvā vātānam silāyūpam cāletum
translated: Just so: here the one with cankers destroyed should be regarded as the stone pillar, the defilements arising at the six doors as the great winds, and the winds coming from the four quarters as the winds coming from the four quarters.

original: asamatthabhāvo viya chasu dvāresu uppajjanakakilesānaṃ khīṇāsavassa cittaṃ cāletuṃ
analyzed: asamattha bhāvaḥ viya chasu dvāresu uppajjanaka kilesānam khīṇāsavassa cittam cāletum
translated: just as it is impossible to make a man whose corruptions are destroyed waver by stirring up the defilements that arise through the six doors.

original: asamatthabhāvo veditabbo. Imasmimpi sutte khīṇāsavova kathito.
analyzed: asamattha bhāvaḥ veditabbaḥ imasmim pi sutte khīṇāsavaḥ iva kathito
translated: The meaning should be understood as the inability to stir the heart of one whose cankers are destroyed, just as the inability to stir the six elements. In this sutta too only one whose cankers are destroyed is spoken of.

original: 7-8. Verasuttadvayavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vera sutta dvaya vaṇṇanā
translated: The two Suttas on Fear

original: 27-28. Sattame bhayaṃ veraṃ pasavatīti cittutrāsabhayañca puggalaverañca paṭilabhati.
analyzed: sattame bhayam veram pasavati iti cittu trāsa bhayañca puggala veram ca paṭilabhati
translated: In the seventh, he produces fear and enmity: he gets both the fear of mental anguish and enmity towards persons.

original: Cetasikanti cittanissitaṃ. Dukkhanti kāyavatthukaṃ. Domanassanti paṭighasampayuttadukkhaṃ.🔽Imasmiṃ sutte sotāpattimaggo kathito. Aṭṭhamaṃ bhikkhusaṅghassa kathitaṃ, imasmiṃ
analyzed: cetasikanti citta nissitam dukkhanti kāya vatthukam domanassanti paṭigha sampayutta dukkhaṃ  imasmim sutte sotāpatti maggo kathito aṭṭhamam bhikkhu saṅghassa kathitam imasmim
translated: Mental: dependent on the mind. Pain: bodily pain. Sorrow: the pain associated with resentment.

original: pana sotāpannova kathitoti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pana sotāpannaḥ eva kathitaḥ iti vuttam
translated: In this sutta the path of stream-entry is spoken of. The eighth is spoken of as the bhikkhu-saṅgha. But here only the stream-enterer is spoken of.

original: 9. Āghātavatthusuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: āghāta vatthu sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Sutta on the Basis for Resentment

original: 29. Navame āghātavatthūnīti āghātakāraṇāni. Āghātaṃ bandhatīti kopaṃ bandhati uppādeti.
analyzed: navame āghāta vatthūni iti āghāta kāraṇāni āghātam bandhati iti kopam bandhati uppādeti
translated: In the ninth, the bases for resentment are the causes for resentment. He binds resentment: he produces anger.

original: 10-11. Āghātapaṭivinayasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: āghāta paṭivinaya sutta ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: The Suttas on the Abandoning of Resentment, etc.

original: 30-31. Dasame āghātapaṭivinayāti āghātassa paṭivinayakāraṇāni. Taṃ kutettha labbhāti
analyzed: dasame āghāta paṭivinayā ti āghātassa paṭivinaya kāraṇāni tam kutas ittha
translated: In the tenth, the abandoning of resentment are the causes for the abandoning of resentment. Where can it be found?

original: “taṃ anatthacaraṇaṃ mā ahosī”ti etasmiṃ puggale kuto labbhā, kena kāraṇena sakkā
analyzed: tam anattha caraṇam mā ahosi iti etasmin puggale kutas labbhā kena kāraṇena sakkā
translated: “How could there be any harm done to him?” “By what means could I get at him?”

original: laddhuṃ, “paro nāma parassa attano cittaruciyā anatthaṃ karotī”ti evaṃ cintetvā āghātaṃ🔽paṭivineti. Atha vā sacāhaṃ kopaṃ kareyyaṃ, taṃ kopakaraṇaṃ ettha puggale kuto labbhā,🔽kena kāraṇena laddhabbanti attho. Kuto lābhātipi pāṭho. Sacāhaṃ ettha kopaṃ kareyyaṃ,
analyzed: laddhum paraḥ nāma parassa attano citta ruciyā anattham karoti iti evam cintetvā āghātam  paṭivineti atha vā sacā aham kopam kareyyam tam kopa karaṇam ettha puggale kutas labbhā  kena kāraṇena laddhabbanti atthaḥ kutas sacā aham ettha kopam kareyyam
translated: Thinking thus, he dispels resentment. Or else, if I were to get angry, how could there be any means of getting at him in this person?🔽What means could I get at him by? This is the meaning. The reading kuto lābhā is also allowable. If I were to get angry with him,

original: tasmiṃ me kopakaraṇe kuto lābhā lābhā, nāma ke siyunti attho. Imasmiñca atthe tanti
analyzed: tasmin me kopa karaṇe kutas lābhāḥ lābhāḥ nāma ke siyunti imasmin ca atthe
translated: how could there be any means of getting at him in me? What would be the means? This is the meaning. And in this meaning the nipāta is merely a particle.

original: nipātamattameva hoti. Ekādasame anupubbanirodhāti anupaṭipāṭinirodhā. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.
analyzed: nipāta mattam eva hoti ekādasame anupubba nirodhā ati anu paṭipāṭi nirodhā sesam sabbattha uttāna attham eva ati
translated: In the eleventh, successive cessation: by successive cessation. The rest is plain in all sections.

original: Sattāvāsavaggo tatiyo.
analyzed: sattāvāsa vaggaḥ tatiyaḥ
translated: The third chapter on the Seven Stations is finished.

original: 4. Mahāvaggo
analyzed: mahāvaggo
translated: The Great Chapter

original: 1-2. Anupubbavihārasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: anupubba vihāra sutta ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Anupubbavihāra Sutta, etc.

original: 32-33. Catutthassa paṭhame anupubbavihārāti anupaṭipāṭiyā samāpajjitabbavihārā. Dutiye
analyzed: catutthassa paṭhame anupubba vihārā ati anupaṭipāṭiyā samāpajjitabba vihārā dutiye
translated: In the first of the fourth chapter, the successive abidings: the abidings to be entered into by successive order.

original: yattha kāmā nirujjhantīti yasmiṃ ṭhāne kāmā vūpasammanti. Nirodhetvāti appaṭivatte
analyzed: yattha kāmāḥ nirujjhanti iti yasmin ṭhāne kāmāḥ vūpasammanti nirodhetvā ati appaṭivatte
translated: Where they cease: in which place they are stilled. Having ceased: having made them cease without remainder.

original: katvā. Nicchātāti taṇhādiṭṭhicchātānaṃ abhāvena nicchātā. Nibbutāti attaparitāpanakilesānaṃ🔽abhāvena nibbutā. Tiṇṇāti kāmato tiṇṇā. Pāraṃgatāti kāme pāraṃ gatā. Tadaṅgenāti
analyzed: katvā nicchātā ati taṇhā diṭṭhi chātānam abhāvena nicchātā nibbutā ati atta paritāpana kilesānam  abhāvena nibbutā tiṇṇā ati kāmataḥ tiṇṇā pāraṃgatā ati kāme pāram gatā tad aṅgena ati
translated: Free from hunger: free from the hunger of craving and views. At peace: at peace through the absence of the defilements that torment oneself and others.

original: tena jhānaṅgena. Ettha kāmā nirujjhantīti ettha paṭhamajjhāne kāmā nirujjhanti. Te
analyzed: tena jhāna aṅgena ettha kāmāḥ nirujjhanti iti ettha paṭhamajjhāne kāmāḥ nirujjhanti te
translated: Crossed over: crossed over from sense desires. Reached the other shore: reached the other shore of sense desires. With that factor: with that jhāna factor. Here: in the first jhāna. Sense desires cease: sense desires cease here in the first jhāna.

original: cāti ye paṭhamajjhānaṃ samāpajjanti, te kāme nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharanti nāma.
analyzed: ca ati ye paṭhamajjhānam samāpajjanti te kāme nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharanti nāma

original: Pañjalikoti paggahitaañjaliko hutvā. Payirupāseyyāti upaṭṭhāpeyya. Iminā upāyena
analyzed: pañjalikaḥ ti paggahita añjalikaḥ hutvā payirupāseyya ati upaṭṭhāpeyya iminā upāyena
translated: With hands together in reverential salutation: with hands placed together in reverential salutation. Would attend upon: would wait upon. In this way

original: sabbattha attho veditabbo.
analyzed: sabbattha atthaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: the meaning should be understood in all cases.

original: 3. Nibbānasukhasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: nibbāna sukha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the “Discourse on the Happiness of Nibbāna” is finished.

original: 34. Tatiye udāyīti lāḷudāyitthero. Etadeva khvetthāti etadeva kho ettha. Kāmasahagatāti
analyzed: tatiye udāyī iti lāḷudāyi theraḥ etat eva khu ettha ati etat eva khalu ettha kāma sahagatā ati
translated: In the third , Udāyī is the elder Lāḷudāyī. This alone is the case here: this alone is the case here. Associated with sense desires: associated with sense desires.

original: kāmanissitā. Samudācarantīti manodvāre sañcaranti. Ābādhāyāti ābādhanāya pīḷanāya.
analyzed: kāma nissitā samudācarantī iti manodvāre sañcaranti ābādhāya ati ābādhanāya pīḍanāya
translated: They are based on sense desires. They are in operation: they are in operation at the mind door. To harm: to harm, to torment.

original: Pariyāyenāti kāraṇena. Evaṃ sabbavāresu attho veditabbo. Imasmiṃ sutte avedayitasukhaṃ nāma kathitaṃ.
analyzed: pariyāyena ati kāraṇena evam sabba vāresu atthaḥ veditabbaḥ imasmim sutte avedayitasukham nāma kathitam
translated: By means of a method: by means of a reason. The meaning should be understood in this way in all the passages. In this sutta the pleasure of the in-breaths and out-breaths is called “unfelt” .

original: 4. Gāvīupamāsuttavaṇṇanā🔽35. Catutthe pabbateyyāti pabbatacārinī. Na suppatiṭṭhitaṃ patiṭṭhāpetvāti yathā🔽suppatiṭṭhitā hoti, evaṃ na patiṭṭhāpetvā. Taṃ nimittanti taṃ paṭhamajjhānasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: catutthe pabbateyyā ati pabbata cārinī na suppatiṭṭhitam patiṭṭhāpetvā iti yathā  su patiṭṭhitā hoti evam na patiṭṭhāpetvā tam nimittam ti tam paṭhamajjhāna saṅkhātam
translated: The explanation of the Simile of the Cow

analyzed: nimittam na svādhiṭṭhitam adhiṭṭhāti iti yathā suṭṭhu adhiṭṭhitam hoti na evam adhiṭṭhāti  an abhihiṃsamānaḥ ti a pothentaḥ a viheṭhentaḥ mudu cittam hoti kammaññanti yathā vipassanā cittam
translated: In the fourth , “mountain-bred” : living on mountains. Not having established it well: not having established it as it should be established. That sign: the sign called the first jhāna. He does not resolve upon it well: he does not resolve upon it as it should be well resolved upon.

original: lokuttaramaggakkhaṇe mudu kammakkhamaṃ kammayoggaṃ hoti, evamassa abhiññāpādakaṃ
analyzed: lokuttara magga kkhaṇe mudu kamma kkhamam kamma yoggam hoti evam assa abhiññā pādakam
translated: Not hurting: not piercing, not tormenting. His mind becomes malleable: his mind becomes wieldy as it is at the moment of the supramundane path in insight.

original: catutthajjhānacittaṃ mudu hoti kammaññaṃ. Appamāṇo samādhīti catubrahmavihārasamādhipi
analyzed: catuttha jhāna cittam mudu hoti kammaññam appamāṇo samādhi iti catu brahmavihāra samādhi pi
translated: The fourth-jhāna consciousness is workable and wieldy.🔽Immeasurable concentration: the concentration of the four divine abodes and the concentration of the path and fruition are called immeasurable concentration. But here the concentration of the fourth jhāna is called immeasurable concentration because it is the basis for the immeasurable brahma-world and because it is the proximate cause for the attainment of the immeasurable divine abodes.

analyzed: magga phala samādhi pi appamāṇaḥ samādhi nāma idha pana appamāṇam appamāṇa ārammaṇanti  iminā pariyāyena su ppaguṇa samādhi appamāṇa samādhi iti daṭṭhabbo saḥ appamāṇena samādhinā
translated: That concentration is called immeasurable because it is the basis for the immeasurable brahma-world and because it is the proximate cause for the attainment of the immeasurable divine abodes.🔽That concentration is called immeasurable because it is the basis for the immeasurable brahma-world and because it is the proximate cause for the attainment of the immeasurable divine abodes.🔽That concentration is called immeasurable because it is the basis for the immeasurable brahma-world and because it is the proximate cause for the attainment of the immeasurable divine abodes.🔽That concentration is called immeasurable because it is the basis for the immeasurable brahma-world and because it is the proximate cause for the attainment of the immeasurable divine abodes.

analyzed: su bhāvitena ati imasmin ṭhāne ayam bhikkhu vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā arahattam pattaḥ idāni
translated: That concentration is called immeasurable because it is the basis for the immeasurable brahma-world and because it is the proximate cause for the attainment of the immeasurable divine abodes.🔽That concentration is called immeasurable because it is the basis for the immeasurable brahma-world and because it is the proximate cause for the attainment of the immeasurable divine abodes.

analyzed: khīṇāsavassa abhiññā paṭipāṭim dassento yassa yassa ca atiādim āha  jhāna sutta vaṇṇanā

original: 36. Pañcame āsavānaṃ khayanti arahattaṃ. Yadeva tattha hoti rūpagatanti tasmiṃ paṭhamajjhānakkhaṇe
analyzed: pañcame āsavānam arahattam yat eva tattha hoti tasmin paṭhama jhāna kkhaṇe
translated: That concentration is called immeasurable because it is the basis for the immeasurable brahma-world and because it is the proximate cause for the attainment of the immeasurable divine abodes.🔽That concentration is called immeasurable because it is the basis for the immeasurable brahma-world and because it is the proximate cause for the attainment of the immeasurable divine abodes.

original: vatthuvasena vā cittasamuṭṭhānikādivasena vā yaṃ rūpaṃ nāma pavattati. Vedanāgatādīni
analyzed: vatthu vasena vā citta samuṭṭhānika ādi vasena vā yam rūpam nāma pavattati vedanā gata ādīni
translated: That concentration is called immeasurable because it is the basis for the immeasurable brahma-world and because it is the proximate cause for the attainment of the immeasurable divine abodes.

translated: That concentration is called immeasurable because it is the basis for the immeasurable brahma-world and because it is the proximate cause for the attainment of the immeasurable divine abodes.🔽That concentration is called immeasurable because it is the basis

analyzed: aniccato tiādīsu hutvā abhāva ākārena aniccato paṭipīḷana ākārena dukkhato rujjana ākārena  rogataḥ antodussana ṭhena gaṇḍataḥ anupaviṭṭha ṭhena anukantana ṭṭhena ca sallataḥ
translated: As to “impermanent, etc.,” he sees with strong insight knowledge in the aspect of “non-existence after being” as “impermanent,” in the aspect of “oppression” as “painful,”🔽in the aspect of “afflicting” as “a disease,” in the sense of “internal corruption” as “a tumour,” and in the sense of “internal affliction” and “internal dissolution” as “a dart,”

original: palokato, assāmikaṭṭhena suññato, avasavattanaṭṭhena anattato. Samanupassatīti balavavipassanāpaññāya passati.🔽Tehi dhammehīti tehi pañcakkhandhadhammehi. Paṭivāpetīti nibbānavasena nivatteti.

translated: As to “he sees those ideas as they are”: he sees them with strong insight knowledge.🔽As to “he turns his mind away from those ideas”: he turns them away by means of extinction.

analyzed: amatāya dhātuyā ati nibbāna dhātuyā cittam upasaṃharati iti ñāṇena ānisaṃsam disvā otāreti 🔽santanti paccanīka santatāya santam paṇītam ti atappakam saḥ tattha ṭhitaḥ āsavānam
translated: As to “he turns his mind towards the deathless element”: he directs it by seeing the advantage with knowledge.🔽As to “peaceful”: peaceful because of the absence of opposition. As to “choice”: choice because of the absence of what is inferior. As to “secluded”: secluded because of the absence of what is mixed. As to “sweet”: sweet because of the absence of what is bitter. As to “rare”: rare because of the absence of what is common. As to “blissful”: blissful because of the absence of what is painful. As to “not a man’s portion”: not a man’s portion because of the absence of what belongs to a man. As to “not to be made” : not to be made because of the absence of what can be made. As to “not a tumour”: not a tumour because of the absence of what is a tumour. As to “not a misfortune”: not a misfortune because of the absence

original: khayaṃ pāpuṇātīti so tasmiṃ paṭhamajjhāne ṭhito taṃ balavavipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā arahattaṃ
analyzed: khayam pāpuṇāti iti so tasmin paṭhama jhāne ṭhitaḥ tam balava vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā arahattam
translated: He reaches exhaustion : he who is established in the first jhana increases that strong insight and reaches exhaustion of taints in arahatship.

original: pāpuṇāti. Aparo nayo – so tehi dhammehīti yasmā aniccatotiādīsu aniccato palokatoti
analyzed: pāpuṇāti aparaḥ nayaḥ saḥ tehi dhammehi iti yasmai aniccato tiādīsu aniccataḥ palokato ti
translated: Another method: He who sees those ideas thus : since the two terms “impermanent” and “subject to change” state the characteristic of impermanence,

original: dvīhi padehi aniccalakkhaṇaṃ kathitaṃ, dukkhatotiādīhi chahi dukkhalakkhaṇaṃ, parato,
analyzed: dvīhi padehi anicca lakkhaṇam kathitam dukkhato ti ādīhi chahi dukkha lakkhaṇam paratas
translated: and the six terms beginning with “painful” state the characteristic of pain, and the three terms beginning with “void” state the characteristic of not-self,

analyzed: suññataḥ anattataḥ ti tīhi anatta lakkhaṇam tasmā saḥ tehi evam ti lakkhaṇam āropetvā
translated: therefore he who sees those ideas thus, having stamped them with the three characteristics in this way,

original: diṭṭhehi antosamāpattiyaṃ pañcakkhandhadhammehi. Cittaṃ paṭivāpetīti cittaṃ paṭisaṃharati🔽moceti apaneti. Upasaṃharatīti vipassanācittaṃ tāva savanavasena thutivasena pariyattivasena
analyzed: diṭṭhehi antosamāpattiyam pañcakkhandha dhammehi cittam paṭivāpeti iti cittam paṭisaṃharati  moca iti apaneti upasaṃharati iti vipassanā cittam tāva savana vasena thuti vasena pariyatti vasena
translated: with the five aggregates as ideas that are seen in the attainment of the jhana, “he turns his mind back” : he withdraws his mind,🔽he releases it, he removes it.

original: paññattivasena ca santaṃ nibbānanti evaṃ asaṅkhatāya amatāya dhātuyā upasaṃharati.
analyzed: paññatti vasena ca santam nibbānanti evam asaṅkhatāya amatāya dhātuyā upasaṃharati
translated: He brings it to absorption : he brings the insight-understanding to absorption in the unformed, deathless element, Nibbāna, thus “ This is peace, this is exquisite” , by way of hearing, by way of praise, by way of the scriptures,🔽and by way of the theory .

original: Maggacittaṃ nibbānaṃ ārammaṇakaraṇavaseneva “etaṃ santaṃ etaṃ paṇīta”nti na evaṃ
analyzed: magga cittam nibbānam ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena iva etam santam etam paṇītam ti na evam
translated: He brings the path-understanding to absorption in Nibbāna only by making Nibbāna the object, not by way of “ This is peace, this is exquisite” ,

original: vadati. Iminā panākārena taṃ paṭivijjhanto tattha cittaṃ upasaṃharatīti attho.
analyzed: vadati iminā pana ākārena tam paṭivijjhantaḥ tattha cittam upasaṃharati iti attho
translated: He speaks. The meaning is that he directs his mind to that in that way by penetrating it.

original: So tattha ṭhitoti tassā tilakkhaṇārammaṇāya vipassanāya ṭhito. Āsavānaṃ khayaṃ pāpuṇātīti
analyzed: saḥ tattha ṭhitaḥ ti tassā tilakkhaṇa ārammaṇāya vipassanāya ṭhitaḥ āsavānam khayam pāpuṇāti iti
translated: Standing in that: standing in that insight whose object is the three characteristics. He reaches the destruction of the taints:

original: anukkamena cattāro magge bhāvetvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. Teneva dhammarāgenāti samathavipassanādhamme🔽chandarāgena. Dhammanandiyāti tasseva vevacanaṃ. Samathavipassanāsu hi sabbaso chandarāgaṃ
analyzed: anukkamena cattāraḥ magge bhāvetvā arahattam pāpuṇāti tena iva dhamma rāgena ati samatha vipassanā dhamme  chanda rāgena dhamma nandiyā ti tassa iva vevacanam samatha vipassanāsu hi sabbaso chanda rāgam
translated: he reaches Arahantship by gradually developing the four paths. With the passion for the Dhamma: with the passion for the Dhamma of serenity and insight.

original: pariyādātuṃ sakkonto arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti, asakkonto anāgāmī hoti.
analyzed: pariyādātum sakkontaḥ arahattam pāpuṇāti a sakkontaḥ anāgāmī hoti
translated: The Dhamma-joy: this is a synonym for the same thing. For one who is able to completely eliminate passion for serenity and insight reaches Arahantship, and one who is unable is a non-returner.

original: Tiṇapurisarūpake vāti tiṇapotthakarūpe vā. Dūre kaṇḍe pātetīti dūrepātī. Avirādhitaṃ
analyzed: tiṇa purisa rūpake vā ati tiṇa potthaka rūpe vā dūre kaṇḍe pāta iti iti dūrepātī avirādhitam
translated: In the form of grass and sticks: in the form of bundles of grass. He shoots far: he is a long-range shooter. He shoots without missing: he is an accurate shooter.

original: vijjhatīti akkhaṇavedhī. Yadeva tattha hoti vedanāgatanti idha rūpaṃ na gahitaṃ.
analyzed: vijjhati iti akkhaṇa vedhī yat eva tattha hoti vedanā gatam ti idha rūpam na gahitam
translated: Whatever there is there that is subject to feeling: materiality is not included here.

original: Kasmā? Samatikkantattā. Ayañhi heṭṭhā rūpāvacarajjhānaṃ samāpajjitvā rūpaṃ atikkamitvā
analyzed: kasmā samatikkanta ttā ayam hi heṭṭhā rūpāvacara jhānam samāpajjitvā rūpam atikkamitvā
translated: Why? Because he has transcended it. For having attained the fine-material jhānas below, he has transcended materiality.

original: arūpāvacarasamāpattiṃ samāpannoti samathavasenāpi anena rūpaṃ samatikkantaṃ, heṭṭhā
analyzed: arūpāvacara samāpattim samāpannoti samatha vasena api anena rūpam samatikkantam heṭṭhā
translated: He has surmounted form by attaining the formless attainments: he has surmounted form by serenity too, for he has surmounted the coarseness of the fine-material jhānas.

original: rūpaṃ sammasitvā taṃ atikkamma idāni arūpaṃ sammasatīti vipassanāvasenāpi anena rūpaṃ
analyzed: rūpam sammasitvā tam atikkamma idāni arūpam sammasati iti vipassanā vasena api anena rūpam
translated: He has surmounted form by insight too, for he has surmounted form by comprehending it as impermanent, etc., and he has now begun to comprehend formless states.

original: atikkantaṃ. Āruppe pana sabbasopi rūpaṃ natthīti taṃ sandhāyapi rūpaṃ na gahitaṃ.🔽Atha nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ kasmā na gahitanti? Sukhumattā. Tasmiñhi cattāropi arūpakkhandhā
analyzed: atikkantam āruppe pana sabbaso pi rūpam natthi iti tam sandhāya api rūpam na gahitam  atha nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam kasmā na gahitan ti sukhuma tā tasmin hi cattāraḥ api arūpa kkhandhāḥ
translated: But in the formless attainments there is no form at all, and that is why it is not said that he has surmounted form.🔽Why is the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception not mentioned? Because it is subtle. For the four mental aggregates in that jhāna are so subtle that they are hard to discern.🔽That is why it is said: “Bhikkhus, the penetration of the four noble truths is for the destruction of the taints.

original: sukhumā na sammasanūpagā. Tenevāha – “iti kho, bhikkhave, yāvatā saññāsamāpatti tāvatā🔽aññāpaṭivedho”ti. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yāvatā sacittakasamāpatti nāma atthi, tāvatā
analyzed: sukhumā na sammasana upagā tena iva āha iti kho bhikkhave yāvatā saññā samāpatti tāvatā  aññāpaṭivedho ti idam vuttam hoti yāvatā sacittaka samāpatti nāma atthi tāvatā
translated: And what is the penetration of the four noble truths?🔽It is the knowledge of the noble path and the knowledge of the noble fruition” .

original: oḷārike dhamme sammasato aññāpaṭivedho hoti, arahattaṃ sampajjati. Nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ
analyzed: oḷārike dhamme sammasato aññā paṭivedhaḥ hoti arahattam sampajjati nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam
translated: This is the meaning: the penetration of the four noble truths is for the destruction of the taints, for the realization of the fruit of arahantship, as far as there are mundane states with consciousness and associated with form.🔽But the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception is not called a “mundane state with consciousness and associated with form.”

original: pana sukhumattā saññāsamāpattīti na vuccati. Jhāyīheteti jhāyīhi jhānābhiratehi etāni.
analyzed: pana sukhuma tā saññā samāpatti iti na vuccati jhāyī hetā iti jhāyīhi jhāna abhiratehi etāni
translated: They are for meditators: they are for those who delight in jhāna.

original: Vuṭṭhahitvāti tato samāpattito vuṭṭhāya. Samakkhātabbānīti sammā akkhātabbāni, “santāni
analyzed: vuṭṭhahitvā ti tatas samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhāya samakkhātabbāni iti sammā akkhātabbāni santāni
translated: Having emerged: having emerged from that attainment. Should be rightly proclaimed: should be rightly proclaimed thus:

original: paṇītānī”ti evaṃ kevalaṃ ācikkhitabbāni thometabbāni vaṇṇetabbānīti.
analyzed: paṇītāni iti evam kevalam ācikkhitabbāni thometabbāni vaṇṇetabbāni iti
translated: Having emerged: having emerged from that attainment. Should be declared: should be rightly declared, should be pointed out, should be intimated, should be revealed, should be disclosed, should be made known, should be handed down, should be shown, should be taught, thus ‘peaceful’ and ‘excellent’ .

original: 6. Ānandasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ānanda sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . Commentary on the Sixth Chapter

original: 37. Chaṭṭhe sambādheti pañcakāmaguṇasambādhe. Okāsādhigamoti okāsassa adhigamo. Sattānaṃ
analyzed: chaṭṭhe sambādhe iti pañca kāmaguṇa sambādhe okāsa adhigamo ti okāsassa adhigamo sattānam
translated: In the sixth chapter, in the cramped quarters: in the cramped quarters of the five strands of sense pleasure.🔽The attainment of an opportunity: the attainment of an opportunity.

original: visuddhiyāti sattānaṃ visuddhiṃ pāpanatthāya. Samatikkamāyāti samatikkamanatthāya.
analyzed: visuddhiyā ati sattānam visuddhim pāpana tthāya samatikkamāya ati samatikkamana tthāya
translated: For the purification of beings: for the sake of bringing beings to purification.🔽For the overcoming of sorrow and lamentation: for the sake of overcoming sorrow and lamentation.🔽For the ending of pain and grief: for the sake of ending pain and grief.

original: Atthaṅgamāyāti atthaṃ gamanatthāya. Ñāyassa adhigamāyāti sahavipassanakassa maggassa
analyzed: atthaṅgamāya ati attham gamana tthāya ñāyassa adhigamāya ati saha vipassanakassa maggassa
translated: For the attainment of the true way: for the sake of attaining the way together with insight.

original: adhigamanatthāya. Nibbānassa sacchikiriyāyāti apaccayanibbānassa paccakkhakaraṇatthāya.🔽Tadeva nāma cakkhuṃ bhavissatīti taññeva pasādacakkhu asambhinnaṃ bhavissati. Te
analyzed: adhigamana tthāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya ati apaccaya nibbānassa paccakkha karaṇa tthāya  tat eva nāma cakkhum bhavissati iti tat na eva pasāda cakkhu a sambhinnam bhavissati te
translated: For the realization of Nibbāna: for the sake of realizing Nibbāna without remainder.🔽That same eye will be: that very eye of sensitive matter will be intact.

original: rūpāti tadeva rūpārammaṇaṃ āpāthaṃ āgamissati. Tañcāyatanaṃ no paṭisaṃvedissatīti
analyzed: rūpa ati tat eva rūpa ārammaṇam āpātham āgamissati tat ca āyatanam no paṭisaṃvedissati iti
translated: Those forms: that very object of eye-consciousness will come into focus. But he will not experience that base:

original: tañca rūpāyatanaṃ na jānissati. Sesesupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: tat ca rūpa āyatanam na jānissati sesesu pi esa iva nayo
translated: and he will not know the visible-data base. The same method applies in the other cases.🔽Udāyī: the Elder Kāḷudāyī.

original: Udāyīti kāḷudāyitthero. Saññīmeva nu khoti sacittakoyeva nu kho. Makāro padasandhimattaṃ.
analyzed: udāyī iti kāḷudāyi thero saññīm eva nu kho ti nu kho makāro
translated: Possessing only perception: possessing only consciousness. The syllable “ka” is a mere filler.🔽What kind of perception? Having become possessed of what kind of perception?

original: Kiṃsaññīti katarasaññāya saññī hutvā. Sabbaso rūpasaññānanti idaṃ kasmā gaṇhi, kiṃ
analyzed: kiṃsaññī iti katara saññāya saññī hutvā sabbaso rūpa saññānan ti idam kasmai gaṇhi kim
translated: Why did he take only “perceptions of visible objects” ?🔽Because there is the experiencing of visible data, etc., in one who possesses the first jhāna, etc.

original: paṭhamajjhānādisamaṅgino rūpādipaṭisaṃvedanā hotīti? Na hoti, yāva pana kasiṇarūpaṃ🔽ārammaṇaṃ hoti, tāva rūpaṃ samatikkantaṃ nāma na hoti. Asamatikkantattā paccayo bhavituṃ
analyzed: paṭhamajjhāna ādi samaṅgino rūpa ādi paṭisaṃvedanā hoti iti na hoti yāva pana kasiṇa rūpam  ārammaṇam hoti tāva rūpam samatikkantam nāma na hoti a samatikkanta ttā paccayaḥ bhavitum
translated: But as long as the kasiṇa visible data is the object,🔽it is not called “transcended” .🔽As long as it is not transcended, it can be a condition.

original: sakkhissati. Samatikkantattā pana taṃ natthi nāma hoti, natthitāya paccayo bhavituṃ
analyzed: sakkhissati samatikkanta ttā pana tat natthi nāma hoti natthi tāya paccayaḥ bhavitum
translated: But when it is transcended, it is as if it were non-existent, and so it cannot be a condition.

original: na sakkotīti dassetuṃ idameva gaṇhi.🔽Jaṭilavāsikāti jaṭilanagaravāsinī. Na cābhinatotiādīsu rāgavasena na abhinato, dosavasena
analyzed: na sakkoti iti dassetum idam eva gaṇhi  jaṭila vāsikā ati jaṭila nagara vāsinī na ca abhinataḥ iti ādīsu rāga vasena na dosa vasena
translated: In order to show this, he took only “perceptions of visible objects.”🔽Jaṭilavāsikā: a resident of Jaṭila town.🔽Not bent on: not bent on lust.🔽Not turned away: not turned away from hate.

original: na apanato. Sasaṅkhārena sappayogena kilese niggaṇhitvā vāretvā ṭhito, kilesānaṃ
analyzed: na apanataḥ sa saṅkhārena sa payogena kilese niggaṇhitvā vāretvā ṭhitaḥ kilesānaṃ
translated: Standing with applied thought and sustained thought: standing after having restrained and checked defilements with applied thought and sustained thought.

original: pana chinnante uppannoti na sasaṅkhāraniggayhavāritagato. Vimuttattā ṭhitoti kilesehi🔽vimuttattāyeva ṭhito. Ṭhitattā santusitoti ṭhitattāyeva santuṭṭho nāma jāto. Santusitattā
analyzed: pana chinna ante uppannaḥ ti na sa saṅkhāra niggayha vārita gataḥ vimutta ttā ṭhitaḥ ti kilesehi  vimutta ttāya iva ṭhitaḥ ṭhitattā santusitaḥ iti ṭhitattāya iva santuṭṭhaḥ nāma jātaḥ santusitattā
translated: but when it is cut off, it is not subject to being checked by the exertion of a resolve. ‘He stands’: he stands by being liberated from defilements. ‘He is satisfied’: he is satisfied by standing.

original: no paritassatīti santuṭṭhattāyeva paritāsaṃ nāpajjati. Ayaṃ, bhante ānanda, samādhi🔽kiṃ phaloti iminā ayaṃ therī tālaphalaññeva gahetvā “idaṃ phalaṃ kiṃ phalaṃ nāmā”ti🔽pucchamānā viya arahattaphalasamādhiṃ gahetvā “ayaṃ, bhante ānanda, samādhi kiṃ phalo🔽vutto bhagavatā”ti pucchati. Aññāphalo vuttoti aññā vuccati arahattaṃ, arahattaphalasamādhi🔽nāmeso vutto bhagavatāti attho. Evaṃsaññīpīti imāya arahattaphalasaññāya saññīpi
analyzed: no paritassati iti santuṭṭha ttāya iva paritāsam na āpajjati ayam bhante ānanda samādhi  kim iminā ayam therī gahetvā idam phalam kim phalam nāma ati  pucchamānā viya arahatta phala samādhim gahetvā ayam bhante ānanda kim  vuttaḥ bhagavatā ati pucchati aññā phalaḥ vuttaḥ ti aññā vuccati arahattam arahatta phala samādhi  nāma iso vuttaḥ bhagavatā ti attho evaṃsaññīpī iti imāya arahatta phala saññāya saññīpi
translated: But when it is cut off, it is not subject to being checked by the exertion of a resolution. ‘He is steadied because he is liberated’: he is steadied just because he is liberated from defilements. ‘He is satisfied because he is steadied’: he is called satisfied just because he is steadied. ‘He is not agitated because he is satisfied’: he does not fall into agitation just because he is satisfied. ‘This concentration, venerable Ānanda,

original: tadāyatanaṃ no paṭisaṃvedetīti evaṃ imasmiṃ sutte arahattaphalasamādhi kathitoti.
analyzed: tat āyatanam no paṭisaṃvedeti iti evam imasmin sutte arahatta phala samādhi kathitā ti
translated: what is its fruit, what is its reward?’ In this way, taking the concentration of the Arahant path as the ‘fruit,’ as it were, the Elder Nun asks, ‘This concentration, venerable Ānanda, what is its fruit, what is its reward?’ as if taking a palm fruit and asking, ‘What is the fruit of this fruit called?’ ‘It is called the fruit of clear vision’: clear vision is called Arahantship. The meaning is that this concentration of the Arahant path is called the fruit of clear vision. ‘He is possessed of such a perception’: he is possessed of the perception of the Arahant path. ‘He does not experience that base’: thus in this sutta the concentration of the Arahant path is taught.

original: 7. Lokāyatikasuttavaṇṇanā🔽38. Sattame lokāyatikāti lokāyatavādakā. Satatanti sadā. Samitanti nirantaraṃ. Tiṭṭhatetanti🔽tiṭṭhatu etaṃ, mā etaṃ paṭṭhapetha, ko vo etena attho. Dhammaṃ vo brāhmaṇā desessāmīti
analyzed: lokāyatika sutta vaṇṇanā  sattame lokāyatikā ati lokāyata vādakā sadā samitanti nirantaram  tiṭṭhatu etam mā etam paṭṭhapetha kaḥ vaḥ etena atthaḥ dhammam vaḥ brāhmaṇāḥ desessāmi iti
translated: 7. The Discussion of the Discourse on the Materialists

original: ahaṃ vo catusaccadhammaṃ desessāmi.🔽Daḷhadhammoti daḷhadhanuṃ gahetvā ṭhito. Dhanuggahoti issāso. Daḷhadhanu nāma dvisahassathāmaṃ🔽vuccati. Dvisahassathāmaṃ nāma yassa āropitassa jiyābaddho lohasīsādīnaṃ bhāro daṇḍe🔽gahetvā yāva kaṇḍappamāṇā ukkhittassa pathavito muccati. Sikkhitoti dasa dvādasa🔽vassāni ācariyakule uggahitasippo. Katahatthoti eko sippameva uggaṇhāti, katahattho
analyzed: aham vaḥ catu sacca dhammam desessāmi  daḷha dhammaḥ ti daḷha dhanum gahetvā ṭhitaḥ dhanuggahaḥ ti issāsaḥ daḷha dhanu nāma dvi sahassa thāmam  vuccati dvi sahassa thāmam nāma yassa āropitassa jiyā baddhaḥ loha sīsa ādīnam bhāraḥ daṇḍe  gahetvā yāva kaṇḍappamāṇā ukkhittassa pathavitaḥ muccati sikkhito ti dasa dvādasa  vassāni ācariya kule uggahita sippo kata hatthaḥ ti ekaḥ sippam eva uggaṇhāti kata hatthaḥ
translated: In the seventh , “materialists” are those who hold the doctrine of materialism. “Always” means constantly. “Without a break” means uninterruptedly. “Let that be” means “Let that be, don’t bother with that, what is the use of that to you?” “I will teach you the Dhamma, brahmins” means I will teach you the Dhamma of the Four Noble Truths.

original: na hoti ayaṃ pana katahattho ciṇṇavasibhāvo. Katūpāsanoti rājakulādīsu dassitasippo.
analyzed: na hoti ayam pana kata hatthaḥ ciṇṇa vasi bhāvo kata upāsanaḥ ti rāja kula ādīsu dassita sippo
translated: “Firm in his bow” means standing with a firm bow. “A master archer” means a skilled archer. A “firm bow” is said to be one that can shoot an arrow two thousand fathoms. A “two-thousand-fathom bow” is one that, when drawn to the ear, can shoot an arrow from the ground to the height of a man’s knee. “Skilled” means one who has learned the craft for ten or twelve years in the teacher’s house. “One who has had practice” means one who has learned only the craft and has not had practice. “One who has had practice” means one who has had practice and has mastered the craft. “One who has shown his skill” means one who has shown his skill in the royal house and so on.

original: Lahukena asanenāti anto susiraṃ katvā tūlādīhi pūretvā katalakkhaparikammena sallahukakaṇḍena.
analyzed: lahukena asanena ati antar su siram katvā tūla ādīhi pūretvā kata lakkha parikammena sat lahuka kaṇḍena
translated: With a light weapon: having made a hollow inside, he filled it with cotton wool, etc., and made it light by a light covering.

original: Evaṃ katañhi ekausabhagāmī dve usabhānipi gacchati…pe… aṭṭhusabhagāmī soḷasa usabhānipi
analyzed: evam katañhi eka ausabha gāmī dve usabhānipi gacchatipe aṭṭhusabha gāmī soḷasaḥ usabhānipi
translated: For when it is made thus, it goes two leagues with one pull of the bellows, and so on up to sixteen leagues with eight pulls of the bellows.

original: gacchati. Appakasirenāti niddukkhena. Atipāteyyāti atikkameyya. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti
analyzed: gacchati appa kasirena ati niddukkhena atipāteyya ati atikkameyya idam vuttam hoti
translated: With little pain: with little discomfort. He would surpass: he would go beyond. What is meant is this:

original: – yathā so dhanuggaho taṃ vidatthicaturaṅgulaṃ chāyaṃ sīghameva atikkāmeti, evaṃ
analyzed: yathā saḥ dhanuggahaḥ tam vidatthi catur aṅgulam chāyam sīgham eva atikkāmeti evam
translated: just as that archer would quickly go beyond the shadow of the four-league arrow,

original: sakalacakkavāḷaṃ sīghaṃ sīghaṃ atikkamanasamatthena javena samannāgato. Sandhāvanikāyāti
analyzed: sakala cakkavāḷam sīgham sīgham atikkamana samatthena javena samannāgataḥ sandhāvanikāya ati
translated: so he would be endowed with such speed that he could quickly go beyond the whole world system.🔽On foot: by running on foot. They say thus:

original: padasā dhāvanena. Evamāhaṃsūti evaṃ vadanti.
analyzed: padasā dhāvanena evam āhaṃsu iti evam vadanti
translated: they speak thus.

original: 8. Devāsurasaṅgāmasuttavaṇṇanā🔽39. Aṭṭhame samupabyūḷho ahosīti paccupaṭṭhito ahosi. Saṅgāmeyyāmāti saṅgāmaṃ kareyyāma
analyzed: devāsurasaṅgāma sutta vaṇṇanā  aṭṭhame samupabyūḷhaḥ ahosi iti paccupaṭṭhitaḥ ahosi saṅgāmeyyāma ati saṅgāmam kareyyāma
translated: The Discussion of the Sutta on the Battle Between the Gods and Asuras

original: yujjheyyāma. Apayiṃsuyevāti palāyiṃsuyeva. Uttarenābhimukhāti uttarāmukhā hutvā.
analyzed: yujjheyyāma apayiṃsuyā iva ati palāyiṃsuyā iva uttarena abhimukhā ati uttarā mukhā hutvā
translated: Was ready: was present. We would fight: we would make war. They ran away: they fled. With their faces to the north: having made the north the front.

original: Abhiyante vāti anubandhantiyeva. Bhīruttānagatenāti bhīruttānaṃ bhayanivāraṇaṃ patiṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: abhiyante vā ati anubandhantiyā iva bhīru uttāna gatena ati bhīru uttānam bhaya nivāraṇam patiṭṭhānam
translated: They pursue them, they follow them. With a gait that inspires fear: with a gait that inspires fear by being a refuge for the frightened.

original: gatena. Akaraṇīyāti yuddhena kiñci akattabbā. Kasmā pana nesaṃ saṅgāmo hotīti? Asurā🔽hi pubbe tāvatiṃsavāsino, te cittapāṭaliyā pupphanakāle dibbapāricchattakapupphaṃ🔽anussaranti. Tato uppannakodhā “gaṇhatha deve”ti sammukhasammukhaṭṭhāneneva sineruṃ
analyzed: gatena a karaṇīyā ati yuddhena kiñci a kattabbā kasmā pana nesam saṅgāmaḥ hoti iti asurāḥ  hi pubbe tāvatiṃsa vāsinaḥ te cittapāṭaliyā pupphana kāle dibba pāricchattaka puppham  anussaranti tatas uppanna kodhāḥ gaṇhatha deva iti sammukha sammukha ṭṭhānena iva sinerum
translated: Unassailable: incapable of being attacked by war. But why do they fight?🔽For formerly the asuras lived in the Tāvatiṃsa realm. At the time of the flowering of the divine coral-tree, they remember the divine coral-tree flowers,

analyzed: yaḥ jhānam abujjhi iti yaḥ jhānam abujjhi ekībhāva vasena paṭilīnaḥ ca iva  uttama ṭṭhena ca nisabhaḥ muni iti buddha muni pariyāyena ati ekena kāraṇena kāma sambādhassa  hi abhāva mattena iva paṭhamajjhānam okāsādhigamaḥ nāma na sabbathā sabbam tatra apatthi  sambādho ti tasmim pi paṭhamajjhāne sambādho paṭipīḍanam
translated: ‘Who has awakened to the jhana’: who has awakened to the jhana. ‘The bull that has gone to the end of the round’: the bull that has gone to the end of the round by means of unification.🔽‘Sage’: Buddha-sage. ‘By one means’: by one reason. For it is only because of the absence of the hindrance of sensual desire that the first jhana is called ‘attainment of a station of mindfulness’; not in every way in every respect. There is still a hindrance in that first jhana,🔽there is still oppression there. ‘There is still a hindrance there’: there is still a hindrance in that first jhana, there is still oppression there. ‘There is still’:🔽

original: pāṭho. Kiñca tattha sambādhoti tasmiṃ pana jhāne kiṃ sambādho nāma. Ayamettha sambādhoti🔽ayaṃ vitakkavicārānaṃ aniruddhabhāvo sambādho saṃpīḷā nāma. Iminā upāyena sabbavāresu🔽attho veditabbo. Nippariyāyenāti na ekena kāraṇena, atha kho āsavakkhayo nāma sabbasambādhānaṃ🔽pahīnattā sabbena sabbaṃ okāsādhigamo nāmāti.
analyzed: kiñca tattha sambādho ti tasmim pana jhāne kim sambādhaḥ nāma ayam ettha sambādho ti  ayam vitakka vicārānam a niruddha bhāvaḥ sambādhaḥ saṃpīḷā nāma iminā upāyena sabba vāresu  atthaḥ veditabbaḥ nippariyāyena ati na ekena kāraṇena atha kho āsava kkhayaḥ nāma sabba sambādhānam  pahīna ttā sabbena sabbam okāsa adhigamaḥ nāma ati
translated: “Who has awakened to the jhāna”: who has awakened to the jhāna. “The bull that has entered the fold”: he is both entered and a bull in the sense of being supreme. “The sage”: the Buddha-sage. “By one means”: by one reason. For the first jhāna is called “attainment of a station of freedom” only in the sense of absence of the hindrance of lust, not in all ways in every respect. “There is a station there too”: in that first jhāna there is a station, a pressure, too. “There is a pressure there too” is also a reading. “And what is the pressure there? “: and what is the pressure called in that jhāna? “This is the pressure there”: this non-stopping of applied and sustained thought is the pressure, the oppression, there. The meaning should be understood in this way in all instances. “By every means”: not by one reason, but rather the destruction of cankers is called “attainment of a station” in every way in every respect because of the abandoning of all pressures.
