analyzed: yathā hi udakam paviṭṭhassa sabba disāsu udakam eva hoti na aññam evam eva pathavī kasiṇam
translated: For just as when a man has gone into the water the water is not anything else in any direction for him, so too,

original: pathavīkasiṇameva hoti. Natthi tassa aññakasiṇasambhedoti. Eseva nayo sabbattha.
analyzed: pathavī kasiṇam eva hoti natthi tassa añña kasiṇa sambhedo ti esa iva nayo sabbattha
translated: it is only the earth kasiṇa. There is no intermixture of any other kasiṇa. So too in all the rest.

original: Appamāṇanti idaṃ tassa tassa pharaṇaappamāṇavasena vuttaṃ. Tañhi cetasā pharanto
analyzed: appamāṇam ti idam tassa tassa pharaṇa appamāṇa vasena vuttam tat hi cetasā pharantaḥ
translated: Measureless: this is said of the measurelessness of the pervasion of each one. For when he pervades

original: sakalameva pharati, “ayamassa ādi, idaṃ majjha”nti pamāṇaṃ na gaṇhāti. Viññāṇakasiṇanti🔽cettha kasiṇugghāṭimākāse pavattaviññāṇaṃ. Tattha kasiṇavasena kasiṇugghāṭimākāse,
analyzed: sakalam eva pharati ayam assa ādi idam majjhanti pamāṇam na gaṇhāti viññāṇa kasiṇanti  ca ittha kasiṇugghāṭim ākāse pavatta viññāṇam tattha kasiṇa vasena kasiṇugghāṭim ākāse
translated: with consciousness, he pervades the whole of it. He does not take measure of it thus, “This is its beginning, this is its middle, this is its end.” The consciousness kasiṇa is

original: kasiṇugghāṭimākāsavasena tattha pavattaviññāṇe uddhaṃadhotiriyatā veditabbā. Ayamettha🔽saṅkhepo, kammaṭṭhānabhāvanānayena panetāni pathavīkasiṇādīni vitthārato visuddhimagge vuttāneva.
analyzed: tattha pavatta viññāṇe uddhaṃ adhotiriya tā veditabbā ayam ettha  saṅkhepaḥ kammaṭṭhāna bhāvanā nayena pana itāni pathavī kasiṇa ādīni vitthārataḥ visuddhi magge vuttāneva
translated: the consciousness occurring in the space delimited by the kasiṇa. Herein, the measure of the space delimited by the kasiṇa should be understood as the measure of the consciousness occurring there.

original: 6. Kāḷīsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: kāḷī sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: This is the brief account. But these earth kasiṇas, etc., should be understood in detail according to the method of development given in the Description of the Meditations.

original: 26. Chaṭṭhe kumāripañhesūti kumārīnaṃ māradhītānaṃ pucchāsu. Atthassa pattiṃ hadayassa
analyzed: chaṭṭhe kumāri pañhesu iti kumārīnam māra dhītānam pucchāsu atthassa pattim hadayassa
translated: The commentary on the verse beginning, “The girl asked the question” is finished.

original: santinti dvīhipi padehi arahattameva kathitaṃ. Senanti rāgādikilesasenaṃ. Piyasātarūpanti
analyzed: padehi arahattam eva kathitam senanti rāga ādi kilesa senam
translated: “Tranquil” is said by both terms to be Arahantship. “Army” is the army of defilements such as lust. “Dear and pleasing”

original: piyajātikesu ca sātajātikesu ca vatthūsu uppajjanato evaṃladdhanāmaṃ. Ekohaṃ jhāyaṃ
analyzed: piya jātikesu ca sāta jātikesu ca vatthūsu uppajjanataḥ evaṃladdha nāmam eka ūham jhāyam
translated: “Tranquil” is said by both terms to be Arahantship. “Army” is the army of defilements. “Dear and pleasing” is so-called because it arises in regard to dear and pleasing kinds of objects. “I, alone,🔽meditating”

original: sukhamanubodhinti evaṃ kilesasenaṃ jinitvā ahaṃ ekakova jhāyanto sukhaṃ anubujjhiṃ
analyzed: evam kilesa senam jinitvā aham ekakaḥ iva jhāyantaḥ sukham anubujjhim
translated: I, alone, having conquered the army of defilements, experienced bliss,

original: sacchiakāsiṃ. Sakkhinti sakkhibhāvappattaṃ dhammasakkhiṃ. Na sampajjati kenaci meti
analyzed: sacchiakāsim sakkhinti sakkhibhāva ppattam dhamma sakkhim na sampajjati kenacid mā iti
translated: I realized it. “Witness” is one who has attained the state of a witness, a witness of the Dhamma. “No one can be my friend”

original: mayhaṃ kenaci saddhiṃ mittadhammo nāma natthi. Pathavīkasiṇasamāpattiparamā kho,
analyzed: mayham kenacid saddhim mitta dhammo nāma natthi pathavī kasiṇa samāpatti paramā kho
translated: means that there is no friendship with anyone on my part. “The earth kasiṇa attainment is the highest good”

original: bhagini, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā atthoti abhinibbattesunti pathavīkasiṇasamāpattiparamo🔽uttamo atthoti gahetvā abhinibbattesuṃ. Yāvatā kho, bhagini, pathavīkasiṇasamāpattiparamatāti
analyzed: bhagini eke samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ atthoti abhinibbattesunti pathavī kasiṇa samāpatti paramaḥ  uttamaḥ atthaḥ ti gahetvā abhinibbattesum yāvatā kho bhagini pathavī kasiṇa samāpatti parama tā ati
translated: means that some ascetics and brahmins, taking the earth kasiṇa attainment to be the highest,🔽the ultimate, have attained it. “As far as the earth kasiṇa attainment goes”🔽means as far as the highest limit of the earth kasiṇa attainment. “The Blessed One has directly known that”

original: yattakā pathavīkasiṇasamāpattiyā uttamakoṭi. Tadabhiññāsi bhagavāti taṃ bhagavā abhiññāpaññāya
analyzed: yattakā pathavī kasiṇa samāpattiyāḥ uttama koṭi tat abhiññāsi bhagavā ti tam bhagavā abhiññā paññāya
translated: means that the Blessed One has directly known that by means of the knowledge of omniscience.

original: abhiññāsi. Assādamaddasāti samudayasaccaṃ addasa. Ādīnavamaddasāti dukkhasaccaṃ addasa.
analyzed: abhiññāsi assādam addasa ati samudaya saccam addasa ādīnavam addasa ati dukkha saccam addasa
translated: He saw the path. He saw the path and the wrong path.

original: Nissaraṇamaddasāti nirodhasaccaṃ addasa. Maggāmaggañāṇadassanamaddasāti maggasaccaṃ🔽addasa. Atthassa pattīti etesaṃ catunnaṃ saccānaṃ diṭṭhattā arahattasaṅkhātassa atthassa
analyzed: nissaraṇam addasa ati nirodha saccam addasa magga amagga ñāṇa dassanam addasa ati magga saccam  addasa atthassa pattī iti etesam catunnam saccānam diṭṭhattā arahatta saṅkhātassa atthassa
translated: He attained the goal. He attained the goal of arahatship, which is called the “attainment of the purpose,”

original: patti, sabbadarathapariḷāhavūpasantatāya hadayassa santīti.
analyzed: patti sabbada ratha pariḷāha vūpasanta tāya hadayassa santi iti
translated: because of the seeing of the four truths. His heart was tranquil because of the complete cessation of all his desires and fevers.

original: 7. Paṭhamamahāpañhasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the First Great Chapter

original: 27. Sattame abhijānāthāti abhijānitvā paccakkhaṃ katvā viharatha. Abhiññāyāti abhijānitvā.
analyzed: sattame abhijānātha ati abhijānitvā paccakkham katvā viharatha abhiññāya ati abhijānitvā
translated: In the seventh chapter, “You should live having known and seen” means that you should live having known and seen them with your own eyes. “Having directly known” means having known.

original: Idhāti imāya. Dhammadesanāya vā dhammadesananti yadidaṃ samaṇassa gotamassa dhammadesanāya
analyzed: idha ati imāya dhamma desanāya vā dhamma desanam ti yat idam samaṇassa gotamassa dhamma desanāya
translated: “Here” means in this teaching of the Dhamma. “If there is any difference between our teaching of the Dhamma and the teaching of the Dhamma of the ascetic Gotama”

original: saddhiṃ amhākaṃ dhammadesanaṃ, amhākaṃ vā dhammadesanāya saddhiṃ samaṇassa gotamassa
analyzed: saddhim amhākam dhamma desanam amhākam vā dhamma desanāya saddhim samaṇassa gotamassa
translated: means that if there is any difference between our teaching of the Dhamma and the teaching of the Dhamma of the ascetic Gotama,🔽then “what is it?”

original: dhammadesanaṃ ārabbha nānākaraṇaṃ vuccetha, taṃ kiṃ nāmāti vadanti. Dutiyapadepi
analyzed: dhamma desanam ārabbha nānākaraṇam vuccetha tam kim nāma ati vadanti dutiya pade pi
translated: In the second passage, too,

original: eseva nayo. Iti te majjhe bhinnasuvaṇṇaṃ viya sāsanena saddhiṃ attano laddhiṃ vacanamattena
analyzed: iti te majjhe bhinna suvaṇṇam viya sāsanena saddhim laddhim vacana mattena
translated: So too, they, like the gold in the middle, established their own doctrine together with the Dispensation by mere words, sweet to the ear,

original: samadhuraṃ ṭhapayiṃsu. Neva abhinandiṃsūti “evameta”nti na sampaṭicchiṃsu. Nappaṭikkosiṃsūti🔽“na idaṃ eva”nti nappaṭisedhesuṃ. Kasmā? Te kira “titthiyā nāma andhasadisā jānitvā🔽vā ajānitvā vā katheyyu”nti nābhinandiṃsu.
analyzed: sa madhuram ṭhapayiṃsu na iva abhinandiṃsu iti evam etat ti na sampaṭicchiṃsu na paṭikkosiṃsu iti  na idam evanti na paṭisedhesum kasmā te kira titthiyāḥ nāma andha sadisāḥ jānitvā  vā a jānitvā vā na abhinandiṃsu
translated: and did not approve. They did not agree, saying: “So it is.” They did not contradict.🔽They did not oppose, saying: “It is not so.” Why? They did not approve, thinking: “They may speak, knowing or not knowing that the sectarians are like the blind.

original: Na sampāyissantīti sampādetvā kathetuṃ na sakkhissanti. Uttari ca vighātanti asampādanato
analyzed: na sampāyissanti iti sampādetvā kathetum na sakkhissanti uttari ca a sampādanato
translated: They will not be able to answer.” They will not be able to answer after having answered.

original: uttarimpi dukkhaṃ āpajjissanti. Sampādetvā kathetuṃ asakkontānañhi dukkhaṃ uppajjati.
analyzed: uttarim pi dukkham āpajjissanti sampādetvā kathetum a sakkontānam hi dukkham uppajjati
translated: And they will come to greater misfortune. For those who are unable to answer after having answered, misfortune arises.

original: Yathā taṃ, bhikkhave, avisayasminti ettha ca tanti nipātamattaṃ. Yathāti kāraṇavacanaṃ,
analyzed: yathā tam bhikkhave avisayasmin ti ettha ca tat ti nipāta mattam yathā iti kāraṇavacanam
translated: And here the word “yathā” is merely a particle. “Yathā” is a word for reason.

original: yasmā avisaye pañhaṃ pucchitā hontīti attho. Ito vā pana sutvāti ito vā pana mama
analyzed: yasmai avisaye pañham pucchitāḥ honti iti attho itas vā pana sutvā ati itas vā pana mama
translated: The meaning is: “because they are asking a question outside their field of knowledge.” Or, “having heard this from me,”

original: sāsanato sutvā. Itoti tathāgatatopi tathāgatasāvakatopi. Ārādheyyāti paritoseyya,
analyzed: sāsanataḥ sutvā itoti tathāgatataḥ pi tathāgata sāvakataḥ pi ārādheyya ati paritoseyya
translated: and he heard it from the Dispensation. ‘From here’: from a Perfect One or from a disciple of a Perfect One. ‘Should serve’: should serve by honouring,

original: aññathā ārādhanaṃ nāma natthīti dasseti.
analyzed: aññathā ārādhanam nāma natthi iti dasseti
translated: showing that there is no other kind of service.

original: Ekadhammeti ekasmiṃ dhamme. Iminā uddeso dassito. Parato katamasmiṃ ekadhammeti iminā
analyzed: eka dhamme iti ekasmin dhamme iminā uddesaḥ dassito paratas katamasmin eka dhamme iti iminā
translated: ‘In one idea’: in one idea. This is the indication of the recitation. The question is indicated by the words ‘Which is the one idea? ‘

original: pañho dassito. Sabbe sattā āhāraṭṭhitikāti idaṃ panettha veyyākaraṇaṃ. Sesesupi eseva
analyzed: pañhaḥ dassito sabbe sattāḥ āhāra ṭṭhitikā ti idam pana ittha veyyākaraṇam sesesu pi esā eva
translated: The answer is ‘All beings subsist by nutriment.’ The same method applies to the rest.

original: nayo. Sammā nibbindamānotiādīsu pana sammā hetunā nayena nibbidānupassanāya nibbindanto
analyzed: nayo sammā nibbindamāno ti ādīsu pana sammā hetunā nayena nibbida anupassanāya nibbindanto
translated: But in the case of the words ‘when he is fully dispassionate’ and so on, he who is fully dispassionate by means of the contemplation of dispassion with its cause, with its reason,

original: ukkaṇṭhanto, virāgānupassanāya virajjanto, paṭisaṅkhānupassanāya muccanassa upāyaṃ
analyzed: ukkaṇṭhantaḥ virāga anupassanāya virajjantaḥ paṭisaṅkhā anupassanāya muccanassa upāyam
translated: is one who is disgusted, who is repelled. He who is fading away by means of the contemplation of fading away is one who is fading away. He who is liberated by means of the contemplation of reflexion, having made the means to the vanishing of vanity,

original: katvā vimuccamāno, adhimokkhavasena vā vimuccamāno sanniṭṭhānaṃ kurumānoti attho.
analyzed: katvā vimuccamānaḥ adhimokkha vasena vā vimuccamānaḥ sanniṭṭhānam kurumānaḥ iti attho
translated: is one who is liberated. The meaning is that he makes an end by means of resolution.

original: Udayabbayehi paricchinditvā pubbantāparantadassanena sammā pariyantadassāvī. Sammadatthaṃ
analyzed: udaya bbayehi paricchinditvā pubbanta aparanta dassanena sammā pariyanta dassāvī sammad attham
translated: He who sees rightly the end by means of the contemplation of rise and subsidence that defines the past and future by means of the rise and subsidence of formations is one who sees rightly the end.

original: abhisameccāti sammā sabhāgatthaṃ ñāṇena abhisamāgantvā. Dukkhassantakaro hotīti sakalavaṭṭadukkhassa
analyzed: abhisamecca ati sammā sa bhāga ttham ñāṇena abhisamāgantvā dukkhassa anta karaḥ hoti iti sakala vaṭṭa dukkhassa
translated: He has penetrated to the end of suffering: he has penetrated to the end of the suffering of the entire round of rebirths.

original: pariyantaṃ parivaṭumaṃ karo hoti.🔽Sabbe sattāti kāmabhavādīsu ekavokārabhavādīsu ca sabbabhavesu sabbe sattā. Āhāraṭṭhitikāti
analyzed: pariyantam parivaṭumam karaḥ hoti  sabbe sattā ati kāma bhava ādīsu ekavokāra bhava ādīsu ca sabba bhavesu sabbe sattā āhāra ṭṭhitikā ti
translated: “He has penetrated” means that he has penetrated by means of the knowledge of the state of being in conformity with the truth. “He has made an end of suffering” means that he has made an end of the suffering of the entire round of rebirths.

original: āhārato ṭhiti etesanti āhāraṭṭhitikā. Iti sabbasattānampi ṭhitihetu āhāro nāma eko🔽dhammo, tasmiṃ ekadhamme. Nanu ca evaṃ sante yaṃ vuttaṃ – “asaññasattā devā ahetukā
analyzed: āhārato ṭhiti etesanti āhāraṭṭhitikāḥ iti sabba sattānam pi ṭhiti hetu āhāraḥ nāma ekaḥ  dhammaḥ tasmin eka dhamme nanu ca evam sante yam vuttam asaññasattāḥ devāḥ ahetukāḥ
translated: “All beings” means all beings in all the realms of existence, such as the sensual realm, etc., and the realms of existence such as the single-element realm, etc. “Are sustained by nutriment” means that their existence is sustained by nutriment. Thus nutriment is the one thing that is the cause of the existence of all beings.

original: anāhārā aphassakā”tiādi, taṃ virujjhatīti. Na virujjhati. Tesañhi jhānaṃ āhāro hoti.
analyzed: anāhārāḥ aphassakā atiādi tam virujjhati iti na virujjhati tesam hi jhānam āhāraḥ hoti
translated: “In that one thing” means in that one thing, nutriment. But is it not contradictory to say that nutriment is the cause of the existence of the non-percipient beings, since it is said that they are “without root cause, without nutriment, without contact, without feeling”? It is not contradictory. For their jhāna is their nutriment.

original: Evaṃ santepi “cattārome, bhikkhave, āhārā”ti idaṃ virujjhatīti. Idampi na virujjhati.
analyzed: evam sante pi cattāro me bhikkhave āhārā ti idam virujjhati iti idam api na virujjhati
translated: But is it not contradictory to say that nutriment is the cause of the existence of all beings, since it is said that there are four kinds of nutriment? It is not contradictory.

original: Etasmiñhi sutte nippariyāyena āhāralakkhaṇā dhammā āhārāti vuttā, idha pana pariyāyena
analyzed: etasmin hi sutte nippariyāyena āhāra lakkhaṇāḥ dhammāḥ āhārā ti vuttāḥ idha pana pariyāyena
translated: For in this sutta, nutriment is said to be the one thing that is the cause of the existence of all beings in the sense of the characteristic of nutriment, but here it is said in the sense of the classification of nutriment.

original: paccayo āhāroti vutto. Sabbadhammānañhi paccayo laddhuṃ vaṭṭati. So ca yaṃ yaṃ phalaṃ🔽janeti, taṃ taṃ āharati nāma. Tasmā āhāroti vuccati. Tenevāha – “avijjampāhaṃ, bhikkhave,🔽sāhāraṃ vadāmi, no anāhāraṃ. Ko ca, bhikkhave, avijjāya āhāro? Pañca nīvaraṇātissa
analyzed: paccayaḥ āhāraḥ iti vuttaḥ sabba dhammānam hi paccayaḥ laddhum vaṭṭati saḥ ca yam yam phalam  janeti tam tam āharati nāma tasmai āhāraḥ iti vuccati tena iva āha avijjampa aham bhikkhave  sa āhāram vadāmi no anāhāram kaḥ ca bhikkhave avijjāya āhāro pañca
translated: and it is said that it is a condition for them. For a condition must be found for all states. And that nutriment is said to “bring about” whatever fruit it generates, and it is said to “bring in” that fruit. That is why it is called nutriment. Hence it is said: “Bhikkhus, I do not say that nutriment is to be sought after by one who hungers, nor that it is not to be sought after. But, bhikkhus, I say that nutriment is to be sought after by one who hungers, and that it is not to be sought after by one who does not hunger. And what is the nutriment for the arising of unarisen ignorance and for the increase and expansion of arisen ignorance? There are, bhikkhus, these five hindrances, which are defilements of the mind and weaken wisdom. What five? The hindrance of sensual desire, the hindrance of ill will, the hindrance of sloth and torpor, the hindrance of restlessness and remorse, and the hindrance of doubt. These are the five hindrances, which are defilements of the mind and weaken wisdom.

original: vacanīya”nti. Ayaṃ idha adhippeto. Etasmiñhi paccayāhāre gahite pariyāyāhāropi nippariyāyāhāropi🔽sabbo gahitova hoti.
analyzed: vacanīyanti ayam idha adhippetaḥ etasmin hi paccaya āhāre gahite pariyāya āhāraḥ api nippariyāya āhāraḥ api  sabbaḥ gahitaḥ iva hoti
translated: and it is said that it is a condition for them. For a condition is needed for all states. And that condition brings about whatever fruit it does, and it is called its “bringing” . That is why it is called “bringing” . That is why it is said: “Bhikkhus, I do not say that final knowledge is by a way without bringing. And what is the bringing of ignorance? It should be said: the five hindrances” . This is what is intended here. For when the bringing as condition is included, then the bringing as manner of expression and the bringing as non-manner of expression are included too.

original: Tattha asaññībhave paccayāhāro labbhati. Anuppanne hi buddhe titthāyatane pabbajitā🔽vāyokasiṇe parikammaṃ katvā catutthajjhānaṃ nibbattetvā tato vuṭṭhāya “dhi cittaṃ,
analyzed: tattha asaññībhave paccaya āhāraḥ labbhati anuppanne hi buddhe titthāyatane pabbajitā  vāyokasiṇe parikammam katvā catuttha jhānam nibbattetvā tatas vuṭṭhāya dhi cittam
translated: In the state of non-percipient beings the bringing as condition is found. For when a Buddha has not arisen, those who go forth in the sects’ monasteries

original: dhi vatetaṃ cittaṃ, cittassa nāma abhāvoyeva sādhu. Cittañhi nissāya vadhabandhādipaccayaṃ
analyzed: dhi vata itam cittam cittassa nāma sādhu cittam hi nissāya vadha bandha ādi paccayam
translated: do the preliminary work for the air kasiṇa and produce the fourth jhāna. When they emerge from it they think, “It is good that the mind does not exist, that it has been annihilated. For it is owing to the mind that there are such conditions as killing, binding, etc.

original: dukkhaṃ uppajjati. Citte asati nattheta”nti khantiṃ ruciṃ uppādetvā aparihīnajjhānā
analyzed: dukkham uppajjati citte asati nattha itanti khantim rucim uppādetvā a parihīna jjhānā
translated: and suffering arises. When there is no consciousness, there is no future renewed existence. ’

original: kālaṃ katvā asaññībhave nibbattanti. Yo yassa iriyāpatho manussaloke paṇihito ahosi,
analyzed: kālam katvā asaññībhave nibbattanti yaḥ yassa iriyāpathaḥ manussa loke paṇihitaḥ ahosi
translated: Having aroused this approval and desire, they are reborn in the non-percipient realm without losing their jhana.🔽They are reborn in the form of the posture they had in the human world when they made their resolution.

original: so tena iriyāpathena nibbattitvā cittarūpasadiso hutvā pañca kappasatāni tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: so tena iriyāpathena nibbattitvā citta rūpa sadisaḥ hutvā pañca kappa satāni tiṭṭhati
translated: They remain there for five hundred eons, looking like a mental creation.

original: Ettakaṃ addhānaṃ sayito viya hoti. Evarūpānampi sattānaṃ paccayāhāro labbhati. Te
analyzed: ettakam addhānam sayitaḥ viya hoti evarūpānam pi sattānam paccaya āhāraḥ labbhati te
translated: For that length of time they are as if asleep. And they get nutriment in the form of conditions,

original: hi yaṃ jhānaṃ bhāvetvā nibbattā, tadeva nesaṃ paccayo hoti. Yathā jiyāvegena khittasaro
analyzed: hi yam jhānam bhāvetvā nibbattā tat eva na isam paccayaḥ hoti yathā jiyā vegena khitta saro
translated: for the jhana they developed is a condition for their remaining there. Just as an arrow shot by a strong archer

original: yāva jiyāvego atthi, tāva gacchati. Evaṃ yāva jhānapaccayo atthi, tāva tiṭṭhanti.
analyzed: yāva jiyā vegaḥ atthi tāva gacchati evam yāva jhāna paccayo atthi tāva tiṭṭhanti
translated: goes as long as its momentum lasts, so they remain there as long as the condition lasts.

original: Tasmiṃ niṭṭhite khīṇavego viya saro patanti. Cavanakāle ca tesaṃ so rūpakāyo antaradhāyati,
analyzed: tasmin niṭṭhite khīṇa vegaḥ viya saraḥ patanti cavana kāle ca tesam saḥ rūpa kāyaḥ antaradhāyati
translated: When that is finished, they fall like an arrow whose momentum is spent. And at the moment of their falling, their material body disappears,

original: kāmāvacarasaññā uppajjati, tena saññuppādena te devā tamhā kāyā cutāti paññāyanti.
analyzed: kāmāvacara saññā uppajjati tena saññuppādena te devā tamhā kāyā cutā ati paññāyanti
translated: and perception of the sense-desire realm arises. By the arising of that perception they are said to “fall from that existence.”

original: Ye pana te nerayikā neva vuṭṭhānaphalūpajīvī, na puññaphalūpajīvīti vuttā, tesaṃ
analyzed: ye pana te nerayikāḥ na iva vuṭṭhāna phala upajīvī na puñña phala upajīvī iti vuttā tesam
translated: But what is the nutriment of those beings in hell who are said not to live on the fruits of consciousness or of kamma?

original: ko āhāroti? Tesaṃ kammameva āhāro. Kiṃ pañca āhārā atthīti? Pañca, na pañcāti idaṃ
analyzed: kaḥ āhāro ti tesam kammam eva āhāro kim pañca āhārāḥ atthi iti pañca na pañca ati idam
translated: Their nutriment is kamma itself. But is there the fivefold nutriment there or not?

original: na vattabbaṃ, nanu “paccayo āhāro”ti vuttametaṃ. Tasmā yena kammena niraye nibbattanti,
analyzed: na vattabbam nanu paccayaḥ āhāraḥ iti vuttam etam tasmā yena kammena niraye nibbattanti
translated: It should not be said that there is or that there is not, for it is said that “a condition is nutriment” .

original: tadeva tesaṃ ṭhitipaccayattā āhāro hoti. Yaṃ sandhāya idaṃ vuttaṃ – “na ca tāva kālaṃ
analyzed: tat eva tesam ṭhiti paccaya ttā āhāraḥ hoti yam sandhāya idam vuttam na ca tāva kālam
translated: So the kamma by which they are reborn in hell is their nutriment since it is a condition for their presence there.

original: karoti, yāva na taṃ pāpakammaṃ byantī hotī”ti.
analyzed: karoti yāva na tam pāpa kammam byantī hoti iti
translated: For it is said: “He does not die until the dissolution of that kamma” .

original: Kabaḷīkārāhāraṃ ārabbhāpi cettha vivādo na kātabbo. Mukhe uppajjanakheḷopi hi tesaṃ
analyzed: kabaḷīkāra āhāram ārabbhā api ca ittha vivādaḥ na kātabbaḥ mukhe uppajjana kheḷaḥ api hi tesam
translated: And there should be no dispute about the nutriment consisting of edible food, since even the saliva that falls into the mouth of those in hell serves the function of nutriment.

original: āhārakiccaṃ sādheti. Kheḷo hi niraye dukkhavedanīyo hutvā paccayo hoti, sagge sukhavedaniyo.
analyzed: āhāra kiccam sādheti kheḷaḥ hi niraye dukkha vedanīyaḥ hutvā paccayaḥ hoti sagge sukha vedaniyaḥ
translated: For that saliva is a condition for the painful feeling in hell and for the pleasant feeling in the happy destinies.

original: Iti kāmabhave nippariyāyena cattāro āhārā, rūpārūpabhavesu ṭhapetvā asaññe sesānaṃ
analyzed: iti kāma bhave nippariyāyena cattāraḥ āhārāḥ rūpa arūpa bhavesu ṭhapetvā asaññe sesānam
translated: So in the sense sphere there are four kinds of nutriment in the strict sense, and in the fine-material and immaterial spheres there are three kinds of nutriment, excluding edible food.

original: tayo, asaññānañceva avasesānañca paccayāhāroti iminā ākārena sabbe sattā āhāraṭṭhitikāti🔽veditabbā. Tattha cattāro āhāro yo vā pana koci paccayāhāro dukkhasaccaṃ, āhārasamuṭṭhāpikā🔽purimataṇhā samudayasaccaṃ, ubhinnaṃ appavatti nirodhasaccaṃ, nirodhappajānanā paññā
analyzed: tayo asaññānam ca iva avasesānam ca paccaya āhāro ti iminā ākārena sabbe sattā āhāra ṭṭhitikā ti  veditabbā tattha cattāraḥ āhāraḥ yaḥ vā pana koci paccaya āhāraḥ dukkha saccam āhāra samuṭṭhāpikā  purima taṇhā samudaya saccam ubhinnam appavatti nirodha saccam nirodha ppajānanā paññā
translated: “The three and the rest are conditions for the nutriments” : in this way all beings should be understood to subsist by way of nutriment.

original: maggasaccanti evaṃ catusaccavasena sabbavāresu yojanā kātabbā.
analyzed: magga saccam ti evam catu sacca vasena sabba vāresu yojanā kātabbā
translated: Herein, the four nutriments and any other kind of condition as nutriment are the truth of suffering. The craving that originates from nutriment is the truth of origin. The non-occurrence of both is the truth of cessation. The understanding of cessation is the truth of the path. Thus the application should be made in all instances by way of the four truths.

original: 8. Dutiyamahāpañhasuttavaṇṇanā🔽28. Aṭṭhame kajaṅgalāyanti evaṃnāmake nagare. Kajaṅgalāti kajaṅgalāvāsino. Mahāpañhesūti
analyzed: dutiya mahāpañha sutta vaṇṇanā  aṭṭhame kajaṅgalāyanti evaṃnāmake nagare kajaṅgalā ati kajaṅgalā vāsinaḥ mahā pañhesu iti
translated: . Commentary

original: mahantaatthapariggāhakesu pañhesu. Yathā mettha khāyatīti yathā me ettha upaṭṭhāti.
analyzed: mahanta attha pariggāhakesu pañhesu yathā mā ittha khāyati iti yathā me ettha upaṭṭhāti
translated: In the eighth sutta, in the town named Kajaṅgalā. Kajaṅgalā means the inhabitants of Kajaṅgalā. In the great questions means in the questions that grasp great meaning. As it appears to me means as it occurs to me.

original: Sammā subhāvitacittoti hetunā nayena suṭṭhu bhāvitacitto. Eso ceva tassa atthoti
analyzed: sammā su bhāvita citto ti hetunā nayena suṭṭhu bhāvita citto esaḥ ca iva tassa attho ti
translated: With his mind well developed by reason means with his mind well developed by cause, by reason. This is the meaning of that.

original: kiñcāpi bhagavatā “cattāro dhammā”tiādayo pañhā “cattāro āhārā”tiādinā nayena vissajjitā,🔽yasmā pana catūsu āhāresu pariññātesu cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvitā honti, tesu ca
analyzed: kiñca api bhagavatā cattāro dhammā ati ādayaḥ pañhā cattāro āhārā ati ādinā nayena vissajjitā  yasmā pana catūsu āhāresu pariññātesu cattāro satipaṭṭhānāḥ bhāvitāḥ honti tesu ca
translated: Although the Blessed One answered the questions beginning with “Four dhammas” by the method beginning with “Four nutriments,”🔽still, when the four nutriments are fully understood, the four foundations of mindfulness are developed,

original: bhāvitesu cattāro āhārā pariññātāva honti. Tasmā desanāvilāsena byañjanamevettha🔽nānaṃ, attho pana ekoyeva. Indriyādīsupi eseva nayo. Tena vuttaṃ – “eso ceva tassa
analyzed: bhāvitesu cattāro āhārā pariññātā ava honti tasmā desanā vilāsena byañjanam eva ittha  atthaḥ pana ekaḥ yā iva indriya ādīsu pi esā iva nayaḥ tena vuttam esaḥ ca iva tassa
translated: and when the four foundations of mindfulness are developed, the four nutriments are fully understood. So the difference here is only in the phrasing,🔽which is varied for the sake of ornamenting the teaching.

original: attho”ti. Atthato hi ubhayampetaṃ majjhe bhinnasuvaṇṇamiva hoti.
analyzed: attha uti atthataḥ hi ubhayampetam majjhe bhinna suvaṇṇam iva hoti
translated: The meaning is the same in both cases. The same method applies in the case of the faculties, etc. That is why it is said, “The meaning is the same in both cases.” For in meaning both are like well-refined gold.

original: 9. Paṭhamakosalasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: paṭhama kosala sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The first Kosala-Bhagga Sutta

original: 29. Navame yāvatāti yattakā. Kāsikosalāti kāsikosalajanapadā. Attheva aññathattanti🔽ṭhitassa aññathattaṃ atthiyeva. Atthi vipariṇāmoti maraṇampi atthiyeva. Tasmimpi

analyzed: catutthā ākiñcaññāyatana saññā yasmā pana sā saññā aggā ti āgatā tato param saññā paññatti

translated: “Of outsiders”: of those who go outside the Dispensation. “It would not be, it would not belong to me”: if I were to

analyzed: sace pi anāgate na bhavissāmi na ca me kiñci palibodha jātam bhavissati agge virajjati iti

original: Paramatthavisuddhinti uttamatthavisuddhiṃ. Nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasamāpattiyā etaṃ

original: adhivacanaṃ. Ākiñcaññāyatanañhi vipassanāpadaṭṭhānattā aggaṃ nāma jātaṃ, nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ

analyzed: nibbānam hi sabba vedayita ppahāna ttā vedanānam pariññā nāma anupādā parinibbānan ti  apaccaya parinibbānam idam pana suttam kathentaḥ bhagavā anabhirati pīḷitāni pañca
translated: For Nibbāna is called the full understanding of feeling because it is the abandoning of all feeling. By the deathless element, Nibbāna, without clinging:🔽by the element of Nibbāna without condition.

original: bhikkhusatāni disvā tesaṃ anabhirativinodanatthaṃ kathesi. Tepi anabhiratiṃ vinodetvā
analyzed: bhikkhu satāni disvā tesam anabhirati vinodana attham kathesi te api anabhiratim vinodetvā

original: ākappo mayā karaṇīyo, santindriyena santamānasena yugamattadassinā visamaṭṭhāne udakasakaṭeneva🔽mandamitapadavītihārena hutvā gantabbanti paccavekkhitabbaṃ. Evaṃ paccavekkhato hi
analyzed: ākappaḥ mayā karaṇīyaḥ santa indriyena santa mānasena yuga matta dassinā visama ṭṭhāne udaka sakaṭena iva  manda mita padavī tihārena hutvā gantabbanti paccavekkhitabbam evam paccavekkhataḥ hi
translated: He should walk with his faculties and mind quiet, looking straight ahead the length of a plough yoke, and with a gait that is neither too slow nor too fast, like a figure in a painting walking.

original: iriyāpatho sāruppo hoti, tisso sikkhā paripūrenti. Kaccinukhoti salakkhaṇe nipātasamudāyo.
analyzed: iriyāpathaḥ sāruppaḥ hoti tissaḥ sikkhāḥ paripūrenti sa lakkhaṇe nipāta samudāyaḥ
translated: For when he reviews thus, his deportment becomes seemly, and he fulfils the three trainings.🔽The words “Now, is my mind” are a compound of terms that denote characteristics.🔽“My mind” is the heart .

original: Attāti cittaṃ. Sīlato na upavadatīti aparisuddhaṃ te sīlanti sīlapaccayo na upavadati.
analyzed: attā ati cittam sīlataḥ naḥ upavadati iti a parisuddham te sīlam ti sīla paccayaḥ naḥ upavadati
translated: “Does not reproach me as to virtue” : the condition of virtue does not reproach him, thinking, “Your virtue is impure.”

original: Evaṃ paccavekkhato hi ajjhattaṃ hirī samuṭṭhāti, sā tīsu dvāresu saṃvaraṃ sādheti,
analyzed: evam paccavekkhataḥ hi ajjhattam hirī samuṭṭhāti sā tīsu dvāresu saṃvaram sādheti
translated: For when he reviews thus, shame arises in him, and that shame accomplishes restraint in the three doors,

original: tīsu dvāresu saṃvaro catupārisuddhisīlaṃ hoti, catupārisuddhisīle ṭhito vipassanaṃ🔽vaḍḍhetvā arahattaṃ gaṇhāti. Anuvicca viññū sabrahmacārīti paṇḍitā sabrahmacārino
analyzed: tīsu dvāresu saṃvaro catu pārisuddhi sīlam hoti catu pārisuddhi sīle ṭhitaḥ vipassanam  vaḍḍhetvā arahattam gaṇhāti anuvicca viññū sabrahmacārī iti paṇḍitā sabrahmacārino
translated: Restraint in the three doors is virtue of purification by means of the four paths. Standing upon that virtue, he develops insight and reaches Arahantship.

original: anuvicāretvā. Evaṃ paccavekkhato hi bahiddhā ottappaṃ saṇṭhāti, taṃ tīsu dvāresu
analyzed: anuvicāretvā evam paccavekkhataḥ hi bahiddhā ottappam saṇṭhāti tam tīsu dvāresu
translated: Having examined: having had wise companions in the life of purity examine him. For when he reflects thus, shame at wrongdoing is established in him externally.

original: saṃvaraṃ sādhetīti anantaranayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: saṃvaram sādha iti iti anantara nayena iva veditabbam
translated: He accomplishes restraint in the three doors: this should be understood in the way already stated.

original: Nānābhāvo vinābhāvoti jātiyā nānābhāvo, maraṇena vinābhāvo. Evaṃ paccavekkhato hi
analyzed: nānābhāvaḥ vinābhāvaḥ ti jātiyāḥ nānābhāvaḥ maraṇena vinābhāvaḥ evam paccavekkhataḥ hi
translated: Difference and separation: the difference is due to birth, the separation is due to death. For when he reflects thus,

original: tīsu dvāresu asaṃvutākāro nāma na hoti, maraṇassati sūpaṭṭhitā hoti. Kammassakomhītiādīsu🔽kammaṃ mayhaṃ sakaṃ attano santakanti kammassakā. Kammena dātabbaṃ phalaṃ dāyaṃ,
analyzed: tīsu dvāresu asaṃvuta ākāraḥ nāma na hoti maraṇassa ti su upaṭṭhitā hoti  kammam mayham sakam attanaḥ santakam ti kammassakā kammena dātabbam phalam dāyam
translated: the aspect of unguardedness in the three doors does not occur in him, and mindfulness of death is well established in him.🔽He is the owner of his deeds: kamma is his own, belonging to himself, his own affair.🔽The fruit to be given by kamma is kamma-dāya.🔽He takes up kamma-dāya, thus he is a kamma-dāyāda.

original: kammassa dāyaṃ kammadāyaṃ, taṃ ādīyāmīti kammadāyādo. Kammaṃ mayhaṃ yoni kāraṇanti
analyzed: kammassa dāyam kamma dāyam tam ādīyāmi iti kamma dāya adaḥ kammam mayham yoni
translated: Kamma is his own source, his own cause.

original: kammayoni. Kammaṃ mayhaṃ bandhu ñātakoti kammabandhu. Kammaṃ mayhaṃ paṭisaraṇaṃ patiṭṭhāti
analyzed: kamma yoni kammam mayham bandhu ñātakā uti kamma bandhu kammam mayham paṭisaraṇam patiṭṭhāti
translated: ‘Kamma is my kinsman’ means that kamma is his kinsman, his relative. ‘Kamma is my refuge’ means that kamma is his refuge, his support.

original: kammapaṭisaraṇo. Tassa dāyādo bhavissāmīti tassa kammassa dāyādo tena dinnaphalaṃ
analyzed: kamma paṭisaraṇaḥ tassa dāyādaḥ bhavissāmi iti tassa kammassa dāyādaḥ tena dinna phalam
translated: ‘I am the heir to kamma’ means that he will be the heir to the result of that kamma, the receiver of the result given by kamma.

original: paṭiggāhako bhavissāmi. Evaṃ kammassakataṃ pana paccavekkhato pāpakaraṇaṃ nāma na🔽hoti. Kathaṃbhūtassa me rattindivā vītivattantīti kinnu kho me vattappaṭipattiṃ karontassa,
analyzed: paṭiggāhakaḥ bhavissāmi evam kammassakatam pana paccavekkhato pāpa karaṇam nāma na  hoti kathaṃbhūtassa me rattindivā vītivattanti iti kin nu kho me vatta paṭipattim karontassa
translated: When he reflects thus on the ownership of kamma, he will not commit evil.🔽‘How do day and night pass for me?’ means ‘How do day and night pass for me, while I am engaged in the practice of the duties or not, while I am reciting the Buddha’s word or not, while I am applying my mind to the development of concentration or not?’

original: udāhu akarontassa, buddhavacanaṃ sajjhāyantassa, udāhu asajjhāyantassa, yonisomanasikāre
analyzed: udāhu a karontassa buddha vacanam sajjhāyantassa udāhu a sajjhāyantassa yoniso manasikāre
translated: ‘How do day and night pass for me?’ means ‘How do day and night pass for me, while I am engaged in the practice of the duties or not, while I am reciting the Buddha’s word or not, while I am applying my mind to the development of concentration or not?’🔽‘How do day and night pass for me?’ means ‘How do day and night pass for me, while I am engaged in the practice of the duties or not, while I am reciting the Buddha’s word or not, while I am applying my mind to the development of concentration or not?’

original: kammaṃ karontassa, udāhu akarontassāti kathaṃbhūtassa me rattindivā vītivattanti,
analyzed: kammam karontassa udāhu a karontassa ati kathaṃbhūtassa me rattin divā vītivattanti
translated: The meaning is: ‘How do they pass for me, while I am engaged in the practice of the duties or not, while I am reciting the Buddha’s word or not, while I am applying my mind to the development of concentration or not?’

original: parivattantīti attho. Evaṃ paccavekkhato hi appamādo paripūrati.
analyzed: parivattanti iti atthaḥ evam paccavekkhataḥ hi appamādaḥ paripūrati
translated: For when he reflects thus, his heedfulness is fulfilled.

original: Suññāgāre abhiramāmīti vivittokāse sabbiriyāpathesu ekakova hutvā kacci nu kho abhiramāmīti
analyzed: suññāgāre abhiramāmi iti vivitta ukāse sa biriyāpathesu ekakaḥ iva hutvā kacci nu kho abhiramāmi iti
translated: ‘I delight in an empty place’ means ‘I delight in a secluded place, in a location that is quiet and still, in a place where there are no people, in a place that is remote from the noise of people, in a place that is remote from the habitations of men.’

original: attho. Evaṃ paccavekkhato kāyaviveko paripūrati. Uttarimanussadhammoti uttarimanussānaṃ🔽ukkaṭṭhamanussabhūtānaṃ jhāyīnañceva ariyānañca jhānādidhammo, dasakusalakammapathasaṅkhātamanussadhammato
analyzed: atthaḥ evam paccavekkhato kāya viveko paripūrati uttari manussa dhammo ti uttari manussānam  ukkaṭṭha manussa bhūtānam jhāyīnam ca iva ariyānam ca jhāna ādi dhammaḥ dasa kusala kammapatha saṅkhāta manussa dhammato
translated: The meaning is: “When he reflects thus, bodily seclusion is fulfilled for him.” The supramundane state: the state of those who are superior to mundane beings,🔽the state of the lofty, the state of the meditators and noble ones, the jhānas, etc., which is superior to the mundane state of the ten wholesome courses of action.

original: vā uttaritaro visiṭṭhataro dhammo me mama santāne atthi nu kho, santi nu khoti attho.🔽Alamariyañāṇadassanavisesoti mahaggatalokuttarapaññā pajānanaṭṭhena ñāṇaṃ, cakkhunā
analyzed: vā uttaritaraḥ visiṭṭhataraḥ dhammaḥ me mama santāne atthi nu kho santi nu kho ti attho  alam ariya ñāṇa dassana viseso ti mahaggata lokuttara paññā pajānana ṭṭhena ñāṇam cakkhunā
translated: The meaning is: “Is there or is there not in my continuity the supramundane state that is higher than the mundane state consisting in the ten profitable courses of action?”🔽The distinction of knowledge and vision that is noble: knowledge is the supra-mundane understanding that occurs in the mode of knowing ; vision is the seeing that occurs in the mode of seeing , as though seeing a visible object with the eye.

original: diṭṭhamiva dhammaṃ paccakkhakaraṇato dassanaṭṭhena dassananti ñāṇadassanaṃ, ariyaṃ🔽visuddhaṃ uttamaṃ ñāṇadassananti ariyañāṇadassanaṃ, alaṃ pariyattakaṃ kilesaviddhaṃsanasamatthaṃ
analyzed: diṭṭham iva dhammam paccakkha karaṇataḥ dassana ṭṭhena dassanan ti ñāṇa dassanam ariyam  visuddham uttamam ñāṇa dassanan ti ariya ñāṇa dassanam alam pariyattakam kilesa viddhaṃsana samattham
translated: The combination of knowledge and vision is called “knowledge and vision” . The noble knowledge and vision is purified, exalted, surpassing, and supramundane.🔽The meaning is: “Is there or is there not in my continuity the supramundane state that is higher than the mundane state consisting in the ten profitable courses of action?”🔽The distinction of knowledge and vision that is noble: the knowledge is the supra-mundane understanding that occurs in the mode of knowing ; the vision is the seeing that occurs in the mode of seeing , as though seeing a visible object with the eye.

original: ariyañāṇadassanamettha, assa vāti alamariyañāṇadassano, jhānādibhedo uttarimanussadhammo
analyzed: ariya ñāṇa dassanam ettha assa vāti alam ariya ñāṇa dassanaḥ jhāna ādi bhedaḥ uttari manussa dhammaḥ
translated: The combination of knowledge and vision is called “knowledge and vision” . The noble knowledge and vision is purified, exalted, surpassing, and supramundane.🔽The meaning is: “Is there or is there not in my continuity the supramundane state that is higher than the mundane state consisting in the ten profitable courses of action?”

original: alamariyañāṇadassano ca so viseso cāti alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso. Atha vā tameva🔽kilesaviddhaṃsanasamatthaṃ visuddhaṃ ñāṇadassanameva visesoti alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso
analyzed: alam ariya ñāṇa dassano ca saḥ visesaḥ ca ati alam ariya ñāṇa dassana visesaḥ atha vā tam eva  kilesa viddhaṃsana samattham visuddham ñāṇa dassanam eva viseso ti alam ariya ñāṇa dassana viseso
translated: and that is the distinction, thus it is the distinction of the Noble Ones’ knowledge and vision. Or alternatively, that purified knowledge and vision itself which is capable of destroying the defilements is the distinction, thus it is the distinction of the Noble Ones’ knowledge and vision.

original: vā. Adhigatoti paṭiladdho me atthi nu kho. Sohanti paṭiladdhaviseso so ahaṃ. Pacchime🔽kāleti maraṇamañce nipannakāle. Puṭṭhoti sabrahmacārīhi adhigataguṇavisesaṃ pucchito.
analyzed: vā adhigato ti paṭiladdhaḥ me atthi nu kho sohanti paṭiladdha viseso so aham pacchime  kāle iti maraṇa mañce nipanna kāle puṭṭhaḥ ti sabrahmacārīhi adhigata guṇa visesam pucchitaḥ
translated: Or alternatively, the distinction of the Noble Ones’ knowledge and vision is the distinction of the Noble Ones’ knowledge and vision.

original: Na maṅku bhavissāmīti patitakkhandho nittejo na hessāmīti. Evaṃ paccavekkhantassa
analyzed: na maṅku bhavissāmi iti patita kkhandhaḥ nittejaḥ na hessāmi iti evam paccavekkhantassa
translated: ‘I have attained’: I have obtained. ‘That distinction’: that distinction of what has been attained. ‘At the time of my death’: at the time of lying on my deathbed. ‘I shall not be embarrassed’: I shall not be downcast and spiritless.🔽For one who reflects thus

original: hi moghakālakiriyā nāma na hoti.
analyzed: hi mogha kālakiriyā nāma na hoti
translated: his death will not be fruitless.

original: 9-10. Sarīraṭṭhadhammasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Suttas on the states that are in the body, etc.,

original: 49-50. Navame ponobbhavikoti punabbhavanibbattako. Bhavasaṅkhāroti bhavasaṅkharaṇakammaṃ.
analyzed: navame ponobbhaviko ti punabbhava nibbattakaḥ bhava saṅkhāro ti bhava saṅkharaṇa kammam
translated: In the ninth, ‘subject to rebirth’ is ‘subject to the production of renewed existence.’ ‘The process of becoming’ is kamma that generates the process of becoming.

original: Imasmiṃ sutte vaṭṭameva kathitaṃ. Dasame sīlabāhusaccavīriyasatipaññā lokiyalokuttarāmissikā
analyzed: imasmim sutte vaṭṭam eva kathitam dasame sīla bāhu sacca vīriya sati paññā lokiya lokuttarā āmissikā
translated: In this sutta only the round is stated. In the tenth, virtue, learning, generosity, and understanding, whether mundane or supramundane, whether of the disciple or of the Arahant, are all called ‘virtue, etc., in the world.’

original: kathitā. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.🔽Akkosavaggo pañcamo.
analyzed: kathitā sesam sabbattha uttāna attham eva ati  akkosa vaggaḥ pañcamaḥ
translated: is explained. The rest is clear in meaning everywhere.🔽The fifth sub-chapter on reviling is finished.

original: Paṭhamapaṇṇāsakaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: paṭhama paṇṇāsakam niṭṭhitam
translated: The first fifty is finished.🔽The second fifty

original: 2. Dutiyapaṇṇāsakaṃ🔽(6) 1. Sacittavaggo
analyzed: dutiya paṇṇāsakam  sa citta vaggaḥ
translated: The chapter on the mind

original: 1-4. Sacittasuttādivaṇṇanā🔽51-54. Dutiyassa paṭhame sacittapariyāyakusaloti attano cittavārakusalo. Rajanti
analyzed: dutiyassa paṭhame sa citta pariyāya kusalo ti attano citta vāra kusalo rajanti
translated: The explanation of the Sacitta Sutta, etc.

original: āgantukaupakkilesaṃ. Aṅgaṇanti tatthajātakaaṅgakāḷatilakādiṃ. Āsavānaṃ khayāyāti
analyzed: āgantuka aupakkilesam āsavānam khayāya āti
translated: In the first of the second group, “skilled in the way of the mind” means skilled in the matter of his own mind. “Dust” means the dust of the defilements that come from outside. “Dirt” means the dirt of the hair, soot, etc., that are born there. “For the destruction of the taints” means

original: arahattatthāya. Tatiye paṭibhānenāti vacanasaṇṭhānena. Catutthe adhipaññādhammavipassanāyāti
analyzed: arahat tatthāya tatiye paṭibhānena ati vacana saṇṭhānena catutthe adhi paññā dhamma vipassanāya ati
translated: for the purpose of arahatship. In the third, “in the reply” means in the form of the words. In the fourth, “in the higher wisdom and in the insight into ideas” means

original: saṅkhārapariggāhakavipassanāya.
analyzed: saṅkhāra pariggāhaka vipassanāya
translated: in the insight that investigates formations.

original: 8. Mūlakasuttavaṇṇanā🔽58. Aṭṭhame amatogadhāti ettha saupādisesā nibbānadhātu kathitā, nibbānapariyosānāti
analyzed: aṭṭhame amatogadhā ti ettha sa aupādisesā nibbāna dhātu kathitā nibbāna pariyosānā ti
translated: The explanation of the Mūlaka Sutta

original: ettha anupādisesā. Anupādisesaṃ pattassa hi sabbe dhammā pariyosānappattā nāma honti.
analyzed: ettha anupādisesāḥ anupādisesam pattassa hi sabbe dhammā pariyosāna ppattāḥ nāma honti
translated: In the eighth, “the deathless element” is said to be the Nibbāna element with residue left; “ending with Nibbāna” is said to be the Nibbāna element without residue left. For when one has reached the Nibbāna element without residue left, all ideas have reached their ending.

original: Sesapadāni heṭṭhā vuttatthāneva.
analyzed: sesa padāni heṭṭhā vutta tthānā eva
translated: The remaining terms have the same meaning as given above.

original: 9. Pabbajjāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: pabbajjā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Pabbajjā Sutta

original: 59. Navame tasmāti yasmā evaṃ aparicitacittassa sāmaññattho na sampajjati, tasmā.
analyzed: navame tasmā iti yasmai evam a paricita cittassa sāmaññatthaḥ na sampajjati tasmai
translated: 9. Therefore: since the purpose of the ascetic life is not fulfilled for one whose mind is not thus purified, therefore.

original: Yathāpabbajjāparicitañca no cittaṃ bhavissatīti yathā pabbajjānurūpena paricitaṃ.
analyzed: yathā pabbajja a paricitam ca no cittam bhavissati iti yathā pabbajja anurūpena paricitam
translated: Let our mind be purified as it was when we went forth: let our mind be as it was when it was purified and developed by the going forth.

original: Ye hi keci pabbajanti nāma, sabbe te arahattaṃ patthetvā. Tasmā yaṃ cittaṃ arahattādhigamatthāya🔽paricitaṃ vaḍḍhitaṃ, taṃ yathāpabbajjāparicitaṃ nāmāti veditabbaṃ. Evarūpaṃ pana
analyzed: ye hi keci pabbajanti nāma sabbe te arahattam patthetvā tasmai yam cittam arahatta adhigama tthāya  paricitam vaḍḍhitam tam yathāpabbajjāparicitam nāma ati veditabbam evarūpam pana
translated: For all who go forth do so after aspiring to reach Arahantship. Therefore the mind that was purified and developed🔽for the purpose of reaching Arahantship should be understood as “purified as it was when we went forth.” But we must train thus: “Let our mind be of that kind.”

original: cittaṃ bhavissatīti sikkhitabbaṃ. Lokassa samañca visamañcāti sattalokassa sucaritaduccaritāni.
analyzed: cittam bhavissati iti sikkhitabbam lokassa samañca visamañca ati satta lokassa su carita duccaritāni
translated: The world’s unevenness and evenness: the world of living beings’ good conduct and bad conduct.

original: Lokassa bhavañca vibhavañcāti tassa vaḍḍhiñca vināsañca, tathā sampattiñca vipattiñca.🔽Lokassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañcāti pana saṅkhāralokaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ, khandhānaṃ
analyzed: lokassa bhavañca vibhavañca ati tassa vaḍḍhiñca vināsañca tathā sampattiñca vipattiñca  lokassa samudayam ca atthaṅgamam ca ati pana saṅkhāra lokam sandhāya vuttam khandhānam
translated: The world’s coming and going: its growth and decay, and its success and failure.

original: nibbattiñca bhedañcāti attho.
analyzed: nibbattiñca bhedañca ati attho
translated: The world’s arising and passing away: this is said with reference to the world of formations, the meaning being the production and dissolution of the aggregates.

original: 10. Girimānandasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: girima ānanda sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Exposition of the Discourse with Girimananda🔽.

original: 60. Dasame anukampaṃ upādāyāti girimānandatthere anukampaṃ paṭicca. Cakkhurogotiādayo🔽vatthuvasena veditabbā. Nibbattitappasādānañhi rogo nāma natthi. Kaṇṇarogoti bahikaṇṇe
analyzed: dasame anukampam upādāya ati girima ānanda there anukampam paṭicca cakkhu roga uti ādayo  vatthu vasena veditabbā nibbatti tad pasādānam hi rogaḥ nāma natthi kaṇṇa rogaḥ ti bahi kaṇṇe
translated: 60. In the tenth, out of compassion, means out of compassion for the Elder Girimānanda. Eye disease, etc.,

original: rogo. Pināsoti bahināsikāya rogo. Nakhasāti nakhehi vilekhitaṭṭhāne rogo. Pittasamuṭṭhānāti
analyzed: rogo pināso ti bahi nāsikāya rogaḥ nakhasā ati nakhehi vilekhita ṭhāne rogaḥ pitta samuṭṭhānā ati
translated: should be understood according to the location. For those who have acquired confidence have no disease. Ear disease is a disease in the outer ear. Catarrh is a disease in the nose. Itching is a disease in the place scratched by the nails. Originating from bile, etc.,

original: pittasamuṭṭhitā. Te kira dvattiṃsa honti. Semhasamuṭṭhānādīsupi eseva nayo. Utupariṇāmajāti🔽utupariṇāmena accuṇhātisītena uppajjanakarogā. Visamaparihārajāti aticiraṭṭhānanisajjādinā🔽visamaparihārena jātā. Opakkamikāti vadhabandhanādinā upakkamena jātā. Kammavipākajāti
analyzed: pitta samuṭṭhitā te kira dvattiṃsa honti semha samuṭṭhāna ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ utu pariṇāma jāti  utu pariṇāmena accuṇha ati sītena uppajjanaka rogāḥ visama parihāra jāti ati cira ṭṭhāna nisajja ādinā  visama parihārena jātā opakkamikā ati vadha bandhana ādinā upakkamena jātā kamma vipāka jāti
translated: means originating from bile. They are said to be thirty-two. The same method applies to those originating from phlegm, etc. Originating from a change of temperature🔽means diseases arising from excessive cold or heat due to a change of temperature. Originating from misconduct means diseases arising from excessive standing, sitting, etc.,

original: balavakammavipākasambhūtā. Santanti rāgādisantatāya santaṃ. Atappakaṭṭhena paṇītaṃ.
analyzed: balava kamma vipāka sambhūtā rāga ādi santatāya santam a tappaka ṭṭhena paṇītam
translated: due to misconduct. Originating from assault means diseases arising from assault, imprisonment, etc. Originating as kamma result means diseases arising from the kamma result of powerful kamma. Continuous means continuous by way of lust, etc. It is refined in the sense of being free from fever.

original: Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.
analyzed: sesam sabbattha uttāna attham eva ati
translated: The rest is clear in all instances.

original: Sacittavaggo paṭhamo.
analyzed: sa citta vaggaḥ paṭhamaḥ
translated: The first chapter called “The Chapter on the Mind” is finished.

original: (7) 2. Yamakavaggo
analyzed: yamaka vaggo
translated: The Twin Verses

original: 1. Avijjāsuttādivaṇṇanā🔽61-62. Dutiyassa paṭhame sāhāranti sapaccayaṃ. Vijjāvimuttinti phalañāṇañceva sesasampayuttadhamme🔽ca. Bojjhaṅgāti maggabojjhaṅgā. Dutiye bhavataṇhāyāti bhavapatthanāya. Evaṃ dvīsupi
analyzed: dutiyassa paṭhame sa āhāram ti sa paccayam vijjā vimuttim ti phala ñāṇam ca iva sesa sampayutta dhamme  ca bojjhaṅgā ati magga bojjhaṅgā dutiye bhava taṇhāya ati bhava patthanāya evam dvīsu pi
translated: 1. Description of the “Ignorance” sutta, etc.

original: suttesu vaṭṭameva kathitaṃ, vaṭṭañcettha paṭhame sutte avijjāmūlakaṃ vaṭṭaṃ kathitaṃ,
analyzed: suttesu vaṭṭam eva kathitam vaṭṭam ca ittha paṭhame sutte avijjā mūlakam vaṭṭam kathitam
translated: In the first of the second group, “with conditions” is with conditions for the arising of the five aggregates. “Knowledge and freedom” is the knowledge of fruition and the other associated states. “Factors of enlightenment” is the factors of the path of stream-entry. In the second, “craving for being” is craving for the five aggregates. Thus in both suttas the round is taught. And here in the first sutta the round is taught as rooted in ignorance,

original: dutiye taṇhāmūlakaṃ.
analyzed: dutiye taṇhā mūlakam
translated: in the second as rooted in craving.

original: 3-4. Niṭṭhaṅgatasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: 2. Description of the “One who has reached the end” sutta, etc.

original: 63-64. Tatiye niṭṭhaṃ gatāti nibbematikā. Idha niṭṭhāti imasmiṃyeva loke parinibbānaṃ.🔽Idha vihāyāti imaṃ lokaṃ vijahitvā suddhāvāsabrahmalokaṃ. Catutthe aveccappasannāti
analyzed: tatiye niṭṭham gatā ati nibbematikā idha niṭṭhā ati imasmin yeva loke parinibbānam  vihāya ati imam lokam vijahitvā suddhāvāsa brahma lokam catutthe aveccappasannā ti
translated: In the third, “one who has reached the end” is one who has reached the end of doubt. “Here” is in this very world. “Nibbana” is the attainment of final Nibbāna.

original: acalappasādena sampannā. Sotāpannāti ariyamaggasotaṃ āpannā.🔽5-7. Paṭhamasukhasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: acala pasādena sampannā sotāpannā ati ariya magga sotam āpannā
translated: “Here” is in this world. “Having left” is having abandoned this world. “The brahma world of the pure abodes” is the world of the Suddhāvāsa Brahmas. In the fourth, “one who has perfect confidence” is one who has attained unshakable confidence. “Stream-enterer” is one who has entered the stream of the noble path.🔽3. Description of the “First happiness” sutta, etc.

original: 65-67. Pañcame vaṭṭamūlakaṃ sukhadukkhaṃ pucchitaṃ, chaṭṭhe sāsanamūlakaṃ. Sattame
analyzed: pañcame vaṭṭa mūlakam sukha dukkham pucchitam chaṭṭhe sāsana mūlakam sattame
translated: In the fifth, happiness and suffering rooted in the round are asked about. In the sixth, happiness and suffering rooted in the Dispensation. In the seventh,

original: naḷakapānanti atīte bodhisattassa ovāde ṭhatvā vānarayūthena naḷehi udakassa pītaṭṭhāne
analyzed: naḷaka pānam ti atīte bodhisattassa ovāde ṭhatvā vānara yūthena naḷehi udakassa pīta ṭṭhāne
translated: The village called Naḷakapāna was so called because in the past, after following the advice of the Bodhisatta, a troop of monkeys had drunk water from a reed and then had built a village there.

original: māpitattā evaṃladdhanāmo nigamo. Tuṇhībhūtaṃ tuṇhībhūtanti yaṃ yaṃ disaṃ anuviloketi,
analyzed: evaṃladdha nāmaḥ nigamaḥ yam yam disam yam yam disam
translated: “It was quiet, very quiet”: wherever he looked,🔽it was quiet.🔽“After looking around”: after looking here and there.

original: tattha tattha tuṇhībhūtameva. Anuviloketvāti tato tato viloketvā. Piṭṭhi me āgilāyatīti
analyzed: tattha tattha tuṇhībhūtam eva anuviloketvā ati tatas tatas viloketvā me āgilāyati iti
translated: “My back aches”:

original: kasmā āgilāyati? Bhagavato hi cha vassāni mahāpadhānaṃ padahantassa mahantaṃ kāyadukkhaṃ🔽ahosi, athassa aparabhāge mahallakakāle piṭṭhivāto uppajji. Upādinnakasarīrassa ṭhānanisajjādīhi
analyzed: kasmai āgilāyati bhagavataḥ hi cha vassāni mahā padhānam padahantassa mahantam kāya dukkham  ahosi athassa aparabhāge mahallaka kāle piṭṭhivātaḥ uppajji upādinnaka sarīrassa ṭhāna nisajja ādīhi
translated: why did it ache? For six years the Blessed One had been practicing the Great Practice, and he had suffered great physical pain.🔽Later, in his old age, he developed a back wind. For one who has taken up a physical body, it is not possible to be without some slight affliction in the way of standing, sitting, etc.

original: appamattakena ābādhena na sakkā kenaci bhavituṃ. Taṃ gahetvāpi therassa okāsakaraṇatthaṃ🔽evamāha. Saṅghāṭiṃ paññāpetvā ekamante patirūpaṭṭhāne paññattassa kappiyamañcassa upari attharitvā.
analyzed: appamattakena ābādhena na sakkā kenacid bhavitum tam gahetvā api therassa okāsa karaṇa attham  evam āha saṅghāṭim paññāpetvā eka mante patirūpaṭṭhāne paññattassa kappiya mañcassa upari attharitvā
translated: In order to give the Elder an opportunity to take him,

original: 9-10. Kathāvatthusuttadvayavaṇṇanā
translated: he said this. After spreading his outer robe on a suitable spot at one side, he lay down on his right side, placing one foot on the other, mindful and clearly comprehending, after reflecting on the time of rising.

original: 69-70. Navame tiracchānakathanti aniyyānikattā saggamokkhamaggānaṃ tiracchānabhūtaṃ
analyzed: navame tiracchāna kathanti aniyyānika ttā saggamokkha maggānam tiracchāna bhūtam
translated: 9. Talk that is animal is talk that is not concerned with the supramundane path to heaven and to deliverance.

original: kathaṃ. Tattha rājānaṃ ārabbha “mahāsammato mandhātā dhammāsoko evaṃmahānubhāvo”tiādinā🔽nayena pavattakathā rājakathā. Esa nayo corakathādīsu. Tesu “asuko rājā abhirūpo
analyzed: katham tattha rājānam ārabbha mahāsammataḥ mandhātā dhammāsokaḥ evaṃmahā anubhāvaḥ iti ādinā  nayena pavatta kathā rāja kathā esa nayo cora kathā ādīsu tesu asukaḥ rājā abhirūpaḥ
translated: It is talk that is concerned with kings, thieves, and so on. Herein, talk about kings is talk that occurs in such-and-such a way, referring to kings, such as “Mahāsammata, Mandhātu, Dhammāsoka had such and such great power,” and so on.

original: dassanīyo”tiādinā gehasitakathāva tiracchānakathā hoti, “sopi nāma evaṃmahānubhāvo🔽khayaṃ gato”ti evaṃ pavattā pana kammaṭṭhānabhāve tiṭṭhati. Coresupi “mūladevo evaṃmahānubhāvo,🔽meghadevo evaṃmahānubhāvo”ti tesaṃ kammaṃ paṭicca “aho sūrā”ti gehasitakathāva tiracchānakathā.
analyzed: dassanīyā ti ādinā tiracchāna kathā hoti saḥ api nāma evaṃmahā anubhāvo  khayam gataḥ ti evam pavattā pana kammaṭṭhāna bhāve tiṭṭhati coresu pi mūladevaḥ evaṃmahā anubhāvo  meghadevaḥ evam mahā anubhāvo ti tesam kammam paṭicca aho tiracchāna kathā
translated: This is the method in the case of talk about thieves, and so on. Herein, talk that is concerned with what is merely customary in the world, such as “So-and-so is a king, so-and-so is handsome, so-and-so is good-looking,” is animal talk. But that which occurs in such a way as “So-and-so, who had such and such great power, has come to destruction,” is fit for a meditator’s practice.🔽In the case of thieves too, talk that is concerned with their deeds, such as “Mūladeva had such and such great power, Meghadeva had such and such great power,” and is merely customary in the world, such as “Ah! how brave they were!” is animal talk.

original: Yuddhesupi bhāratayuddhādīsu “asukena asuko evaṃ mārito evaṃ viddho”ti kammassādavaseneva
analyzed: yuddhesu pi bhārata yuddha ādīsu asukena asukaḥ evam māritaḥ evam viddhaḥ iti kammassāda vasena iva
translated: In the case of battles too, talk that occurs in such-and-such a way, referring to the Bhārata war, such as “So-and-so was killed by so-and-so, so-and-so was wounded by so-and-so,” is merely customary in the world and is animal talk. But that which occurs in such a way as “So-and-so, who had such and such great power, has come to destruction,” is fit for a meditator’s practice.

original: kathā tiracchānakathā, “tepi nāma khayaṃ gatā”ti evaṃ pavattā pana sabbattha kammaṭṭhānameva🔽hoti. Apica annādīsu “evaṃ vaṇṇavantaṃ rasavantaṃ phassasampannaṃ khādimha bhuñjimha🔽pivimha paribhuñjimhā”ti kāmarasassādavasena kathetuṃ na vaṭṭati, sātthakaṃ pana
analyzed: kathā tiracchāna kathā te pi nāma khayam gatā ati evam pavattā pana sabbattha kammaṭṭhānam eva  hoti apica anna ādīsu evam vaṇṇavantam rasavantam phassa sampannam khādimha bhuñjimha  pivimha paribhuñjimha ati kāma rasa ssāda vasena kathetum na vaṭṭati sātthakam pana
translated: “Animal talk” is talk about animals, but it is a meditation subject in all cases when it occurs as “They too have come to an end.”

original: katvā “pubbe evaṃ vaṇṇādisampannaṃ annaṃ pānaṃ vatthaṃ yānaṃ mālaṃ gandhaṃ sīlavantānaṃ
analyzed: katvā pubbe evam vaṇṇa ādi sampannam annam pānam vattham yānam mālam gandham sīlavantānam
translated: Moreover, it is not proper to talk about food, etc., with relish for the taste of enjoyment, as follows: “We ate such-and-such food, we drank such-and-such drink, we used such-and-such vehicles, we used such-and-such couches and seats, we used such-and-such perfumes and scents, we used such-and-such clothes, we used such-and-such ornaments, we had such-and-such slaves, servants, and workmen, we had such-and-such villages, towns, and cities, we had such-and-such countries, such-and-such kingdoms, such-and-such wealth, such-and-such property, such-and-such enjoyments.”

original: adamha, cetiyaṃ pūjimhā”ti kathetuṃ vaṭṭati.🔽Ñātikathādīsupi “amhākaṃ ñātakā sūrā samatthā”ti vā “pubbe mayaṃ evaṃ vicitrehi yānehi🔽vicarimhā”ti vā assādavasena vattuṃ na vaṭṭati, sātthakaṃ pana katvā “tepi no ñātakā
analyzed: adamha cetiyam pūjimha iti kathetum vaṭṭati  ñāti kathā ādīsu pi amhākam ñātakā sūrā samatthā iti vā pubbe mayam evam vicitrehi yānehi  vicarimha ati vā assāda vasena vattum na vaṭṭati sātthakam pana katvā te pi no ñātakā
translated: But it is proper to talk about them, making them a reason for practicing rightly, as follows: “Formerly we had such-and-such food, drink, vehicles, etc., and we gave them to the virtuous and observed the Uposatha days, and we worshipped a shrine.”🔽As regards talk about relatives, etc., it is not proper to talk with relish for the taste of enjoyment, as follows: “Our relatives are powerful and able,” or “Formerly we travelled about in such-and-such various vehicles.”

original: khayaṃ gatā”ti vā “pubbe mayaṃ evarūpā upāhanā saṅghassa adamhā”ti vā kathetabbaṃ.
analyzed: khayam gatā ati vā pubbe mayam evarūpāḥ upāhanā saṅghassa adamha ati vā kathetabbam
translated: But it is proper to talk about them, making them a reason for practicing rightly, as follows: “Those relatives of ours have come to an end,” or “Formerly we gave such-and-such sandals to the Community.”

original: Gāmakathāpi suniviṭṭhadunniviṭṭhasubhikkhadubbhikkhādivasena vā “asukagāmavāsino
analyzed: gāma kathā api suniviṭṭha dunniviṭṭha subhikkha dubbhikkha ādi vasena vā asuka gāma vāsinaḥ
translated: Or else the talk may be about villages, about which people say, “The people in such-and-such a village live thus and so, and they live well or badly, and there is much or little food there.”

original: sūrā samatthā”ti vā evaṃ assādavaseneva na vaṭṭati, sātthakaṃ pana katvā “saddhā🔽pasannā”ti vā “khayavayaṃ gatā”ti vā vattuṃ vaṭṭati. Nigamanagarajanapadakathāsupi eseva nayo.🔽Itthikathāpi vaṇṇasaṇṭhānādīni paṭicca assādavasena na vaṭṭati, “saddhā pasannā khayaṃ
analyzed: sūrā samatthā ati vā evam assāda vasena iva na vaṭṭati sātthakam pana katvā saddhā  vā khaya vayam gatā ati vā vattum vaṭṭati nigama nagara janapada kathāsu pi eṣa iva nayaḥ  itthi kathā api vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna ādīni paṭicca assāda vasena na vaṭṭati saddhā pasannā khayam
translated: And talk of a village is not allowable as a mere description of the village as well or badly laid out, as prosperous or not, and so on, or as “The people of such a village are brave, able,” and so on, in terms of its advantages; but it is allowable to describe it as “Faithful, confident,” or as “They have reached the end of the round,” in a way relevant to the True Idea. So too with talk of a town, a country, and a region.

original: gatā”ti evameva vaṭṭati. Sūrakathāpi “nandimitto nāma yodho sūro ahosī”ti assādavaseneva🔽na vaṭṭati, “saddho ahosi khayaṃ gato”ti evameva vaṭṭati. Surākathanti pāḷiyaṃ pana🔽anekavidhaṃ majjakathaṃ assādavasena kathetuṃ na vaṭṭati, ādīnavavaseneva vattuṃ
analyzed: gatā ati evam eva vaṭṭati sūrakathā api nandimittaḥ nāma yodhaḥ sūraḥ ahosi iti assāda vasena iva  na vaṭṭati saddhaḥ ahosi khayam gato ti evam eva vaṭṭati surākathanti pāḷiyam pana  anekavidham majja katham assāda vasena kathetum na vaṭṭati ādīnava vasena iva vattum
translated: And talk of women is not allowable as a description of their looks, figure, and so on, in terms of their advantages; but it is allowable to describe them as “Faithful, confident,” or as “They have reached the end of the round,” in a way relevant to the True Idea. And talk of heroes is not allowable as a description of their bravery, and so on, in terms of their advantages; but it is allowable to describe them as “Faithful, confident,” or as “They have reached the end of the round,” in a way relevant to the True Idea. And talk of strong drink is not allowable as a description of the various kinds of strong drink in terms of their advantages; but it is allowable to describe them as “They are the root of unprofit” in a way relevant to the True Idea.

original: vaṭṭati. Visikhākathāpi “asukavisikhā suniviṭṭhā dunniviṭṭhā sūrā samatthā”ti assādavaseneva
analyzed: vaṭṭati visikhā kathā api asuka visikhā su niviṭṭhā dunniviṭṭhā sūrā samatthā ati assāda vasena iva
translated: And talk of a guild is not allowable as a description of a guild as well or badly laid out, as prosperous or not, and so on, or as “The members of such-and-such a guild are brave, able,” and so on, in terms of its advantages; but it is allowable to describe it as “Faithful, confident,” or as “They have reached the end of the round,” in a way relevant to the True Idea.

original: na vaṭṭati, “saddhā pasannā khayaṃ gatā”ti vaṭṭati. Kumbhaṭṭhānakathā nāma kūṭaṭṭhānakathā🔽udakatitthakathā vuccati. Kumbhadāsikathā vā. Sāpi “pāsādikā naccituṃ gāyituṃ chekā”ti
analyzed: na vaṭṭati saddhā pasannā khayam gatā ati vaṭṭati kumbhaṭṭhānakathā nāma kūṭa ṭṭhāna kathā  udakatittha kathā vuccati kumbhadāsi kathā vā sā api pāsādikā naccitum gāyitum chekā ati
translated: “She has faith and confidence” is allowable. The story of the pot-house is a story of a gambling house.🔽The story of the bathing place is a story of a brothel.

original: assādavasena na vaṭṭati, “saddhā pasannā”tiādinā nayeneva vaṭṭati.
analyzed: assāda vasena na vaṭṭati saddhā pasannā ati ādinā nayena iva vaṭṭati
translated: Or it is a story of a slave girl who is a potter. That too is not allowable because of the pleasure, but it is allowable in the way beginning “She has faith and confidence. ”

original: Pubbapetakathā nāma atītañātikathā. Tattha vattamānañātikathāsadisova vinicchayo.
analyzed: pubbapetakathā nāma atīta ñāti kathā tattha vattamāna ñāti kathā sadisaḥ eva vinicchayo
translated: The story of a previous birth is a story about the past. Herein, the exposition is similar to that for the story about the present.

original: Nānattakathā nāma purimapacchimakathāvimuttā avasesā nānāsabhāvā tiracchānakathā.
analyzed: nānattakathā nāma purima pacchima kathā vimuttā avasesā nānā sabhāvā tiracchāna kathā
translated: The various kinds of stories are the various kinds of stories other than those already mentioned, namely, animal stories.

original: Lokakkhāyikā nāma “ayaṃ loko kena nimmito? Asukena nāma nimmito. Kāko seto aṭṭhīnaṃ
analyzed: lokakkhāyikā nāma ayam loko kena nimmito asukena nāma nimmitaḥ kāko seto aṭṭhīnam
translated: The stories about the world are such as “By whom was this world created? It was created by a certain person called so-and-so. The crow is white because its bones are white,

original: setattā, balākā rattā lohitassa rattattā”tievamādikā lokāyatavitaṇḍasallāpakathā.
analyzed: sā itattā balākā rattā lohitassa ratta ttā ati evamādikā lokāyata vitaṇḍa sallāpa kathā
translated: and the crow is black because its blood is black,” and so on. These are stories of speculation about the world.

original: Samuddakkhāyikā nāma kasmā samuddo sāgaroti. Sāgaradevena khatattā sāgaro, khato
analyzed: samuddakkhāyikā nāma kasmā samuddaḥ sāgaro ti sāgaradevena khatattā sāgaraḥ khataḥ
translated: The stories about the ocean are such as “Why is the ocean called sāgara ? It is called sāgara because it was dug by the god Sāgara. It was dug

original: meti hatthamuddāya niveditattā samuddotievamādikā niratthakā samuddakkhāyanakathā.🔽Bhavoti vuddhi, abhavoti hāni. Iti bhavo iti abhavoti yaṃ vā taṃ vā niratthakakāraṇaṃ
analyzed: mā iti hattha muddāya nivedita ttā samuddaḥ ti evamādikā niratthakā samudda khāyana kathā  bhavoti hāni iti bhavo iti abhavoti yam vā tam vā niratthaka kāraṇam
translated: “The sea” is the sea, etc., which is a meaningless story of the sea’s being measured.

original: vatvā pavattitakathā itibhavābhavakathā nāma.
analyzed: vatvā iti bhava abhava kathā nāma
translated: “Existence” is growth, “non-existence” is diminution. So any story told by saying “it is” or “it is not” for some reason that is meaningless is called “talk of existence and non-existence.”

original: Tejasā tejanti attano tejasā tesaṃ tejaṃ. Pariyādiyeyyāthāti khepetvā gahetvā abhibhaveyyātha.🔽Tatridaṃ vatthu – eko piṇḍapātiko mahātheraṃ pucchi – “bhante, tejasā tejaṃ pariyādiyamānā🔽bhikkhū kiṃ karontī”ti. Thero āha – āvuso, kiñcideva ātape ṭhapetvā yathā chāyā heṭṭhā
analyzed: tejasā tejanti attanaḥ tejasā tesam tejam pariyādiyeyyātha ati khepetvā gahetvā abhibhaveyyātha  tatra idam vatthu ekaḥ piṇḍapātikaḥ mahā theram pucchi bhante tejasā tejam pariyādiyamānā  bhikkhū kim karonti iti theraḥ āha āvuso kiñcid eva ātape ṭhapetvā yathā chāyā heṭṭhā
translated: “With their own brilliance” : with their own radiance. “They would overpower” : they would overpower them by exhausting and taking away their radiance.

original: na otarati, uddhaṃyeva gacchati tathā karonti. Dasame pāsaṃsāni ṭhānānīti pasaṃsāvahāni
analyzed: na otarati uddhaṃya iva gacchati tathā karonti dasame pāsaṃsāni ṭhānāni iti pasaṃsa āvahāni
translated: Here is a story. A certain alms-food-eater asked a senior elder, “Venerable sir, when bhikkhus overpower with their own brilliance the brilliance of others, what do they do?” The elder said, “Friend, they do as follows: they act so that the shadow does not descend below but goes up as it were above the sun that is placed in the sky.”

original: kāraṇāni. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.
analyzed: kāraṇāni sesam sabbattha uttāna attham eva ati
translated: In the tenth case, the “praiseworthy things” are the reasons for praise. The rest is all clear in meaning.

original: Yamakavaggo dutiyo.🔽(8) 3. Ākaṅkhavaggo
analyzed: yamaka vaggo dutiyaḥ  ā kaṅkha vaggaḥ
translated: The second sub-chapter on pairs is finished.🔽The sub-chapter on wishes

original: 1. Ākaṅkhasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ākaṅkha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the Sutta on Wishes.

original: 71. Tatiyassa paṭhame sampannasīlāti paripuṇṇasīlā, sīlasamaṅgino vā hutvāti attho.
analyzed: tatiyassa paṭhame sampanna sīlā ati paripuṇṇa sīlā sīla samaṅginaḥ vā hutvā ati attho
translated: 71.In the first of the third tetrad “possessed of virtue” means possessed of fulfilled virtue, or it means having become possessed of virtue.🔽Herein, virtue is fulfilled for two reasons: by seeing the danger in the slightest fault and by undertaking the training precepts well.

original: Tattha dvīhi kāraṇehi sampannasīlatā hoti sīlavipattiyā ca ādīnavadassanena, sīlasampattiyā
analyzed: tattha dvīhi kāraṇehi sampanna sīla tā hoti sīla vipattiyā ca ādīnava dassanena sīla sampattiyā
translated: And the seeing of the danger in the slightest fault and the undertaking of the precepts are fulfilled by the practice of virtue in all its aspects.🔽Herein, the words “possessed of virtue” are the virtue of the training precepts.🔽The words “Restrained by the Pātimokkha restraint” are the virtue of resort to the good person.🔽The words “guarding the doors of the sense faculties” are the virtue of avoiding wrong resort.🔽The words “knowing the right amount in eating” are the virtue of avoiding unseemly search.🔽The words “devoted to wakefulness” are the virtue of energy.

original: ca ānisaṃsadassanena. Tadubhayampi visuddhimagge vitthāritaṃ. Tattha “sampannasīlā”ti
analyzed: ca ānisaṃsa dassanena tat ubhayam pi visuddhi magge vitthāritam tattha sampanna sīlā ti
translated: The words “possessed of mindfulness and full awareness” are the virtue of mindfulness.🔽The words “endowed with these five qualities” are the virtue of good character.🔽The words “possessed of virtue” are the virtue of Pātimokkha restraint.

original: ettāvatā kira bhagavā catupārisuddhisīlaṃ uddisitvā “pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvutā”ti
analyzed: ettāvatā kira bhagavā catu pārisuddhi sīlam uddisitvā pātimokkha saṃvara saṃvutā ati
translated: The words “Restrained by the Pātimokkha restraint” are the virtue of restraint by the Pātimokkha.🔽The words “guarding the doors of the sense faculties” are the virtue of restraint by mindfulness.

original: iminā tattha jeṭṭhakasīlaṃ vitthāretvā dassesīti dīpavihāravāsī sumanatthero āha.🔽Antevāsiko panassa tepiṭakacūḷanāgatthero āha – ubhayatthapi pātimokkhasaṃvarova
analyzed: iminā tattha jeṭṭhaka sīlam vitthāretvā dassesi iti dīpavihāra vāsī sumana theraḥ āha  antevāsikaḥ pana assa tepiṭakacūḷanāga theraḥ āha ubhayattha api pātimokkha saṃvaraḥ uva
translated: The words “knowing the right amount in eating” are the virtue of restraint by law.🔽The words “devoted to wakefulness” are the virtue of restraint by energy.🔽The words “possessed of mindfulness and full awareness” are the virtue of restraint by wisdom.🔽The words “endowed with these five qualities” are the virtue of restraint by non-affliction.🔽The words “possessed of virtue” are the virtue of restraint by non-defeat.

original: bhagavatā vutto. Pātimokkhasaṃvaroyeva hi sīlaṃ, itarāni pana tīṇi sīlanti vuttaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: bhagavatā vutto pātimokkha saṃvaraḥ yā iva hi sīlam itarāni pana tīṇi sīlanti vutta ṭṭhānam
translated: The words “Restrained by the Pātimokkha restraint” are the virtue of restraint by non-transgression.🔽The words “guarding the doors of the sense faculties” are the virtue of restraint by non-distraction.🔽The words “knowing the right amount in eating” are the virtue of restraint by non-greed.

original: atthīti ananujānanto vatvā āha – indriyasaṃvaro nāma chadvārārakkhāmattakameva, ājīvapārisuddhi
analyzed: atthi iti an anujānantaḥ vatvā āha indriya saṃvaraḥ nāma cha dvāra ārakkhā mattakam eva ājīva pārisuddhi
translated: The words “devoted to wakefulness” are the virtue of restraint by non-drowsiness.🔽The words “possessed of mindfulness and full awareness” are the virtue of restraint by non-delusion.🔽The words “end

original: dhammena samena paccayuppattimattakaṃ, paccayasannissitaṃ paṭiladdhapaccaye idamatthanti
analyzed: dhammena samena paccayuppattimattakam paccaya sannissitam paṭiladdha paccaye idamatthanti
translated: and it is only the mere receiving of requisites in accordance with the True Idea, and it is only the mere using of requisites that have been received after depending upon them, after reviewing them thus ‘ This is the meaning of the requisites ‘.

original: paccavekkhitvā paribhuñjanamattakaṃ. Nippariyāyena pātimokkhasaṃvarova sīlaṃ. Yassa
analyzed: paccavekkhitvā paribhuñjana mattakam nippariyāyena pātimokkha saṃvaraḥ uva sīlam yassa
translated: In the ultimate sense, however, it is only the restraint of the Patimokkha that is virtue.

original: so bhinno, ayaṃ sīsacchinno viya puriso hatthapāde sesāni rakkhissatīti na vattabbo.
analyzed: saḥ bhinnaḥ ayam sīsa chinnaḥ viya puriso hattha pāde sesāni rakkhissati iti na vattabbo
translated: When that is broken, then this man is like one whose head has been cut off, and it cannot be said that his hands and feet are left to him.

original: Yassa pana so arogo, ayaṃ acchinnasīso viya puriso jīvitaṃ sesāni puna pākatikāni🔽kātuṃ sakkoti. Tasmā “sampannasīlā”ti iminā pātimokkhasaṃvaraṃ uddisitvā “sampannapātimokkhā”ti
analyzed: yassa pana saḥ arogaḥ ayam acchinna sīsaḥ viya purisaḥ jīvitam sesāni puna pākatikāni  kātum sakkoti tasmā sampanna sīlā ati iminā pātimokkha saṃvaram uddisitvā sampanna pātimokkhā ati
translated: But when that is sound, then this man is like one whose head has not been cut off, and he can make his hands and feet good again.🔽So after announcing the restraint of the Patimokkha with the words ‘ Possessed of virtue ‘, he stated the synonyms for it with the words ‘ Possessed of the Patimokkha restraint ‘,

original: tasseva vevacanaṃ vatvā taṃ vitthāretvā dassento pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvutātiādimāha.
analyzed: tassa iva vevacanam vatvā tam vitthāretvā dassentaḥ pātimokkha saṃvara saṃvuta ati ādim āha
translated: and then he showed it in detail with the words ‘ Restraint by the Patimokkha rule ‘, etc.🔽Herein, the words ‘ Restraint by the Patimokkha rule ‘, etc., are in the place where the meaning has already been stated.

original: Tattha pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuttātiādīni vuttatthāneva. Ākaṅkheyya ceti idaṃ kasmā
analyzed: tattha pātimokkha saṃvara saṃvutta ati ādīni vutta tthān eva ākaṅkheyya ca iti idam kasmā
translated: If he should wish: why did he introduce this?🔽For the purpose of showing the benefits of virtue.

original: āraddhanti? Sīlānisaṃsadassanatthaṃ. Sacepi acirapabbajitānaṃ vā duppaññānaṃ vā evamassa
analyzed: āraddham ti sīla anisaṃsa dassana ttham sace pi acira pabbajitānam vā duppaññānam vā evam assa
translated: Even though it might occur to one who has gone forth not long ago or who is not wise thus:

original: “bhagavā ‘sīlaṃ pūretha sīlaṃ pūrethā’ti vadati, ko nu kho sīlapūraṇe ānisaṃso, ko🔽viseso, kā vaḍḍhī”ti tesaṃ dasa ānisaṃse dassetuṃ evamāha – “appeva nāma etaṃ sabrahmacārīnaṃ
analyzed: bhagavā sīlam pūretha sīlam pūretha ati vadati kaḥ nu kho sīla pūraṇe ānisaṃsaḥ kaḥ  viseso kā vaḍḍhi iti tesam dasa ānisaṃse dassetum evam āha appa iva nāma etam sabrahmacārīnam
translated: “The Blessed One says, ‘Fulfil virtue, fulfil virtue.’ But what is the benefit, what is the advantage of fulfilling virtue?🔽What is the distinction, the difference, the excellence of fulfilling virtue?”

original: piyamanāpatādiāsavakkhayapariyosānaṃ ānisaṃsaṃ sutvāpi sīlaṃ paripūreyyu”nti.
analyzed: piya manāpata ādi āsava khaya pariyosānam ānisaṃsam sutvā api sīlam paripūreyyunti
translated: In order to show them the ten benefits, he said this: “Perhaps they will fulfil virtue even on hearing the benefits of virtue, which end with the destruction of the cankers, from their companions in the life of purity.”

original: Tattha ākaṅkheyya ceti yadi iccheyya. Piyo cassanti piyacakkhūhi sampassitabbo, sinehuppattiyā🔽padaṭṭhānabhūto bhaveyyaṃ. Manāpoti tesaṃ manavaḍḍhanako, tesaṃ vā manena pattabbo,
analyzed: tattha ākaṅkheyya ca iti yadi iccheyya piyaḥ cassanti piya cakkhūhi sampassitabbaḥ sineha uppattiyā  padaṭṭhāna bhūtaḥ bhaveyyam manāpo ti tesam tesam vā manena pattabbo
translated: Herein, if he should wish is if he should desire. Dear is to be seen with dear eyes, he should be a basis for the arising of affection.

original: mettacittena pharitabboti attho. Garūti tesaṃ garuṭṭhāniyo pāsāṇacchattasadiso. Bhāvanīyoti
analyzed: metta cittena pharitabboti attho tesam tesam pāsāṇa chatta sadisaḥ bhāvanīyaḥ iti
translated: Dear is to be loved, or he is to be reached by mind, the meaning is that he is to be pervaded by loving-kindness.🔽Respected is to be respected by them, like a sunshade of stone. To be esteemed is

original: “addhāyamāyasmā jānaṃ jānāti passaṃ passatī”ti evaṃ sambhāvanīyo. Sīlesvevassa paripūrakārīti
analyzed: addhā ayam āyasmā jānam jānāti passam passati iti evam sambhāvanīyaḥ sīlesu eva assa paripūra kārī iti
translated: to be esteemed thus, “Surely this venerable one knows what is known, sees what is to be seen.” Fulfiller of virtue is

original: catupārisuddhisīlesuyeva paripūrakārī assa, anūnena ākārena samannāgato bhaveyyāti
analyzed: paripūra kārī assa anūnena ākārena samannāgataḥ bhaveyya ati
translated: He would be one who fulfilled the fourfold purity of virtue, and he would be endowed with the minimum form of virtue.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Ajjhattaṃ cetosamathamanuyuttoti attano cittasamathe yutto. Anirākatajjhānoti
analyzed: vuttam hoti ajjhattam cetaḥ samatham anuyuttaḥ ti attanaḥ citta samathe yuttaḥ a nirākata jhānaḥ ti
translated: This is the meaning. “Intent on the development of serenity of mind”: intent on the serenity of his own mind. “Not abandoning meditation”:

original: bahi anīhaṭajjhāno, avināsitajjhāno vā. Vipassanāyāti sattavidhāya anupassanāya.🔽Brūhetā suññāgārānanti vaḍḍhetā suññāgārānaṃ. Ettha ca samathavipassanāvasena kammaṭṭhānaṃ🔽gahetvā rattindivaṃ suññāgāraṃ pavisitvā nisīdamāno bhikkhu “brūhetā suññāgārāna”nti
analyzed: bahi anīhaṭa jhānaḥ avināsita jhānaḥ vā vipassanāya ati sattavidhāya anupassanāya  suññāgārānaṃ ti ettha ca samatha vipassanā vasena kammaṭṭhānaṃ  gahetvā rattindivam suññāgāram pavisitvā nisīdamānaḥ bhikkhu
